abstract: THERE were three living national treasures on hand for ''Korean Traditional Music and Dance'' to insure the solemnity of the program, performed on Wednesday at Asia Society. But this touring company of nine musicians, singers and dancers proved that ancient folk culture can also be delightfully low fun.   The indisputable stars of the evening were Kim So Hee and Park Dong Jin, both designated by the Korean Government as living national treasures and both practitioners of pansori, the dominant genre of traditional vocal music in the country. Accompanied by the drummer, the pansori singer tells an epic tale by means of song, narration and the merest suggestion of dramatic gesture.

abstract: Reaching for a word to throw at the returning exile Kim Dae Jung, South Korea's ruling soldiers have resorted to an all-purpose oldie: revolutionary. This is accurate in the sense that Jefferson, too, was a revolutionary. Mr. Kim agitates for free elections and civilian government - so strenuously that after a strong run for President in 1971 he was kidnapped from Japan, jailed and sentenced to death after a suspect military trial in 1980.    That sentence was soon commuted at U.S. request, to clear the way for Gen. Chun Doo Hwan to become the first head of state to visit President Reagan. Now the South Korean President wants to come again, in April. But first he must deal with that vexatious revolutionary, who plans to return to Seoul next month. Mr. Kim's timing is doubly shrewd because National Assembly elections occur four days after he arrives, and the regime wants to make the most of allowing this limited plebiscite.
lead_paragraph: Reaching for a word to throw at the returning exile Kim Dae Jung, South Korea's ruling soldiers have resorted to an all-purpose oldie: revolutionary. abstract: LEAD: Helped by rising exports and increased tourism, South Korea's current account surplus reached $9.8 billion in 1987, Bank of Korea officials said today. The current account, which includes trade in goods and services, was up sharply from $4.6 billion in 1986, officials of the central bank said. The December current account surplus widened to $942 million, from $857 million in November and $478 million in December 1986.

abstract: LEAD: South Korea's exports rose to a monthly record of $4.2 billion in July, from the previous high of $4.1 billion in June, the Trade Ministry said today. abstract: In the showroom where the Daewoo Corporation proudly displays its wares, giant panda dolls stand next to shelves of jogging shoes. Grand pianos bump up against scale-model tractors, cranes and ships. Personal computers vie for space with video recorders and stuffed toy rabbits.    But the same diversity that pleases Daewoo executives worries Government economists and angers the general public, who resent what they see as monopolies that keep domestic prices high and small businesses badly overmatched.

abstract: This nation's economy is booming again - welcome news for South Koreans who have weathered a year of economic downturn and months of political turmoil.   Led by what people here call the ''three blessings'' - lower oil prices, lower inflation and a currency that has depreciated with the dollar and made South Korean goods more competitive abroad - exports and economic growth are soaring.   The Government has already increased its estimate of growth in the gross national product and now predicts that the economy will expand between 8 percent and 9 percent this year - a forecast seconded by outside agencies such as the International Monetary Fund. Prospects of a Surplus    For the first time since the Korean War, officials expect a current account surplus, which they predict between $500 million and $800 million.
lead_paragraph: This nation's economy is booming again - welcome news for South Koreans who have weathered a year of economic downturn and months of political turmoil.

abstract: The value of foreign shipbuilding contracts won by South Korean concerns totaled $1.58 billion for 55 ships in the first eight months of this year, more than twice the $748 million for 44 vessels in the comparable 1980 period, officials of the Ministry of Commerce and Industry said today. Korean companies are also negotiating contracts for 47 ships worth $741 million, they said, adding that the ministry expects the 1981 target of $2 billion of ship construction to be surpassed.

abstract: The second of two South Korean children brought to the United States for open-heart surgery was operated on yesterday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I.   The child, Lee Kil Woo, 4 years old, was reported in critical guarded condition after surgery to repair a hole in the bottom of his heart.   The first child, Ahn Gi Sook, 7, underwent surgery Wednesday for numerous congenital defects of the heart and was reported in guarded condition yesterday in the hospital's intensive-care unit.

abstract: LEAD: During its 10 seasons, the Pan Asian Repertory Theater has introduced audiences to plays of Chinese, Japanese, Indian, Filipino and other Asian - and Asian-American - derivation. The current show, Che Inhoon's ''Wha . . . i, Whai, a Long Long Time Ago,'' is the first from Korea. In common with many of the previous plays given by this resourceful company, it demonstrates both a universal application and a cultural specificity.
lead_paragraph: During its 10 seasons, the Pan Asian Repertory Theater has introduced audiences to plays of Chinese, Japanese, Indian, Filipino and other Asian - and Asian-American - derivation. The current show, Che Inhoon's ''Wha . . . i, Whai, a Long Long Time Ago,'' is the first from Korea. In common with many of the previous plays given by this resourceful company, it demonstrates both a universal application and a cultural specificity. However, in contrast to other Pan Asian work, its theatricality is limited. The play, a contemporary work on a classic theme, was found by Tisa Chang, the Pan Asian artistic director, on a recent trip to Korea. As translated by Hui-jin Pak, ''Wha . . . i, Whai'' is running at Playhouse 46, 423 West 46th Street.

abstract: South Korea and Nicaragua have this much in common: Both are pseudo-democracies, ruled by self-enthroned soldiers who seek legitimacy through token elections. Though both have so far failed in that ambition, the Reagan Administration is plainly eager, for strategic reasons, to apply a looser, lesser standard of judgment in Korea. But the results of last Tuesday's election show what a mistake that would be.

abstract: The General Motors Corporation and South Korea's Daewoo group, a leading business conglomerate, said they had agreed to produce automotive parts by 1986 in a joint venture. Roger Smith, G.M.'s chairman, said total investment would come to $60 million. G.M. and Daewoo each would put in $10 million, with the remainder coming from loans, he said. G.M.'s Delco Remy division and Daewoo Precision Industries will turn out cranking motors, alternators, ignition distributors and ignition coils at the plant in Nongong, about 200 miles southeast of Seoul, G.M. said.

abstract: LEAD: The '88 Seoul Art Troupe will perform on Oct. 11 at 8 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall. The performance is the last in a five-city tour that opens on Oct. 1 at the Kennedy Center in Washington. The company, a group of 28 performers featured at the Olympic Arts Festival last year, will present modern-dance dramas inspired by the traditional religion and culture of Korean farmers, folk music and acrobatic dancing.
lead_paragraph: The '88 Seoul Art Troupe will perform on Oct. 11 at 8 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall. The company, a group of 28 performers featured at the Olympic Arts Festival last year, will present modern-dance dramas inspired by the traditional religion and culture of Korean farmers, folk music and acrobatic dancing. Tickets are $20 and $25; $10 for students. Information: 759-9550. Charge: 874-6770. The company will also perform on Oct. 3 at the Palace of Fine Arts Theater in San Francisco; on Oct. 5 at the Scottish Rite Theater in Los Angeles, and on Oct. 8 at Orchestra Hall in Chicago.

abstract: It's not just the luck of the draw that brings South Korea's Chun Doo Hwan to Washington today in the second week of the Reagan Presidency. President Chun needs the legitimizing approval of the United States, his country's chief ally and customer. And he wouldn't be here if President Reagan weren't willing, up to a point, to oblige. What happens may thereby define the new Administration's approach to an old and thorny problem - doing business with the ''free'' world's authoritarian regimes.

abstract:
Tell me,'' said the Rev. Choi Soong Mook, ''do you know of another country where they arrest priests?''

We were walking along the beach at Pusan, the busy South Korean port. A breeze blew off the ocean. Young couples sat on the benches, their hands clasped with that decorous Korean tenderness that is one of the country's most endearing traits. Under the beach umbrellas, far enough away not to be obvious, the ''shadows'' of the security police watched our every move.

I knew what my friend, a South Korean Methodist clergyman in his 50's, wanted me to say: that of course the jailing of priests and torture of theology students that have been taking place in South Korea under the military government of President Chun Doo Hwan was not the kind of behavior that the United States expected of its close allies. I sensed his real, unspoken question: Wasn't there something America could do? Why did people in the United States - and Western Europe - lavish such sympathy on the struggle of Christian churchmen for justice and democracy in Poland and the Soviet Union and Latin America and South Africa and pay so little attention to the same struggle going on in South Korea?

abstract: The Reagan Administration correctly insists that its low-key human rights policy should be judged by its fruits. They have ripened in South Korea, and the taste is bitter.   Last October, President Chun Doo Hwan proclaimed a new Constitution that, on paper, improved on the repressive Yushin charter devised by his slain predecessor, Park Chung Hee. The new guarantees have now been put to the test in a parliamentary election - and they proved to be paper indeed.
lead_paragraph: The Reagan Administration correctly insists that its low-key human rights policy should be judged by its fruits. They have ripened in South Korea, and the taste is bitter.

abstract: ''THE LAND OF MORNING CALM'' was a fine title for Sunday night's program of Korean classical dance and music at the Ohio Theater. The dances were as fresh as a spring morning, and they all progressed at an unruffled pace.   Many involved repetitions of simple patterns, and their placidity was emphasized by flowing costumes. Wearing a long-sleeved rainbowhued gown, Iris Park waved her sleeves decorously and stepped ceremoniously forward in a court dance. Du-Yee Chang also wore a long-sleeved costume in a solo. But his incantatory waving of the sleeves indicated that this was a dance for a shaman. Impersonating a sorceress, Miss Park held a bell and a fan in another shamanistic solo. Here, broad gestures gradually quickened, and Miss Park appeared to be conjuring up spirits.
lead_paragraph: ''THE LAND OF MORNING CALM'' was a fine title for Sunday night's program of Korean classical dance and music at the Ohio Theater. The dances were as fresh as a spring morning, and they all progressed at an unruffled pace.

abstract: Canada's state-owned nuclear power company has signed a contract worth $535 million (United States) to build a nuclear power plant for the Korea Electric Power Corporation.   The deal culminates more than 10 years of sales efforts by Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd. It will be the second Canadian reactor built in South Korea.   Officials said on Friday that the 700,000-kilowatt power plant, estimated to cost about $1 billion, would be built in Wolsong, 160 miles southeast of Seoul. It will be built next to the first Canadian reactor, which has been operating since 1983.    South Korea and Canada are each other's fifth-largest trading partners. Trade between the companies is expected to reach $4 billion in 1990.   The Korean power company, known as Kepco, has nine nuclear power plants in operation and two more under construction. The Government expects to have 50 nuclear plants in operation in the next 40 years.   A turbine generator for the new plant will be supplied by the General Electric Company, along with the Korea Heavy Industries and Construction Company, under a contract to be signed soon, officials said. Construction is scheduled to be completed by mid-1997.
lead_paragraph: Canada's state-owned nuclear power company has signed a contract worth $535 million (United States) to build a nuclear power plant for the Korea Electric Power Corporation.

abstract: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea, who was in New York today prior to his visit to Washington and talks with President Reagan on Monday, is a military man. A paratroop officer who served in Vietnam, he was an unknown army intelligence chief under President Park Chung Hee when Mr. Park was murdered by the head of his own secret service in October 1979.   Mr. Chun was born on Jan. 18, 1931, in a hamlet near Taegu in what is now central South Korea - an inhospitable, mountainous region - as the son of a poor farmer. Japanese colonial rule of Korea ended in 1945, and soon after the Korean War began in 1950 Mr. Chun gained admission to the 11th class of the Korean Military Academy. It was the first class to receive a full four years of training, and from it came many of the men who now dominate South Korea.
lead_paragraph: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea, who was in New York today prior to his visit to Washington and talks with President Reagan on Monday, is a military man. abstract: Leaders of North and South Korea, concluding their third round of talks this morning in an atmosphere of discord, failed to narrow their differences over a proposed "declaration of non-aggression," but scheduled another round of talks for late February in the North Korean capital, Pyongyang. abstract: The South Korean Government plans to provide $2.1 billion in grants and loans in the next five years to help finance industries' development of manufacturing technology, the Trade and Industry Ministry reported today.    The plan was outlined n a report submitted to President Roh Tae Woo.   Officials said 919 technology-development projects would be assigned to Korean manufacturing companies, yet to be selected, under the plan, which begins this year.   They said the Government had decided to give priority to revitalizing manufacturing industries through development of technology so that the nation's sagging exports could regain lost competitiveness.   South Korea lags behind industrialized nations in high technology for electronics, new materials, bio-engineering and aerospace.   Officials said about 20 percent of the money would come in official grants, with the remainder in loans with interest rates of 8 percent to 9 percent a year. Bank loans here now carry an annual interest rate of about 12 percent.   They said South Korea would seek 7 joint research projects with Japan and would cooperate with the Soviet Union on 350 projects, mostly for technology transfer to Korea. They did not say what areas would be involved.
lead_paragraph: The South Korean Government plans to provide $2.1 billion in grants and loans in the next five years to help finance industries' development of manufacturing technology, the Trade and Industry Ministry reported today.

abstract: LEAD: Forty years after the cold war turned hot, North and South Korea are about to engage again -at the conference table. New warmth between the U.S. and the Soviet Union is thawing relations between the Koreas. That's a hopeful development. It could, among other benefits, allow the U.S. to bring more troops home.

abstract: LEAD: The Japan Air Lines Company said today that it would cooperate with Korean Air Lines to develop their computer reservation systems jointly. It said the companies would trade data bases and establish reciprocal access between Japan Air's Axcess computer reservation system and Korean Air's Topas system.
lead_paragraph: The Japan Air Lines Company said today that it would cooperate with Korean Air Lines to develop their computer reservation systems jointly. It said the companies would trade data bases and establish reciprocal access between Japan Air's Axcess computer reservation system and Korean Air's Topas system. Conditions for the cooperation have yet to be discussed, a statement said. It also said the airlines would cooperate in developing joint business strategies to compete with other computer reservation systems.

abstract: LEAD: The South Korean automobile industry produced 957,394 vehicles in 1987, up 63.3 percent from the previous year, according to a report issued today. Nearly a third of the vehicles were exported. Yonhap, the South Korean press agency, quoted unidentified industry sources as saying that auto exports totaled 304,471 vehicles, up 78.3 percent from 1986 levels.

abstract: The state-owned Saudi Arabian Oil Company today announced an agreement in principle to set up a joint oil refining company in South Korea with the Ssangyong Oil Refining Company, the official Saudi press agency reported.   The agency said the joint company would use Ssangyong's oil refineries in Korea to process and market petroleum products throughout the Far East. Saudi Aramco will supply up to 175,000 barrels a day of crude oil to the joint venture, the agency said.   The announcement represents the second major oil venture overseas by Saudi Arabia, which controls the world's largest crude reserves. In 1988, the Saudis created Star Enterprise, a United States refining joint venture with Texaco Inc.   Saudi Aramco and Ssangyong Oil will each own half of a new company, identified by the agency as the Han Saudi Oil Refining Company. Saudi Aramco will supply all the joint venture's crude, the news agency said.   Ssangyong Oil is the third-largest refining company in South Korea and is part of the Ssangyong Group, the fifth-largest Korean industrial group, the agency said.
lead_paragraph: The state-owned Saudi Arabian Oil Company today announced an agreement in principle to set up a joint oil refining company in South Korea with the Ssangyong Oil Refining Company, the official Saudi press agency reported.

abstract: Officials in the International Olympic Committee said today that North Korea has failed to reply to an invitation to a meeting scheduled for I.O.C. headquarters early next year to discuss the country's demand to act as a co-host of the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul, the South Korean capital.   The officials, speaking on condition that their names not be used, said that unless North Korea explicitly abandons its demand to divide the 1988 Games equally, the meeting of South Korean, North Korean and I.O.C. officials set for Jan. 8-9 will be canceled.

lead_paragraph: Police divers searched today for at least 20 passengers reported missing after a bus slid off a highway bridge into a river, a South Korean news agency, Yonhap, reported. The rescued passengers told the agency that about 20 others were missing.

lead_paragraph: Riot policemen with sticks and shields clashed with thousands of marchers who gathered today to protest the death of a student, Lee Chul Kyu, whose body was found on Wednesday in a reservoir near Kwangju. Some of the 4,000 troops were beaten by protesters armed with bamboo sticks. The protesters said Mr. Lee was tortured to death by the police. The police denied involvement. The Government is conducting an investigation.

abstract: THE Korean economy is a miracle. In a little more than 20 dizzying years, a country torn apart by war has become an emerging economic power - another Japan of sorts.   But the Korean miracle gets its strength from booming exports, and now the rise of world protectionism threatens to undo this small Asian nation's formula for rapid economic growth.   The challenge to Korea's economic success makes this week's annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank in Seoul all the more important. By coming to Seoul, the elite of the financial community is applauding Korea's accomplishments. At the same time, the delegates are taking up precisely the issues that concern Korea most - trade and debt.
lead_paragraph: THE Korean economy is a miracle. In a little more than 20 dizzying years, a country torn apart by war has become an emerging economic power - another Japan of sorts.

abstract: A new and virulent anti-Americanism, endorsed by a small but fervent minority of South Koreans, is finding expression in threats directed at Americans here.   Diplomats, Government officials and opposition politicians say they believe most Koreans still regard the United States with gratitude and friendship, a view borne out by contacts with ordinary Koreans. But they say antagonism to the United States is growing, fed by a mixture of economic tensions, pride in South Korea's accomplishments and a belief that the United States is too close to the Government of President Chun Doo Hwan.   For protesting students and workers, the United States is a symbol of foreign interference in Korean history. They say they believe the American presence resulted in Korea's division after World War II and prevents the nation from being reunited now. They view the United States as an imperialist power that has supported repressive governments around the world and in their own country.
lead_paragraph: A new and virulent anti-Americanism, endorsed by a small but fervent minority of South Koreans, is finding expression in threats directed at Americans here.

abstract: LEAD: South Korea's exports in May rose 16 percent, to $4.67 billion, from $4.02 billion a year ago, but the rate of increase was below the brisk pace set in the first four months of the year, the Trade and Foreign Ministry said today. The rise in exports in the four-month period averaged 32.5 percent. Imports in May totaled $4.23 billion, up 16.6 percent from $3.63 billion a year earlier.

abstract: LEAD: South Korea's foreign debt declined by $4.4 billion during 1988, the Bank of Korea reported today. The country's foreign debt fell to $31.2 billion in December 1988 from $35.6 billion in December 1987, the bank said. Bank officials said South Korea registered a record trade surplus of $14.27 billion in its current account in 1988, up 44.8 percent from $9.85 billion in 1987.
lead_paragraph: South Korea's foreign debt declined by $4.4 billion during 1988, the Bank of Korea reported today. The country's foreign debt fell to $31.2 billion in December 1988 from $35.6 billion in December 1987, the bank said. Bank officials said South Korea registered a record trade surplus of $14.27 billion in its current account in 1988, up 44.8 percent from $9.85 billion in 1987. It was the third consecutive year of a trade surplus.

abstract: North Korea said today that it had sent an urgent request to the International Olympic Committee to cancel the choice of Seoul, capital of South Korea, as the site for the 1988 Summer Olympics. It warned that South Korea was unstable, facing constant danger of war because of the presence of 40,000 United States troops.   The request came in a letter to Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the I.O.C., from the chairman of North Korea's Olympic committee, according to a broadcast by North Korea's official Pyongyang radio that was monitored in London.
lead_paragraph: North Korea said today that it had sent an urgent request to the International Olympic Committee to cancel the choice of Seoul, capital of South Korea, as the site for the 1988 Summer Olympics. It warned that South Korea was unstable, facing constant danger of war because of the presence of 40,000 United States troops.

abstract: LEAD: A Chinese television factory has signed an agreement with a South Korean company, the first time the Seoul Government has approved a direct investment by a company from a Communist nation, the Finance Ministry said Tuesday. The Hanzhou TV Factory will invest $2.8 million in a joint venture with the Orion Electric Company of South Korea and the Zhejiang Fuchen Company of Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese television factory has signed an agreement with a South Korean company, the first time the Seoul Government has approved a direct investment by a company from a Communist nation, the Finance Ministry said Tuesday. The Hanzhou TV Factory will invest $2.8 million in a joint venture with the Orion Electric Company of South Korea and the Zhejiang Fuchen Company of Hong Kong. A ministry spokesman said the venture was expected to produce 580,000 tubes for color TV sets in 1989, 1.1 million of the 20-inch tubes in 1990 and 1.2 million in 1992.

abstract: South Korea charged North Korea today with firing ''several'' rounds of automatic rifle fire across the demilitarized zone between the two countries. The gunfire came eight miles north of Chorwon, a border town 70 miles northeast of Seoul, at 6:15 P.M. Monday, the Defense Ministry said. It did not say whether there were injuries or damage.
lead_paragraph: South Korea charged North Korea today with firing ''several'' rounds of automatic rifle fire across the demilitarized zone between the two countries. abstract: LEAD: South Korea today reported a sharp fall in its trade surplus with the United States in the first quarter, with imports of American goods rising sharply. Trade Ministry officials said the surplus in the first three months of 1989 fell 34 percent, to $1.2 billion, from the period in 1988. South Korean imports from the United States soared 25 percent, to $3.3 billion, while exports to the United States rose only 1 percent, to $4.5 billion, preliminary figures indicate.
lead_paragraph: South Korea today reported a sharp fall in its trade surplus with the United States in the first quarter, with imports of American goods rising sharply. abstract: North Korea has proposed a conference with the United States and South Korea aimed at unifying Korea, the Pyongyang radio said today.   A broadcast, monitored here, also said North Korea would be willing to discuss any issues the two other parties cared to bring up. It said the proposal was made Tuesday in a joint session of the Central People's Committee, the collective presidency, and the presidium of the Supreme People's Assembly, the nominal legislature.

abstract: LEAD: South Korea's trade surplus with the United States shrank by 15.7 percent in the first seven months of the year, to $4.66 billion, from $5.53 billion a year earlier, the Government reported today. Officials attributed the reduction to Korea's revaluation of the won. Korean merchandise exports to the United States rose 10.8 percent, to $11.39 billion, in the period, while imports from the United States surged by 41.5 percent, to $6.73 billion, the report said.

abstract: LEAD: South Korea's gross national product is expected to grow 11 percent this year, instead of the 10 percent previously projected, the Bank of Korea said Friday. abstract: Some businessmen here have an unpleasant vision. They picture the United States as a boxer taking a trade-protectionist punch at Japan. Only Japan is adroit, and the blow proves to be a glancing one that catches adjacent South Korea on the chin instead.   But at the Ministry of Trade and Industry in Seoul, the assistant minister, Kim Chul-soo, thinks that some of his countrymen may be overwrought. ''Korea is not a likely second sparring partner for the United States,'' he said.
lead_paragraph: Some businessmen here have an unpleasant vision. They picture the United States as a boxer taking a trade-protectionist punch at Japan. Only Japan is adroit, and the blow proves to be a glancing one that catches adjacent South Korea on the chin instead.

abstract: LEAD: A South Korean company has won a Libyan contract to build a water pipeline, the largest construction contract ever awarded in the Middle East, a company spokesman said today. The spokesman for the Dong Ah Construction Industrial Company said the value of the 90-month contract for the 683-mile pipeline totals $5.3 billion.
lead_paragraph: A South Korean company has won a Libyan contract to build a water pipeline, the largest construction contract ever awarded in the Middle East, a company spokesman said today. The spokesman for the Dong Ah Construction Industrial Company said the value of the 90-month contract for the 683-mile pipeline totals $5.3 billion. The pipe will bring water from underground reservoirs in the Sahara to the Tripoli area. It is the second phase of a project to supply water to densely populated coastal areas.

abstract: The 70,000-man army deployed on the streets of Seoul last weekend was not meant to repel a Communist invasion from the North but a democratic mobilization in the South. In that, South Korea's Government succeeded all too well. This inappropriate show of force can only complicate the crisis over the South Korean presidential succession in 1988. The democratic opposition now threatens to boycott the National Assembly. By frustrating the most prudent opposition forces, the Government of President Chun Doo Hwan jeopardizes its own legitimacy and American security interests.

abstract: South Korea's exports of steel products rose 9.5 percent, to the equivalent of $1.22 billion in the first half of 1984 from a year earlier, the Korea Iron and Steel Association said today. The association said exports of sheets and plates totaled $502 million in the first half of the year, up 9.6 percent from the first half of 1983. Steel pipe exports rose 30.9 percent, to $222 million, and steel rod shipments rose 49.3 percent, to $166 million.

abstract: South Korea's state-run Korea Electric Power Corporation and the Korea Advanced Energy Research Institute will form a joint venture to produce nuclear fuel for power generation, officials of the Energy and Resources Ministry said today. The new company will soon start talks with foreign companies to set up a joint venture plant capable of fabricating 200 tons of nuclear fuel a year beginning in 1988, they added. Korea will build eight more atomic plants by 1989, the officials said.

abstract: A North Korean official said today that his country had agreed to South Korea's conditions for delivering relief goods intended for South Korean flood victims, according to a report monitored here.    The announcement by Han Ung Shik, vice chairman of the North Korean Red Cross Society's Central Committee, was carried by the official Pyongyang radio and was monitored here by Radio Press, a Japanese agency.   If the report of an agreement is accurate, it will mark one of the few times the rival Governments of North and South Korea have agreed on an issue.

abstract: LEAD: Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher and South Korea's Minister of Trade and Industry, Han Seung Soo, signed an agreement Tuesday to create a joint committee on commercial cooperation intended to expand trade and reduce friction. The committee will develop opportunities for cooperation in trade and investment, and exchange technical information and data on mutually beneficial development projects.
lead_paragraph: Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher and South Korea's Minister of Trade and Industry, Han Seung Soo, signed an agreement Tuesday to create a joint committee on commercial cooperation intended to expand trade and reduce friction. The committee will develop opportunities for cooperation in trade and investment, and exchange technical information and data on mutually beneficial development projects. ''Our ability to address areas of potential cooperation will lead not only to expanded trade, but reduced friction,'' Mr. Mosbacher said.

abstract: LEAD: THE WEST HAS LONG been familiar with the art of China and Japan, but Korean art remained relatively unknown until the mid-1970's. Viewed as a mere imitation of its two neighbors, the culture was generally overlooked. One effort to correct this situation is an exhibition of 100 works - ''From the Land of Morning Calm: Korean Art at the Brooklyn Museum.
lead_paragraph: THE WEST HAS LONG been familiar with the art of China and Japan, but Korean art remained relatively unknown until the mid-1970's. Viewed as a mere imitation of its two neighbors, the culture was generally overlooked. One effort to correct this situation is an exhibition of 100 works - ''From the Land of Morning Calm: Korean Art at the Brooklyn Museum.'' The exhibition, which opened recently and continues until Jan. 4 testifies to the distinctness of that culture, maintained throughout a 5,000-year history of occupations by China and Japan as well as internal feudal turmoil.

abstract: South Korea, ending weeks of negotiations, has agreed to confine its steel exports to the United States to 1.9 percent of the domestic market and has agreed on the categories of steel to be covered by the limits, the United States Trade Representative's Office said yesterday.   Officials said the agreement, reached last week, ended the talks between the two nations that began last year.

abstract: Few outside events have fired the imagination of South Korea's political dissidents as much as the fall of Ferdinand E. Marcos in the Philippines. It takes little prodding, sometimes none at all, to set opposition politicians to talking hopefully about how the same sort of lightning might strike here.   ''You have many dictatorships in Asia,'' says Kim Dae Jung, the most prominent anti-Government figure. ''But only in South Korea and the Philippines do you have people actively seeking democracy. They succeeded in the Philippines, and maybe we will succeed here.''
lead_paragraph: Few outside events have fired the imagination of South Korea's political dissidents as much as the fall of Ferdinand E. Marcos in the Philippines. abstract: Less than a month after their official introduction, all South Korean-made Hyundai cars sold in the United States are being recalled because a missing or damaged part could cause total brake failure, the importer says. Four thousand cars may be involved in the recall, Bruce Matthias, spokesman for Hyundai Motor America Inc., said Monday. The Hyundai Excel subcompacts, which have a list price of $4,995, are the first Korean cars to be sold in the United States.

abstract: Pope John Paul II will visit Seoul next May 3-6 to commemorate the 200th anniversary of the introduction of Christianity into Korea. abstract: LEAD: It's a dazzling time for South Korea. Its economy is churning out the world's highest growth rate. The Seoul Olympics won wide applause. And now, most impressive of all, the nation steadily consolidates a new and remarkably supple political democracy. That suppleness now faces its trickiest test. The initial response seems encouraging.
lead_paragraph: It's a dazzling time for South Korea. Its economy is churning out the world's highest growth rate. The Seoul Olympics won wide applause. And now, most impressive of all, the nation steadily consolidates a new and remarkably supple political democracy. That suppleness now faces its trickiest test. The initial response seems encouraging. Backed by broad public opinion, an opposition majority in the National Assembly demands that former President Chun Doo Hwan be held accountable for a litany of abuses, from corrupt diversion of funds to the 1980 massacre of civilians at Kwangju.

abstract: CLYDE HABERMAN is the Tokyo bureau chief of The New York Times.  Not many tours require you to sign a form freeing the organizers from responsibility in case you get killed.  That may be the least unusual aspect of a trip to Panmunjom. More disconcerting is how hard it can be to tell the real from the illusory. To visit the Korean demilitarized zone is to experience diversion in the form of propaganda. The effect can be intriguing. It can also be disturbing.    Panmunjom is the village near the 38th parallel where the truce ending the Korean War was signed in 1953. It sits in drabness within the 151-mile-long DMZ. On more than 400 occasions over the last 30 years, the multinational Military Armistice Commission has convened there to listen North and South Korea accuse each other truce violations. Nothing gets accomplished at these sessions, except maybe a good deal of haranguing and finger-pointing. Even the miniature national flags standing atop a table in the main Panmunjom conference room reflect the mutual hostility - their size and shape being the product of hard-won compromise.
lead_paragraph: CLYDE HABERMAN is the Tokyo bureau chief of The New York Times. Not many tours require you to sign a form freeing the organizers from responsibility in case you get killed. That may be the least unusual aspect of a trip to Panmunjom. More disconcerting is how hard it can be to tell the real from the illusory. To visit the Korean demilitarized zone is to experience diversion in the form of propaganda. The effect can be intriguing. It can also be disturbing.

abstract: Despite long and mostly cordial bargaining, North and South Korean officials failed to agree today on how North Korea could carry out an offer to send relief supplies to recent flood victims in the South.    The two sides, meeting in this truce village inside the Korean demilitarized zone, broke off talks over the issue of whether North Korea would be allowed to carry supplies directly to the South Korean capital of Seoul. There was no firm decision on whether to meet again, and it seemed unlikely - even if another session was scheduled, as North Korea proposed - that either country would compromise enough to allow a historic first exchange of material across their hostile border.    The North Korean Government in Pyongyang had said it was ready to send food and other assistance to victims of severe floods in the South that early this month killed about 190 people, left 200,000 homeless and damaged crops. The North offered medicine, 14,300 tons of rice, 550,000 yards of cloth and 100,000 tons of cement.
lead_paragraph: Despite long and mostly cordial bargaining, North and South Korean officials failed to agree today on how North Korea could carry out an offer to send relief supplies to recent flood victims in the South.

abstract: For the first time in several years, the diverse elements that loosely make up South Korea's anti-Government camp have an issue they can rally around. Dissident politicians, clergymen and activist students have begun to demand direct Presidential elections next year to supersede an electoral college system generally presumed to favor President Chun Doo Hwan and anyone he may want as his successor when his term expires in early 1988.   Opposition politicians in particular have pressed the issue. Campus militants picked up the call, and last week the campaign gained momentum when South Korea's Roman Catholic primate, Stephen Cardinal Kim Sou Hwan, added his support. For a preacher who had not said much lately about politics, the Cardinal was surprisingly critical. Not to be outdone, the Korean National Council of Churches, representing 3 million Protestants, shook off a long political torpor late in the week, calling for a constitutional revision to permit direct elections.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in several years, the diverse elements that loosely make up South Korea's anti-Government camp have an issue they can rally around. Dissident politicians, clergymen and activist students have begun to demand direct Presidential elections next year to supersede an electoral college system generally presumed to favor President Chun Doo Hwan and anyone he may want as his successor when his term expires in early 1988.

abstract: KIM JUNG SOO arrived at the Hyundai Motor Company nine years ago with all his belongings in two suitcases. He worked long hours at the factory in the small South Korean city of Ulsan, struggling to make cars on an assembly line that had yet to be automated. He had no place to live, so he slept on the floor of a friend's apartment. ''I was very poor,'' he recalls. ''The working conditions were not so good. I thought, 'How can I continue to work here in the future?' ''   Today, Mr. Kim is a foreman in a modern plant, supervising the manufacture of the Hyundai Excel, the hottest new low-priced car in the North American market. A lean, soft-spoken man with a weather-beaten face, the 39-year-old Kim Jung Soo is married and has two young children. He wants them to grow up to be ''important people'' and is setting aside half of his $920 monthly salary for their education. When he talks about Hyundai Motors now, he says it is a company that gives him everything: ''clothes, shoes, and even underwear.''

abstract: LEAD: President Chun Doo Hwan's repressive South Korean Government doesn't deserve much benefit of doubt. But Mr. Chun has cause now to be more reasonable. He desperately seeks success for the Olympics in his country next year and the legitimacy the games will confer. This gives the democratic opposition real leverage.
lead_paragraph: President Chun Doo Hwan's repressive South Korean Government doesn't deserve much benefit of doubt. But Mr. Chun has cause now to be more reasonable. He desperately seeks success for the Olympics in his country next year and the legitimacy the games will confer. This gives the democratic opposition real leverage. There could be an opportunity here for opposition leaders to find an accommodation, to establish democracy without a mutually destructive showdown.

abstract: LEAD: President Chun Doo Hwan has radically simplified South Korea's political choices. For a time, it looked as though the issue was how much democracy he would allow to succeed him. Now the contest seems to be between him and democracy - and he is winning. By suspending national debate over how to choose his successor, he contradicts the spirit, if not the letter, of his own promises.

abstract:
NEWARK 

 DISCARDED candy wrappers, long-forgotten business memorandums and old cardboard coffee containers formed a crude doormat on the marble entranceway to what was once a retail sewing-machine business when Andy Youm and his family took over the premises three years ago.

Today, the once-empty space on the northwest corner of Halsey and Academy Streets is filled with delicatessen and grocery-store items. The floors, counters and windows sparkle under bright lights, and a constant stream of executives, office workers and shoppers buy goods ranging from sandwiches and coffee to detergents. 

The Youms are among a growing number of Koreans who, in the last 10 years or so, have opened retail stores in downtown Newark, sometimes moving into vacant space, sometimes taking over established concerns.

abstract: Banking, it is said, is the art of gauging risk, deciding whether a client has plans or dreams and then approving or denying a loan.    In South Korea this fundamental bankers' art is not highly developed. The reason is that for the last two decades Korean banks have been essentially instruments of Government policy, funneling money into industries marked for rapid expansion.   ''Korean banks were public corporations without incentives to innovate and become more efficient,'' said Kim Mahn-je, president of the KorAm Bank. ''But things have changed. From now on, the banks will have to start acting more like banks.''
lead_paragraph: Banking, it is said, is the art of gauging risk, deciding whether a client has plans or dreams and then approving or denying a loan.

abstract: When Samul-Nori, the ensemble of four South Korean dancers and percussionists, returns to New York tonight, plumes will whirl and the Asia Society's Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium will echo with the sounds of the puk and the changgo, the ching and the kkwaeng'gwari.   Those instruments are Korean drums and gongs and the plumes are those on the hats of the young men who make up this troupe. What causes the plumes to whirl is the fact that, in several numbers, the performers dance as they play their percussion instruments. The music begins in a stately fashion, then clangs ahead while the dancers' steps go from ceremonial walks to great leaps and dizzying spins.  Samul-Nori amazed audiences at its New York debut in 1983 and is doing so again on its current American tour.
lead_paragraph: When Samul-Nori, the ensemble of four South Korean dancers and percussionists, returns to New York tonight, plumes will whirl and the Asia Society's Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium will echo with the sounds of the puk and the changgo, the ching and the kkwaeng'gwari.

abstract: CLYDE HABERMAN    SEOUL, South Korea - As Pope John Paul II arrived last week on an 11-day swing across Asia, several dozen young men and women held a peaceful anti-Government demonstration in the offices of the National Council of Churches. The Protestant-led council, with 2.1 million members, is a frequent critic of South Korea's authoritarian Government. Its headquarters are commonly used to make a political point. Hardly anyone in Seoul was aware of this sit-in because such events are almost never reported in the highly regulated press. Nevertheless, the protest was a reminder that the churches have long been the chief organized opposition to successive governments possessing limited tolerance for free expression.    These have been desultory days for Korean churches, their human-rights voice muted during a period of introspection and what a Protestant clergyman called ''regrouping.'' Recent anti- Government activism has been largely expressed in the universities. Nearly daily student demonstrations have often led to rock-throwing and police tear-gas attacks. During last week's quiet sit-in at the church council, hundreds of students were battling policemen at two Seoul campuses, one only several hundred yards from a seminary where the Pope was celebrating mass. The student protests continued this weekend.

abstract: Before packing his bags for Europe, President Reagan did his duty for a difficult ally, President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea. What wasn't said spoke loudest at this smoothly managed visit, whose importance should not be lost in the summit shuffle. There was no reference to South Korea's unseemly treatment in March of the returning exile Kim Dae Jung and his American escorts. That was passed over silently as Mr. Reagan toasted South Korea's progress in ''political development,'' the sanitized word for human rights.

abstract: The Roman Catholic primate of South Korea, Stephen Cardinal Kim Sou Hwan, gave his support today to opposition party demands for swift constitutional changes that would permit direct presidential elections.   Cardinal Kim, in a midday sermon at Myongdong Cathedral in Seoul, called on President Chun Doo Hwan to make the necessary revisions before his term expired in March 1988 so a successor could be chosen under an amended constitution. At present the president is chosen by an electoral college.   The issue of constitutional change has brought the South Korean Government and the main opposition party into direct conflict for the last month. Today the Cardinal, in a sermon that was unusual for its political content, warned that how they resolve the matter ''will determine the survival and future of our nation.''
lead_paragraph: The Roman Catholic primate of South Korea, Stephen Cardinal Kim Sou Hwan, gave his support today to opposition party demands for swift constitutional changes that would permit direct presidential elections.

abstract: Three South Korean students have been arrested on charges of leading an anti-Government demonstration, the police said today. abstract: LEAD: South Korea's three auto makers reported today that their combined exports soared 97.4 percent in February, to 49,879 cars, from 25,270 in the same month last year. Officials said that the February shipments were mostly passenger cars and that more than 90 percent of them were to the United States and Canada.
lead_paragraph: South Korea's three auto makers reported today that their combined exports soared 97.4 percent in February, to 49,879 cars, from 25,270 in the same month last year. Officials said that the February shipments were mostly passenger cars and that more than 90 percent of them were to the United States and Canada. The Hyundai Motor Company topped the list with 33,803 autos, followed by the Kia Motors Corporation with 10,360 and Daewoo Motor with 5,716. No statistics for a year earlier were given.

abstract: The future of the South Korean economy, by most accounts, rests in the hands of people like Park Sung-Kyou.   Mr. Park is engineering the technology strategy of the $3.3 billion- a-year Daewoo Corporation, one of Korea's giant industrial groups, as it plunges into such fields as semiconductors, telecommunications and office automation.   South Korea's economy has grown rapidly on the strength of such industries as textiles, construction, shipbuilding and simple electronics. But for its economic advance to continue, it must now make products that are more sophisticated, and whose competitiveness depends more on technical skill and less on cheap labor.
lead_paragraph: The future of the South Korean economy, by most accounts, rests in the hands of people like Park Sung-Kyou.

abstract: Nearly 3,000 South Koreans held an anti-Government rally a few weeks ago in the southern town of Hapchon, after which came a two-mile march through the streets.   In a country where protest is a part of daily life, the incident normally would have drawn little attention. But the demonstrators were unusual: they were gray-robed Buddhist priests who filled the grounds of the Haein Temple, an ancient compound nestled in thick woods.   As a social force, Korean Buddhism has been quiet for decades. Politically, it also has whispered its presence, a fact made especially noticeable because Christian denominations are flourishing and gaining in influence.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 3,000 South Koreans held an anti-Government rally a few weeks ago in the southern town of Hapchon, after which came a two-mile march through the streets.

abstract: DANCES by choreographers from Brazil and Korea opened the Third World Theater Arts Festival on Tuesday night at La Mama Annex. The festival, which continues through Sunday, has been organized by the Third World Institute of Theater Arts Studies and the International League of Folk Arts for Communication and Education under the direction of Cecile Guidote Alvarez.     The program's two dances were similar in several respects. Each lasted approximately 65 minutes and was ritualistic in nature.

abstract: There are any number of economic success stories in South Korea, but the automobile industry is not one of them. At least, not yet.    During the 1970's, in a push to turn South Korea into a major car exporter, the Government promoted an ambitious buildup of industry production capacity. But the effort was premature, and the resulting products were not competitive in performance and quality, especially against Japanese exports. From 1980 to 1982, the industry lost some $200 million and its plants operated at less than 50 percent of capacity.
lead_paragraph: There are any number of economic success stories in South Korea, but the automobile industry is not one of them. At least, not yet.

abstract: BELEAGUERED opposition party members took heart last week when one of their leaders, Kim Dae Jung, challenged the Government, saying he would not run if it would hold direct presidential elections.   Opposition leaders hoped Mr. Kim's announcement would blunt a Government offensive that has thrown them off balance, Korean and Western analysts say. Last spring, the opposition - a loose coalition of politicians, religious leaders, laborers and students whose political views range from moderate to radical - was riding high. Petitions and rallies calling for direct presidential elections had forced the Government to permit discussion of political change. Officials who had excoriated the petition drive as a plot to foment unrest spoke instead about heeding the evident desire for change.
lead_paragraph: BELEAGUERED opposition party members took heart last week when one of their leaders, Kim Dae Jung, challenged the Government, saying he would not run if it would hold direct presidential elections.

abstract: The parallels between Japan and South Korea are striking. Yet if you ask one of the bright, aggressive Korean technocrats whether their economy is another Japan in the making, they'll flinch.    These American-educated economists, M.B.A.'s and engineers, who have been given enormous policy-making power, are justifiably proud of their record. But they know that the future depends on continuing access to markets and technology from more developed countries. If America should come to view this nascent economic giant as a competitor, both countries will be the losers.
lead_paragraph: The parallels between Japan and South Korea are striking. Yet if you ask one of the bright, aggressive Korean technocrats whether their economy is another Japan in the making, they'll flinch.

abstract: A question that perhaps drew more curiosity here than almost any other in the last few days was whether Pope John Paul II caught a whiff of tear gas fired by the police at students demonstrating near a seminary where he was celebrating mass.    Some people who were present at the mass Thursday night said the Pope had dabbed at his eyes and sneezed, but Vatican officials said the fumes never bothered him and that, in fact, he was not aware of any disturbance.   The sneezing question focused attention on the anti-Government protests that have disrupted major South Korean colleges all spring, producing clashes at campus gates between rock- throwing students and policemen armed with tear-gas canisters.   Basic Frustration    Demonstrations, joined at various times by several hundred to several thousand young people, have broken out at half a dozen schools in Seoul and on campuses elsewhere, notably at Kwangju in the southwest, where opposition to President Chun Doo Hwan is strong.
lead_paragraph: A question that perhaps drew more curiosity here than almost any other in the last few days was whether Pope John Paul II caught a whiff of tear gas fired by the police at students demonstrating near a seminary where he was celebrating mass.

abstract: American auto makers are again looking to the Far East to find a nation that offers low labor costs, a well- educated and hard-working labor force and a government that encourages big business. But it is not Japan that has drawn their attention this time, but South Korea.    In June, the General Motors Corporation and the Daewoo Motor Company signed a $426 million agreement to produce 167,000 cars a year in South Korea by 1987. About half those cars will be exported, with many expected to be distributed in the United States by the Pontiac Division of General Motors.

abstract: The South Korean Government is coming under fire for policies that some say have led to a marked slowdown in economic growth.   According to the Bank of Korea, the nation's gross national product grew 4.1 percent in the first three months of this year, the lowest quarterly growth rate in nearly four years and 8.4 percentage points below the rate for the first quarter of 1984.   Government economists insist the slowdown is not structural, and although they have lowered their estimates for growth for the rest of the year they see the situation as temporary. Yet they are facing mounting pressure to reduce Korea's $43 billion foreign debt.
lead_paragraph: The South Korean Government is coming under fire for policies that some say have led to a marked slowdown in economic growth.

abstract: Text of Hirohito remarks, page A6.             TOKYO, Sept. 6 - Emperor Hirohito of Japan, who once ruled Korea as its colonial master, welcomed South Korea's President to the Imperial Palace tonight and said he was sorry for his country's past behavior.   ''It is indeed regrettable,'' the Emperor said in a banquet toast, ''that there was an unfortunate past between us for a period in this century, and I believe that it should not be repeated again.''    The comment to President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea was reminiscent of other regrets that Hirohito voiced over the last decade to the United States and to China for Japan's wartime conduct.

abstract: Predicting that President Chun Doo Hwan will be out of office by fall, the leader of the banned New Democratic Party says South Korea must then move toward ''the restoration of democratic institutions.''   In an interview, the politician, Kim Young Sam, said Mr. Chun could ''not last longer than this coming autumn'' because of the vast financial scandal that erupted recently involving the President's family. Mr. Chun shuffled his Cabinet, and several close relatives of the President and his wife resigned their posts in statecontrolled organizations as a result of fraudulent money market transactions that led to the bankruptcy of several companies.   Mr. Kim said the nation now faced the question of ''not whether'' Mr. Chun should be replaced but ''how we can do this by peaceful means.''   ''Here you have a man,'' Mr. Kim said of the President, ''who has never stood in a free and open election and who is weighed down with a dramatic loss of public confidence. It's like Nixon at the time of Watergate or Tanaka in Japan after the financial scandal broke open in 1974. People don't last long in such situations.''
lead_paragraph: Predicting that President Chun Doo Hwan will be out of office by fall, the leader of the banned New Democratic Party says South Korea must then move toward ''the restoration of democratic institutions.''

abstract: Korean boxing officials, angered by the narrow victory of an American over Kim Dong Kil in a light-welterweight quarterfinal bout today, have protested the decision and have threatened to withdraw from the Olympic boxing competition.    The closely scored 4-1 decision by Jerry Page over Kim prompted the Korean Boxing Federation to lodge a protest with the International Amateur Boxing Federation. But Roland Schwartz of the United States, a member of the jury that oversees officiating and a member of the federation, said he believed the complaint would be in vain because a protest can be valid only on rules violations or mechanical errors made by a judge.   ''You can protest anything you want,'' Schwartz said, ''but you cannot protest a judgment call. It will be of no avail.''
lead_paragraph: Korean boxing officials, angered by the narrow victory of an American over Kim Dong Kil in a light-welterweight quarterfinal bout today, have protested the decision and have threatened to withdraw from the Olympic boxing competition.

abstract: For the first time in 30 years, South Koreans will vote on Tuesday for local government officials. But in sharp contrast to the constant political tumult here since military rule ended three years ago, this election is remarkable for what is missing: strikes, huge rallies and tear gas.    Both the governing Democratic Liberal Party, which President Roh Tae Woo created a year ago in a deft merger with two of his biggest political opponents, and the remaining major opposition group, Kim Dae Jung's Party for Peace and Democracy, have spent the last two months trying to explain away a giant bribery case that has embarrassed them all.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in 30 years, South Koreans will vote on Tuesday for local government officials. But in sharp contrast to the constant political tumult here since military rule ended three years ago, this election is remarkable for what is missing: strikes, huge rallies and tear gas.

abstract: LEAD: Airbus Industrie, the four-nation European consortium, said it had won two orders to build a total of seven planes for airlines in Belgium and South Korea. The Belgian state-owned airline Sabena said in Brussels that it had ordered five long-haul A340-300 aircraft from Airbus to be delivered in 1993 and 1994.
lead_paragraph: Airbus Industrie, the four-nation European consortium, said it had won two orders to build a total of seven planes for airlines in Belgium and South Korea. The Belgian state-owned airline Sabena said in Brussels that it had ordered five long-haul A340-300 aircraft from Airbus to be delivered in 1993 and 1994. And Korean Air has ordered two Airbus medium-haul A300-600 jets to be delivered at the end of 1988.

abstract: Japan, in a move indicating a thaw in relations with North Korea, has permitted an official delegation from Pyongyang to come to Tokyo for the first time to attend an international conference, official sources said today. abstract: LEAD: SOUTH KOREA'S centuries-old kilns, out of operation for more than 50 years, are going full blast again. abstract: While cold-war frost still chills U.S. diplomacy in Korea, Japan and North Korea have begun breaking the ice. Their first round of talks on normalizing relations ended inconclusively last week. But North Korea's new flexibility offers promise when talks resume next month.    Washington now needs to follow Tokyo's lead, establishing ties with the North and scaling down its military exercises and nuclear arsenal in Korea.    The Japan-North Korea talks are the latest warming sign in northeast Asian diplomacy. Last September, South Korea opened full diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union. A month later it signed a commercial treaty with China. Now North Korea is reaching out.
lead_paragraph: While cold-war frost still chills U.S. diplomacy in Korea, Japan and North Korea have begun breaking the ice. Their first round of talks on normalizing relations ended inconclusively last week. But North Korea's new flexibility offers promise when talks resume next month.

abstract: Ever since North Korea shocked its southern neighbor 36 years ago with a surprise attack, this nation has assiduously catalogued every conceiveable threat that could come from the North. Now they see a new weapon in their enemy's arsenal: water.   The threat, as the Seoul Government sees it, comes from a huge North Korean dam and hydroelectric power project that it says could disrupt South Korea's water supply and power generation, upset the ecological balance of the area and unleash disastrous floods in Seoul and its environs.   South Korean military and Government officials have repeatedly warned North Korea to halt work on the project. Lee Ki Baek, South Korea's Defense Minister, said Seoul would not sit back and allow North Korea to build a dam that could threaten South Korea's security. Now, the South Koreans have decided to build what they call a ''peace dam'' able to catch any flow of water released by the North Korean dam.
lead_paragraph: Ever since North Korea shocked its southern neighbor 36 years ago with a surprise attack, this nation has assiduously catalogued every conceiveable threat that could come from the North. Now they see a new weapon in their enemy's arsenal: water.

abstract: Nearly a half century after the end of its brutal subjugation of the Korean Peninsula, Japan is starting to think about possible reparations for North Korea but finding the decision-making difficult because of Koreans' extreme wariness of Japanese motives.   Japanese officials said last week that talks on a compensation package could begin after the first of next year, most probably in Pyongyang, with North Korea demanding at least as much as the $500 million that South Korea received when it normalized relations with Japan in 1965.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a half century after the end of its brutal subjugation of the Korean Peninsula, Japan is starting to think about possible reparations for North Korea but finding the decision-making difficult because of Koreans' extreme wariness of Japanese motives.

abstract: LEAD: Put aside for the moment the fiery oratory of the rivals in tomorrow's free election in South Korea, the first in 16 years. Ignore, too, competing threats: military intervention if left-of-center Kim Dae Jung wins, versus riots by radical students if the ruling party nominee, Roh Tae Woo, is declared the victor.
lead_paragraph: Put aside for the moment the fiery oratory of the rivals in tomorrow's free election in South Korea, the first in 16 years. Ignore, too, competing threats: military intervention if left-of-center Kim Dae Jung wins, versus riots by radical students if the ruling party nominee, Roh Tae Woo, is declared the victor. Instead, ponder the abiding enigma of South Korea - a dazzling economic success with an authoritarian political history that embarrasses the managers and workers who have wrought the Korean miracle.

abstract: North and South Korea make direct contact so infrequently that any meeting becomes an event. Usually, everyone concerned goes home as angry as ever, but last week something different happened. The two Koreas, in sessions at Panmunjom in the demilitarized zone, may actually have agreed on something.   After several false starts and reversals, they settled upon a way for the North's Red Cross organization to make good on an offer to deliver rice, medicine, cloth and cement to victims of recent floods in the South that killed 190 people and left 200,000 homeless. The supplies, worth an estimated $12 million, are to be sent by truck to Panmunjom and by ship to the South Korean ports of Inchon and Pukpyong. The South's Red Cross said that it would pick up the supplies, if given three days notice and if they are delivered by next Sunday.
lead_paragraph: North and South Korea make direct contact so infrequently that any meeting becomes an event. Usually, everyone concerned goes home as angry as ever, but last week something different happened. The two Koreas, in sessions at Panmunjom in the demilitarized zone, may actually have agreed on something.

abstract: Three months ago, North and South Korea began a series of high-level talks, cautious but hopeful about airing their differences politely and reducing tensions that have kept them in a state of hostility since the Korean War ended in 1953.     But as the third round of discussions adjourn today, the gulf of suspicion between Seoul and Pyongyang seemed as wide as ever, perhaps even wider, with each nation accusing the other of using the talks for subversion instead of understanding.
lead_paragraph: Three months ago, North and South Korea began a series of high-level talks, cautious but hopeful about airing their differences politely and reducing tensions that have kept them in a state of hostility since the Korean War ended in 1953.

abstract: LEAD: When asked to comment recently on a proposal in Congress to reduce the United States troop presence in South Korea, President Roh Tae Woo chided, ''If it ain't broke, don't fix it.'' Well, it is broke and it needs fixing.  More than 35 years after the Korean War, the U.S. still maintains 43,000 troops in South Korea at a cost of about $2.6 billion a year.
lead_paragraph: When asked to comment recently on a proposal in Congress to reduce the United States troop presence in South Korea, President Roh Tae Woo chided, ''If it ain't broke, don't fix it.'' Well, it is broke and it needs fixing. More than 35 years after the Korean War, the U.S. still maintains 43,000 troops in South Korea at a cost of about $2.6 billion a year. What began as a necessary but temporary helping hand to a friend in need has become the permanent and costly expectation of a prosperous ally.

abstract: She works in a small clothing factory - or she did until recently, when she was dismissed for refusing to work an extra 12-hour shift on Sunday.   The 30-year-old worker, who declined to give her name for fear of being blacklisted by employers, was used to long hours - she had worked 10-hour days, six days a week, sewing buttons on clothes for an average monthly salary of $185.   But after attending evening classes at a local church, where she learned about labor organizations, she grew to believe that her employers' demands were unfair - and says she is willing to go into factories and organize strikes. ''They fired me,'' she said, ''for being an agitator.''
lead_paragraph: She works in a small clothing factory - or she did until recently, when she was dismissed for refusing to work an extra 12-hour shift on Sunday.

abstract: Exports are a life-and-death matter for South Korea's economy, and this country was rattled in February when the United States Commerce Department ruled that electronics companies here were dumping color television sets on the American market.   Government ministers flew to Washington to plead the Korean case. Trade delegations went off on a $2.4 billion buying spree in the United States to show what faithful business partners the Koreans were. When Commerce Department officials then agreed to review their ruling, the Koreans came home confident that all would end well.
lead_paragraph: Exports are a life-and-death matter for South Korea's economy, and this country was rattled in February when the United States Commerce Department ruled that electronics companies here were dumping color television sets on the American market.

abstract: South Korea's state-owned electric power company has provisionally chosen plans submitted by three American companies to equip and service the two nuclear power plants it intends to build by the mid-1990's.   The contracts are estimated to be worth $500 million. The entire project will cost about $3 billion, with much of the money going to Korean companies involved in the construction.

abstract: LEAD: Nine crewmen from a South Korean freighter were rescued and nine others were lost after the ship sank on Sunday off western Taiwan, maritime officials said today. Nine crew members of the 2,000-ton freighter, the Western Hope, were rescued by sailors from two vessels after it went down Sunday night, according to officials of the Royal Steamship Company.

abstract: Students armed with gasoline bombs took over an American office in the South Korean city of Kwangju today and held it for nine hours.   The police moved in after negotiations between the demonstrators and American officials broke down.   A United States Embassy spokesman in Seoul, David Fitzgerald, said late tonight that there were apparently no injuries and only minor property damage to the office of the director of the United States Cultural Center.

abstract: LEAD: During President Roh Tae Woo's recent Washington visit, President Reagan mused, off the cuff, that we might reduce our 44,000 troops in South Korea or withdraw them if tensions in the region lessened. Although that lessening has barely begun, now is the time to start small cuts in our forces and to begin lowering our military profile.

abstract: Some Asian and European diplomats here expressed doubt today that North Korea was responsible for the bomb explosion in Burma over the weekend that killed 20 people, including four South Korean Cabinet ministers.    The diplomats said reports they had received from Rangoon, the Burmese capital, suggested that the bombing attack might have been planned by Burmese insurgents intent on embarrassing the Burmese Government during a visit by the South Koreans.   The sources said they had been told that one or possibly two undetonated bombs had been found in the mausoleum where the explosion occurred, wounding 48 people in addition to killing 20. This suggested, one diplomat said, that the aim had been to kill as many people as possible and not just the visiting South Koreans.
lead_paragraph: Some Asian and European diplomats here expressed doubt today that North Korea was responsible for the bomb explosion in Burma over the weekend that killed 20 people, including four South Korean Cabinet ministers.

abstract: Two helicopters collided today over western South Korea, burst into flames and then crashed, the police said. Three United States soldiers were killed and three others were reported injured in the accident, which occurred over the town of Sosan 65 miles southwest of Seoul. The bodies of the three Americans were burned beyond recognition, according to the police.

abstract: South Korea captured its second gold medal in Olympic judo today when Ha Hyoung-zoo defeated Douglas Vieira of Brazil in the half-heavyweight (209 pounds) division. Vieira won the silver medal.   Bronze medals went to Gunter Neureuther of West Germany and Bjarni Fridriksson of Iceland.

abstract: Amid glistening greens and pyramids of produce in the small store in Flushing, Queens, that he hoped would insure his family's prosperity, Sun Yong Back assesses a future that has suddenly dimmed. The odds seem as long as his workdays.   As New York City's economy turned anemic, he says, his sales have dropped by more than 30 percent. Taxes are rising. He missed last month's rent. Mr. Back is holding on, but his time, if not his resolve, seems limited.

abstract: North and South Korea today began their first full-fledged talks in 12 years aimed at reuniting millions of families separated by the Korean War more than three decades ago.   Representatives of both sides spoke of the need to ease the ''pain and suffering'' of separated families, but longstanding differences over how to conduct the discussions were evident.   The chief South Korean delegate, Lee Yong Dok, suggested that the negotiators first deal only with ''humanitarian issues,'' leaving aside more overtly political matters such as attempts to reunify the divided peninsula. Mr. Lee said that later, ''our humanitarian project may well be a national undertaking linked directly to the unification of our homeland.''   But the chief North Korean delegate, Li Chong Yul, repeated a decades-old position that Korean reunification must receive top priority. ''The most important thing is that on humanitarian grounds we must work toward peace and unification,'' Mr. Li said. ''We cannot separate peace and unification from other things.''
lead_paragraph: North and South Korea today began their first full-fledged talks in 12 years aimed at reuniting millions of families separated by the Korean War more than three decades ago.

abstract: In a factory the size of an airplane hangar, beyond lines of workers bending over huge machines, stands a solitary assembly line with no workers - operated by a room full of computers that program the manufacture of engine cylinder blocks. It is the Daewoo Corporation's first fully automated assembly line, part of its effort to keep manufacturing costs low.   Assembly lines are still the exception at Daewoo and for most Korean companies, whose ability to turn out lower-priced cars, lower-priced steel and lower-priced video cassette recorders is mounting an increasingly tough challenge to the United States and Japan. The key to Korea's success as a low-cost producer is not the automation or inventory controls that distinguish Japanese manufacturing, but lower wages and a highly disciplined and productive work force, according to analysts.
lead_paragraph: In a factory the size of an airplane hangar, beyond lines of workers bending over huge machines, stands a solitary assembly line with no workers - operated by a room full of computers that program the manufacture of engine cylinder blocks. abstract: In January 1978 one of South Korea's most prominent film actresses disappeared while on a trip to Hong Kong. Six months later her former husband, South Korea's most famous film director, disappeared while ostensibly searching for her.   There were conflicting rumors about what happened to the country's most illustrious movie couple. Some said they had been killed by the South Korean Central Intelligence Agency. Others said they had been abducted to North Korea.

abstract: When the Amoco Chemicals Corporation and Samsung of South Korea embarked on a joint venture some years ago to produce polyester fibers, they ran into an unexpected hitch. Their factory began producing fibers just as a supply surplus hit the market, inventories piled up and profits seemed a remote possibility. But it was when the venture finally started to make money that the real problems began.   The American partners wanted to distribute much of the profit as dividends to investors who had remained patient during hard times. But the Korean partners wanted to reinvest money in the company.

abstract: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea today invited Kim Il Sung, the North Korean leader, to visit Seoul and also said that he was willing to go to Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, for what would be the first meeting of Korean heads of state since the peninsula was divided after World War II.   North Korea and South Korea had been negotiating since early 1979 on a possible meeting of prime ministers, but the talks bogged down, as had previous negotiations between the two governments earlier in the decade. Today's statement appeared to be a first attempt to resume North-South contacts since Mr. Chun took over as President last August.   Although Mr. Chun called for ''peaceful reunification through a resumption of dialogue,'' it seemed unlikely that there would be any rapid progress toward a visit by President Kim to the South. There was no immediate reaction from North Korea, which has been highly critical of the way in which Mr. Chun, who was a little-known major general only a year ago, rose rapidly to power.
lead_paragraph: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea today invited Kim Il Sung, the North Korean leader, to visit Seoul and also said that he was willing to go to Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, for what would be the first meeting of Korean heads of state since the peninsula was divided after World War II.

abstract:
The ugly events involving South Korea - the downing of its airliner; the Rangoon bombing, which killed 20 people, including four South Korean Cabinet ministers - fit a pattern we have almost come to accept as par for the course for the divided peninsula.

In the past decade alone, there have been many outrages: a tree-cutting incident in the demilitarized zone in which two G.I.'s were brutally hacked to death (1976); the Korean Central Intelligence Agency plot to kidnap and assassinate the opposition leader Kim Dae Jung (1973); the assassination of President Park Chung Hee's wife (1974), then the murder of Mr. Park (1979); the rebellion and massacre at Kwangju (1980); now the apparent attempt to kill Seoul's current despot, President Chun Doo Hwan, in isolated Burma.

The prime suspect always seems to be the North Koreans - with understandable though not always sufficient reason. Theirs has been a record of truculence filled with bizarre murder plots against South Korean leaders, tunnels under the DMZ, spies sent overland, shootouts in the waters surrounding the peninsula.
