abstract: Fifteen years ago, this town 160 miles southeast of Seoul was a sleepy farm village noted only for its mountain cable car and for being the birthplace of Park Chung Hee, then the president.   The cable car still climbs the mountain, but this once-dormant town is now bustling, for it has become South Korea's Silicon Valley. On nearly 4,500 acres across the Nakdong River and hemmed by low hills, the Gumi Industrial Complex has spawned the production center for the South Korean electronics industry.   That industry is big business for South Korea. It represented the nation's second-largest export commodity in 1980 after textiles and made Korea the world's 10th-largest producer of electronics equipment, according to Kim Wan Hee, chairman of the Electronic Industries Association of Korea.
lead_paragraph: Fifteen years ago, this town 160 miles southeast of Seoul was a sleepy farm village noted only for its mountain cable car and for being the birthplace of Park Chung Hee, then the president.

abstract: President Kim Il Sung of North Korea today ended his first visit to the Soviet Union in 20 years amid indications that he might have succeeded in obtaining enhanced Soviet military assistance.    Before leaving for Poland and other East European countries, Mr. Kim held a third round of talks with the Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko, during which the state of the Korean forces appeared to have been a leading topic.   A report by Tass, the Soviet press agency, said that ''special emphasis was made on issues of strengthening security in the Far East and in the Pacific Ocean zone.''   Diplomatic reports before Mr. Kim's arrival said one of his priorities would be to win Soviet agreement to provide North Korea with new fighters to replace its aging Soviet-built MIG's, confronted by advanced planes of the United States and South Korean forces.
lead_paragraph: President Kim Il Sung of North Korea today ended his first visit to the Soviet Union in 20 years amid indications that he might have succeeded in obtaining enhanced Soviet military assistance.

abstract: South Korea's gross national product grew by a provisional 10.4 percent in the third quarter, compared with a 7.1 percent rise in the corresponding 1982 period, the Bank of Korea said today. abstract: LEAD: South of here on Route 1 toward Pusan, the crazy-quilt urban patterns of new office buildings and old kiosks begin to melt away into farm land and rice fields. Along the way, exit signs mark directions to nearby towns and villages, some visible from the highway. But for the most part, the road slices through only a verdant countryside, with mountains off in the distance at either side.

abstract: Whatever the South Korean Government's purpose in forceably isolating Kim Dae Jung, one of its leading opponents, on his return from exile 10 days ago, it undoubtedly did not have in mind the kind of election results it got last week. Mr. Kim was unable to vote, much less campaign, but the opposition made its best showing in years in the voting for a new National Assembly.    Allies of Mr. Kim, who formed the New Korea Democratic Party a month before the election, captured 67 of the Assembly's 276 seats and made plans to turn the legislative body into something more than a rubber stamp for President Chun Doo Hwan.
lead_paragraph: Whatever the South Korean Government's purpose in forceably isolating Kim Dae Jung, one of its leading opponents, on his return from exile 10 days ago, it undoubtedly did not have in mind the kind of election results it got last week. abstract: The United States Steel Corporation yesterday announced a far-reaching joint venture with a South Korean steelmaker that will eventually make South Korea the primary supplier of steel for U.S. Steel's finishing plant at Pittsburg, Calif.   The agreement marked U.S. Steel's first major partnership with a foreign steelmaker. A move two years ago to supply its Fairless Works in Pennsylvania with semifinished steel from British Steel was unsuccessful.   U.S. Steel and its Korean partner, the Pohang Iron and Steel Company, also agreed to invest $300 million on a 50-50 basis to modernize the California plant over the next four years.
lead_paragraph: The United States Steel Corporation yesterday announced a far-reaching joint venture with a South Korean steelmaker that will eventually make South Korea the primary supplier of steel for U.S. Steel's finishing plant at Pittsburg, Calif.

abstract: The burning of the American Cultural Center in Pusan by unknown arsonists on March 18 - an act seen by many Koreans as the most serious anti-American incident in South Korea in decades - is regarded by non-Communist dissidents, moderate churchmen and other Korean sources as only the latest evidence of growing anti-American sentiment among radical, non-Communist activists here.   In the incident at Pusan, a port city 260 miles south of here, youthful attackers spread gasoline in the hall of the American Cultural Center, causing a fire that destroyed the first floor of the three-story building, killing a student visitor and injuring several others. No Americans were hurt and work quickly resumed in temporary quarters on the second floor. But the police, who said they questioned some 16,000 people nationwide, especially in Seoul, and carried out house-to-house searches in Pusan, have not caught the culprits.
lead_paragraph: The burning of the American Cultural Center in Pusan by unknown arsonists on March 18 - an act seen by many Koreans as the most serious anti-American incident in South Korea in decades - is regarded by non-Communist dissidents, moderate churchmen and other Korean sources as only the latest evidence of growing anti-American sentiment among radical, non-Communist activists here.

abstract: LEAD: The Kahwa teahouse posted a sign today offering ''free service on this delightful day.'' After three weeks of political turmoil in which the air was never free of tear gas and the streets were never free of riot policemen, the people of Seoul allowed themselves a collective sigh of relief today. They rushed to newsstands, grabbing single-sheet newspaper extras and scanning them intently as they walked.

abstract: This was a weekend of rare contrition and humility for the normally self-assured Prime Minister of Japan, Yasuhiro Nakasone.   Mr. Nakasone came to Seoul on Saturday ostensibly to watch the opening of the Asian Games, a 16-day sports event that carries political overtones for South Koreans while serving as a warm-up for the 1988 Olympic Games, also to be held here.   Athletics placed second to old war wounds, however. Much of the time, the Japanese leader found himself being called to account for his country's imperial past, especially its harsh colonial rule of Korea from 1910 to 1945.
lead_paragraph: This was a weekend of rare contrition and humility for the normally self-assured Prime Minister of Japan, Yasuhiro Nakasone.

abstract:
LATE LAST MONTH, FOLLOWING one of the year's most violent clashes in Seoul between protesters and the police, more than 1,000 university students were arrested for protesting against their country's military dictatorship and what they see as American connivance. Such incidents have been common in South Korea, but there was a startling occurrence in May. Before a university crowd of 3,000 who had gathered to hear a speech by a prominent critic of the Government, a student shouted denunciations of domestic dictatorship and ''American imperialism,'' set himself on fire and jumped from the fourth-floor balcony of a campus building. He died four hours later. Suicide as a form of political protest would have been unimaginable a few years ago, but so far this year, there have been six such incidents, the latest only 10 days ago.

Students are not the only protesters. The urban middle class is becoming increasingly restive. Many leaders of the country's Christians, who constitute close to a quarter of the population, have spoken out against the Government of President Chun Doo Hwan. Even members of the Buddhist clergy, which has been quiescent for centuries as a social force, have joined in the protests.

abstract: Tens of thousands of people marched peacefully Saturday as the opposition party continued to draw enthusiastic support for constitutional change.   The rally was the fourth in the last few weeks. The crowd shouted its disapproval of the Government on the same day that President Chun Doo Hwan left for a visit to Western Europe. Both the opposition rally and a separate student demonstration remained peaceful, eschewing the violence of a small band of demonstrators last week in Kwangju.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of people marched peacefully Saturday as the opposition party continued to draw enthusiastic support for constitutional change.

abstract: LEAD: KOREAN shamanic dance was a focus of two events over the weekend in New York City, one a seminar at Asia Society and the other a performance by Hi-ah Park on Friday night at the Open Center. The word performance is used advisedly here, for Miss Park herself stressed that the evening was a version of a shamanic ritual that was modified for the time and place.
lead_paragraph: KOREAN shamanic dance was a focus of two events over the weekend in New York City, one a seminar at Asia Society and the other a performance by Hi-ah Park on Friday night at the Open Center. The word performance is used advisedly here, for Miss Park herself stressed that the evening was a version of a shamanic ritual that was modified for the time and place. Her audience, clustered around her in the center's small ''teahouse'' performance space, seemed to have come as much to participate as to learn about and observe shamanic dance.

abstract: Two crew members of a Chinese domestic airliner were shot in midair Thursday and their plane, with 105 people aboard, was hijacked to South Korea, Government officials said.   The plane landed at an American Army base northeast of Seoul and then, for seven hours, the hijackers held 92 passengers and five crew members hostage in an apparent demand for political asylum.   During the siege, the two wounded crew members - a navigator and a radio operator - were removed from the aircraft on stretchers.  According to officials, they were flown to an American military hospital, where they were said this morning to be in stable condition following surgery for leg wounds.
lead_paragraph: Two crew members of a Chinese domestic airliner were shot in midair Thursday and their plane, with 105 people aboard, was hijacked to South Korea, Government officials said.

abstract: Following is the text of Congress's joint resolution on the Soviet Union's downing of the South Korean airliner. The House approved the resolution today by a vote of 416 to 0, and the Senate was expected to vote on it Thursday.       WHEREAS the United States joins with the world community in expressing its outrage over the actions of the Soviet Government on Aug. 31, 1983, which caused the destruction of Korean Air Lines Flight 007 with the loss of 269 innocent lives;   WHEREAS on Aug. 31, 1983, Korean Air Lines Flight 007 inadvertently entered Soviet airspace;   WHEREAS Soviet authorities tracked Korean Air Lines Flight 007 for more than two hours but did not adhere to all the internationally recognized procedures necessary to warn the aircraft that it was off course and to protect its passengers;   WHEREAS a Soviet Air Force fighter fired air-to-air missiles at Korean Air Lines Flight 007 and destroyed the unarmed, clearly marked civilian airliner with 269 innocent men, women and children from 14 nations aboard, including 61 of our fellow citizens;   WHEREAS among the victims was a distinguished Member of Congress, the Honorable Larry P. McDonald;   WHEREAS the highest levels of the Soviet Government have lied in an attempt to justify this unconscionable act and have continued to deny access to the area where the airplane went down;   WHEREAS the Soviet Government has publicly proclaimed its intention to repeat its murderous act if another airliner wanders inadvertently into Soviet airspace; and   WHEREAS this cold-blooded barbarous attack on a commercial airliner straying off course is one of the most infamous and reprehensible acts in history: Now, therefore, be it   RESOLVED by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, that the United States hereby    1.
lead_paragraph: Following is the text of Congress's joint resolution on the Soviet Union's downing of the South Korean airliner. The House approved the resolution today by a vote of 416 to 0, and the Senate was expected to vote on it Thursday.

abstract: NEXT month a new imported car will go on sale in the United States.   It is the Hyundai Excel, a subcompact that resembles the popular small cars from Japan. But the Hyundai (pronounced HUN-day) is made in South Korea and is the first of several makes of car from that country that will be coming into the American market over the next few years. Max Jamiesson, a former Toyota and Ford executive, is executive vice president of Hyundai Motor America. He was interviewed at the company's headquarters in Garden Grove, Calif.
lead_paragraph: NEXT month a new imported car will go on sale in the United States.

abstract: Han Young Suk, a woman of quiet intensity onstage and a performer of wider range than one might first suppose, is very obviously a dancer's dancer.   As a foremost exponent of Korean classical dance - the South Korean Government has given her the title of Living National Human Cultural Treasure - she is part of a select group of Asian dancers who can convey the purity of traditional forms and thus allow us a glimpse into their original inspiration.   Miss Han, who will perform Thursday in New York at the Korean Consulate's cultural service, 460 Park Avenue, between 57th and 58th Streets, was invited to the United States by the American Dance Festival. She made her festival debut here Monday night with two younger dancers from South Korea at the Reynolds Industries Theater at Duke University, the festival's home.
lead_paragraph: Han Young Suk, a woman of quiet intensity onstage and a performer of wider range than one might first suppose, is very obviously a dancer's dancer.

abstract:
DESPITE Korea's proximity to China and Japan, the Koreans have held on to their own culture, traditions and cuisine. Although many dishes somewhat resembled Japanese, Chinese and Mongolian foods, the overall impression is of both sweeter and lustier flavors. 

 Not as refined as the Japanese nor, apparently, as varied as the Chinese, still several ingredients are shared, such as soy sauce, rice, ginger, red pepper, sesame oil, scallions and heavy doses of garlic. But Korea's own is kim chee, the peppery, garlicky fermented cabbage used both as a condiment and a flavoring.

abstract: In a compromise with the Reagan Administration, the four-member board of the Export-Import Bank decided unanimously today to guarantee commercial export loans for a South Korean steel complex while refusing to lend Government money at subsidized interest rates.    The bank, a Federal entity, also stipulated that its loan guarantee would be limited to 85 percent of the cost of the equipment that might be purchased from two Pennsylvania- based exporters bidding for contracts on the project - the Dravo Wellman Company of Pittsburgh and Air Products and Chemicals Inc. of Allentown.   The question of aid for companies seeking to sell equipment for the South Korean facility has generated intense debate.   The Commerce Department, in a rare intervention, asked that export assistance be denied entirely, on the ground that the United States should not aid construction of foreign steel plants when imports are hurting the domestic steel industry.
lead_paragraph: In a compromise with the Reagan Administration, the four-member board of the Export-Import Bank decided unanimously today to guarantee commercial export loans for a South Korean steel complex while refusing to lend Government money at subsidized interest rates.

abstract: The Reagan Administration today announced a four-year pact with South Korea to restrain growth in its textile imports to eight-tenths of 1 percent a year.   That level is well below the average 8.6 percent yearly growth in imports from that country from 1981 to 1985.   Today's action came two days before the House votes on a motion to override a Presidential veto of legislation to cut imports of textiles. It follows announcements of similarly restrictive textile import accords in recent weeks with Taiwan, Hong Kong and South Africa - all intended to placate domestic textile producers pressing for legislation that would cut current import levels by about one-third.
lead_paragraph: The Reagan Administration today announced a four-year pact with South Korea to restrain growth in its textile imports to eight-tenths of 1 percent a year.

abstract: Tens of thousands of riot policemen fired tear-gas canisters and pushed back crowds this afternoon to block a large rally that had become a major test of wills between the Government and the opposition.   The police cordoned off large sections of central Seoul, standing three and four deep at some intersections to prevent anti-Government protesters from reaching the designated rally site. There were no early reports of injuries. Anticipating the police strategy, opposition leaders planned smaller demonstrations in the downtown area.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of riot policemen fired tear-gas canisters and pushed back crowds this afternoon to block a large rally that had become a major test of wills between the Government and the opposition.

abstract: Following is the text of remarks tonight by Emperor Hirohito at a state banquet for President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea, as translated by the Foreign Ministry:    I wish to offer my hearty welcome to Your Excellency the President of the Republic of Korea, now paying a visit to this country as a state guest together with Mrs. Chun Doo Hwan, in spite of the pressure of affairs of state. Your visit, being the first official visit to Japan of the head of state of your country, marks an epoch in the history of relations between our two countries and is to be sincerely congratulated for the advancement of their friendship. It gives me utmost pleasure to be able to have the company of Your Excellency and your party at this dinner.

abstract: The soprano Mal-Sun Pak, who made her New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night, was at her best in some contemporary Korean material by Dong-Jin Kim, Sang-Gun Lee and Dae-Ung Ha, to which her direct manner and cultivated musicianship were admirably suited.   Miss Pak has difficulties with her diction in the Italian and German repertory and occasionally produces a disconcertingly hollow tone.

abstract: A jury yesterday acquitted the manager of a Korean grocery of the assault charge that ignited a long, racially tense black boycott in Brooklyn.   The jury found that the manager was not guilty of slapping a black customer in the grocery on Jan. 18, 1990. When the verdict was announced, the manager, Pong Ok Jang, sat down at the defense table, held his head in both hands and wept with relief.

abstract: THE glimpse of Korean culture offered by the Korean National Dance Theater -  a 60-member group based in Seoul and produced here by Kazuko Hillyer - was an enjoyable one presented by a company of attractive dancers and musicians. There  were musical numbers that gave a sense of how traditional instruments sounded and were used. The dance was pretty and lively, and maintained a pleasant balance between popular art and traditional culture. And the dance-drama that completed the program had a great many moments of poignant story-telling.         A high point of Wednesday's program at the Beacon Theater was the P'ansori or love song, a kind of folk recitative performed by Ahn Sook-sun, a singer, and Kang Hyung-joo, a drummer. Although the technical aspects of the performance stood out, it was the earthiness and simplicity of the music that struck one most.
lead_paragraph: THE glimpse of Korean culture offered by the Korean National Dance Theater - a 60-member group based in Seoul and produced here by Kazuko Hillyer - was an enjoyable one presented by a company of attractive dancers and musicians. There were musical numbers that gave a sense of how traditional instruments sounded and were used. The dance was pretty and lively, and maintained a pleasant balance between popular art and traditional culture. And the dance-drama that completed the program had a great many moments of poignant story-telling.

abstract: AS A MAN NAMED KIM Dae Jung sets out on a planned 7,000-mile journey home to South Korea next month, he will undoubtedly be thinking about Benigno Aquino.  Kim did not know Aquino well. Indeed, they met only once, on March 10, 1983, in Cambridge, Mass.    But the parallels between their lives are remarkable. As leading opposition politicians in the Philippines and South Korea, they were jailed, put under house arrest and sentenced to death by authoritarian East Asian governments that had American support. In May 1980, Aquino was released to come to the United States for medical treatment; Kim arrived two and a half years later for the same reason.   Aquino had recently completed his stay at Harvard University's Center for International Affairs, where Kim was soon to follow. Over breakfast at Aquino's home and lunch at the Harvard Faculty Club, they exchanged political ''war stories'' and advice. The encounter was intense.
lead_paragraph: AS A MAN NAMED KIM Dae Jung sets out on a planned 7,000-mile journey home to South Korea next month, he will undoubtedly be thinking about Benigno Aquino. Kim did not know Aquino well. Indeed, they met only once, on March 10, 1983, in Cambridge, Mass.

lead_paragraph: A father hoists his little girl on his shoulder, after carefully affixing a surgical mask to her face. People line the sidewalks as if waiting for a parade. From far away sound the first faint choruses of protest songs. The riot policemen straighten up from their afternoon rest and put on their Darth Vader helmets. Soon, the protest will begin. For all the spontaneous turmoil on the streets of this and other cities in the last 12 days, the anti-Government protests have assumed something of a ritual air. abstract: As the train from China crosses the Yalu River, there is no mistaking the legacy of war. A hundred yards downstream stands a second bridge, with all six supports on the North Korean side of the river missing, blown away by American bombing.   Nearly 32 years after the armistice that ended the Korean War, the first thing a traveler sees on arrival in this tightly sealed nation is a reminder of the destruction wrought by American forces under Gen. Douglas A. MacArthur. In October 1950 United States troops approached within a few miles of the Yalu, prompting the Chinese to enter the war.   The evidence is even starker where the express from Peking halts, beside a red-and-white barrier manned by a soldier in the olive green uniform of North Korea's army. Between the shoreline and the first of the concrete bridge pontoons is a tangled mass of rusted steel. On shore, workmen are busy clearing it away for scrap.
lead_paragraph: As the train from China crosses the Yalu River, there is no mistaking the legacy of war. A hundred yards downstream stands a second bridge, with all six supports on the North Korean side of the river missing, blown away by American bombing.

abstract: It was flattering, the other day, to have one of my sons ask me to play tennis with him. It was sobering to have another say: ''You were in Korea during the war there, weren't you? What was that all about, anyway?''   Well, now, chaps, when June rolls around each year, it is not Father's Day that some of us old codgers reminisce about, nor even Flag Day. We remember the month as the one in which - June 25, 1950 was the date -the trouble began. Listen carefully, because you may find some of this hard to believe. So, apparently, did Gen. Omar Bradley, who was chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff at the time; he said the Korean business was ''the wrong war, at the wrong place, at the wrong time, and with the wrong enemy.'' Actually, the Korean War wasn't ever technically a war. Congress never declared it one. It was often called, for want of any better term, a ''police action.'' That gave little comfort then or since to the families of the 52,246 Americans who died in the course of whatever it was. For another strange thing, the conflict isn't technically over yet. Up at Panmunjom, near the 38th Parallel, which then and now divides North and South Korea, the details of a permanent settlement are still intermittently being thrashed out. You be sure to let your grandchildren know when the hatchet is finally buried.
lead_paragraph: It was flattering, the other day, to have one of my sons ask me to play tennis with him. It was sobering to have another say: ''You were in Korea during the war there, weren't you? What was that all about, anyway?''

abstract: A three-week campaign for the National Assembly ended today amid predictions that the ruling party might lose ground in the balloting on Tuesday.    The campaign was marked by unusually strong denunciations of the Government by an emboldened opposition.    Many political commentators, some of them allies of the Government, said they saw a possibility that the ruling Democratic Justice Party would lose Assembly seats in the elections as well as slip in its share of the popular vote since the last balloting, held in 1981.   Should that happen, the analysts say, the results would inevitably be interpreted as a blow to President Chun Doo Hwan.

abstract: Businesses owned by Koreans along 125th Street in Harlem are at the center of a controversy stemming from charges that they exploit blacks. But Harlem residents are divided on the issue, with some urging that blacks boycott the Koreans' stores and others calling for cooperation between the two groups.   The Koreans insist they are providing jobs for the community's residents and are channeling some of their profits back into the area.   Members of the Universal Negro Improvement Association, representing the remnants of a group led by Marcus Garvey in the early 1900's, are spearheading what they call a ''buy black'' campaign.
lead_paragraph: Businesses owned by Koreans along 125th Street in Harlem are at the center of a controversy stemming from charges that they exploit blacks. abstract: President Chun Doo Hwan said today that the Soviet Union committed ''a barbarous act'' in shooting down a South Korean airliner. He demanded ''the truth'' and an apology from Moscow.   The attack ''cannot be tolerated under any pretext and deserves the censure of the entire world,'' President Chun said in his first statement on the incident. The statement was issued through his chief press secretary, Hwang Sun Pil.

abstract: Several serious incidents, dominated by last September's shooting down of a passenger plane in which 269 people died, have led to a series of shake-ups at Korean Air Lines.    Senior executives, including the president, have been shifted to new jobs in recent weeks, and 14 pilots have been forced to resign. All 582 cockpit crew members have been run through tightened screening procedures, and some were demoted or transferred, according to K.A.L. officials and industry analysts here.   The airline said that one pilot became so angry after being told to resign that he punched a senior officer.
lead_paragraph: Several serious incidents, dominated by last September's shooting down of a passenger plane in which 269 people died, have led to a series of shake-ups at Korean Air Lines.

abstract: The Hyundai Motor Company of Korea will begin selling cars in the United States later this year when it introduces a new, front-wheel-drive subcompact as a 1986 model. The company said its initial plans are to build an additional 100,000 cars a year for sale in the United States.          The formal announcement of the move, the first of its kind by a Korean automobile company, is expected on Monday. Company officials made it clear over  the weekend that their strategy is to concentrate on the market for small, relatively inexpensive cars that the Japanese auto makers have largely abandoned in favor of more elaborate and expensive models.

abstract: Maj. Gen. William F. Dean, a Korean War hero who spent three years in Communist prisoner-of-war camps in North Korea, died yesterday in Alta Bates Hospital here, the Army said today. He was 82 years old.   General Dean, who retired in 1955, had lived since then in Berkeley.  General Dean, who had earlier been military governor of South Korea and had a reputation for being a front-line combat officer, took command of the 24th Infantry Division in Tokyo when North Korean troops crossed the 38th parallel and invaded South Korea on June 25, 1950.
lead_paragraph: Maj. Gen. William F. Dean, a Korean War hero who spent three years in Communist prisoner-of-war camps in North Korea, died yesterday in Alta Bates Hospital here, the Army said today. He was 82 years old.

abstract:
SEOUL DURING the past decade, South Korea was a symbol of economic bootstrapping for the developing world, an example of how hard work, good workers, smart planners and stable government could pay off.

By 1980, however, the dream had ended. A series of external economic factors, homegrown problems and politcal upheavals left many foreigners - and Koreans as well - wondering if the country would be able to reassemble the pieces and return to the pace of the miracle years.

abstract: A young man ''fired'' a toy pistol at the car of Pope John Paul II this morning near Seoul Cathedral and was immediately overpowered by the police.    The Pope saw the incident but appeared to be unperturbed by it.   The Rev. Roberto Tucci, head of the Vatican radio and the official who arranges papal travel, said the man had stepped out from the crowd a few paces to the right of the car, brandishing a toy gun.   Father Tucci said he heard a pop or two and then saw the man throw the toy gun to the ground, breaking it. He made a threatening gesture at the shocked crowd and was then seized by the police and thrown into a van.
lead_paragraph: A young man ''fired'' a toy pistol at the car of Pope John Paul II this morning near Seoul Cathedral and was immediately overpowered by the police.

abstract: --------------------------------------------------------------------  Peter Hyun is a Korean-born editor and writer whose latest book is ''Introducing Korea.'' By PETER HYUN   The exhibition of ''5,000 Years of Korean Art'' - which opens at the Metropolitan Museum of Art next Saturday for a three-month run (en route to Kansas City and Washington, D.C., after its successful tours of San Francisco, Seattle, Chicago, Cleveland and Boston) - may not top the recent ''King Tut'' or ''Pompeii'' shows in its mass appeal, but is certainly strong competition for them in both quality and scope.   This is not surprising. After all, Korea has since the birth of the nation 5,000 years ago produced a unique civilization of its own, including the world's first metal printing machine (some 200 years before the Gutenberg invention in Germany) and the hangul alphabet, regarded by Edwin O. Reischauer, the diplomat and Harvard Orientalist, as ''perhaps the most scientific system of writing in general use in any language.''   Unquestionably the most comprehensive Korean art collection to tour abroad, this exhibition is as extensive as the title indicates, ranging from a neolithic earthenware jar (circa 300 B.C.) to a pair of 20th-century landscape paintings. Between these chronological extremes is a breathtaking array of 345 objects: glittering gold crowns and jewels, gilt-bronze Buddhist images, world-renowned Koryo celadon, highly stylized genre paintings, exquisitely designed ceramic tiles.
lead_paragraph: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Peter Hyun is a Korean-born editor and writer whose latest book is ''Introducing Korea.'' By PETER HYUN

abstract: One of the most important political trials in South Korea since Chun Doo Hwan took power in 1980 opened in Pusan this week with 16 people accused of involvement in burning the United States cultural center there.   The trial began Monday with prosecutors reading a 113-page indictment that depicts two theology students, Moon Pu Shik and his wife, Kim Un Suk, the leaders of the attack, as Communist sympathizers bent on the violent overthrow of President Chun.   The other chief defendants are Kim Hyon Jang, 32 years old, a layworker at a Roman Catholic education center in the Wonju diocese, and the Rev. Choi Ki Shik, 39, head of the center. One Person Died in Fire   The charges include arson, which carries a maximum penalty of death -one Korean died in the fire that caused about $200,000 in damages. Other charges are offenses under the National Security Law, which covers espionage and Communist activities.
lead_paragraph: One of the most important political trials in South Korea since Chun Doo Hwan took power in 1980 opened in Pusan this week with 16 people accused of involvement in burning the United States cultural center there.

abstract: BYUNG KI HWANG, one of the foremost interpreters of the kayagum, a 12-stringed Korean zither with strings made of twisted silk fiber, is the first composer to have written ''modern'' music on an instrument that dates back some 1,400 years. And on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall, Mr. Hwang, accompanied by Sang Won Park on the changgu (an hourglass drum), performed a program that contrasted his own original descriptive pieces with formal traditional kayagum music.

abstract: NO respectable international loan exhibition would nowadays be regarded as complete without its requisite share of glitter and gold. The big new show in town - ''5,000 Years of Korean Art,'' opening tomorrow at the Metropolitan Museum of Art - meets this obligation very handily. In the very first section of the exhibition, which has been organized by the National Museum of Korea, visitors are treated to a gorgeous display of fifth- and sixth-century gold and jade crowns, gold girdles (elaborate gold belts from which are appended a variety of gold objects), gold earrings, gold bracelets, gold cups, a gold cap and some silver cups and bowls.   Further on, in the section of the exhibition focusing on the rise of the Buddhist religion in Korea in the sixth century, there are gilt bronze figures of Buddha and other luminaries of the faith.  Aided by the magic of modern display techniques, all these objects bring us the dazzle and shimmer we have come to associate with loan exhibitions based on foreign national treasures. It is something of a mercy, therefore, that they are also, for the most part, objects of high artistic interest. It was inevitable, I suppose, that they would be given this jewelry-window installation, but even this does not fatally impair their artistic qualities.

abstract: At least 62 people were killed by a drunken policeman who went on an eight-hour shooting spree through several villages in South Korea before blowing himself up with a grenade, the police said today.   The policeman was said to have got drunk after quarreling with a female friend and, armed with stolen carbines and hand grenades, killed her and then began the random shootings, which ended early today with his death, the police said.

abstract: Thirty riot policemen were reported injured today in clashes after they fired tear gas to disperse crowds estimated at 10,000 people at an anti-Government rally in this port city.   The running clashes, in which demonstrators responded by throwing firebombs and rocks, resulted in the cancellation of the rally, injuries on both sides and the arrest of about 100 demonstrators.   Skirmishes continued well after nightfall, with the police firing tear gas as they pursued small bands of protesters.   Yoo Kil Jong, the provincial police director, said 30 policemen were injured and several hospitalized.

abstract: One of the most striking things about daily life in North Korea is the tedious routine that Kim Il Sung appears to have imposed on the almost 20 million inhabitants of this ''worker's state.''   Behind the stream of propaganda about the mutual love between Mr. Kim and the people is a system of authority and discipline that has thrust itself into every corner of life. Basing itself on the claim of Mr. Kim's ''universal genius,'' the Government has set out to organize as many hours in the citizen's day as possible.   When officials are asked why so few people are in Pyongyang's streets, they say that it is because nearly everyone, from the smallest children to the elderly, is ''busy.'' Diplomats who watch the daily comings and goings of people in their neighborhoods say many set out at dawn, finish past dusk and spend much of their nonworking time ''studying'' Mr. Kim's teachings or taking part in compulsory labors like snow clearing, which keeps thousands working until midnight.
lead_paragraph: One of the most striking things about daily life in North Korea is the tedious routine that Kim Il Sung appears to have imposed on the almost 20 million inhabitants of this ''worker's state.''

abstract: LEAD: Television docudramas are in the ascendancy at the moment, and as usual, the results are not only uneven but also worrying. lead_paragraph: Television docudramas are in the ascendancy at the moment, and as usual, the results are not only uneven but also worrying. Tonight's entry, on NBC at 9, is ''Shootdown,'' the fact-based story of one mother's crusade to discover the truth behind the Soviet destruction of Korean Air Lines Flight 007 on Sept. 1, 1983. The mother, here named Nan Moore, is played by Angela Lansbury, who convincingly demonstrates that several seasons of playing the charmingly smug Jessica Fletcher on ''Murder, She Wrote'' haven't dulled her versatility.

abstract: President Roh Tae Woo's governing party won a resounding victory on Tuesday, claiming more than half the posts in South Korea's first local elections in three decades.   The election was the first in a series intended to return some measure of local autonomy to the nation's cities and towns after a long period of military rule in which virtually every decision had been made by officials in Seoul.

abstract: When South Korea decided that the country's only chance at economic pre-eminence lay in supercharged industrialization, it started here, in a scrubby valley formed by the Naktong River.    As a result, the region, the home district of President Roh Tae Woo, could now be mistaken for anywhere in the Silicon Valley of California. But a recent chemical spill that some critics link to South Korea's "industrialize at all cost" policies is causing the area and the nation much anguish.
lead_paragraph: When South Korea decided that the country's only chance at economic pre-eminence lay in supercharged industrialization, it started here, in a scrubby valley formed by the Naktong River.

abstract: It's a long time between such film farces as ''They Call Me Bruce,'' which opened yesterday at the Rivoli II and at neighborhood houses, and one leaves it with mixed emotions. It is a hysterically insane - and inane -comedy send-up of kung fu epics, ethnic stereotypes, movie cliches and stand-up comic routines. But, surprise of surprises, despite your own better judgment, not to mention discerning taste and sophistication, you will find yourself giggling at this mixed bag of familiar silliness.    Perhaps it is because of Johnny Yune, the Korean comic who is starring here in his first film feature and who carries it off with the appealing innocence of the stand-up comic in the guise of a pureminded nebbish.
lead_paragraph: It's a long time between such film farces as ''They Call Me Bruce,'' which opened yesterday at the Rivoli II and at neighborhood houses, and one leaves it with mixed emotions. abstract: In the first diplomatic fallout from the gun battle last week at Panmunjom, North Korea today called off economic talks with South Korea that were scheduled for next week. abstract: North and South Korea have agreed to resume trade talks in Panmunjom and hold Red Cross talks in Seoul next month, a South Korean Government spokesman said today.   The spokesman said that in a telephone message Friday, North Korea agreed to Seoul's proposals for trade talks Jan. 17 and Red Cross talks Jan. 22 to 25.   The economic talks were to have taken place Dec. 5, but were postponed by the North over a firefight at Panmunjom last month in which three border guards from North Korea and one from the South were killed.
lead_paragraph: North and South Korea have agreed to resume trade talks in Panmunjom and hold Red Cross talks in Seoul next month, a South Korean Government spokesman said today.

abstract: SEOUL, South Korea -    By the end of the Korean War 32 years ago, South Korea's forests had been reduced to wasteland. Fierce combat, coupled with occupation by wood-hungry Japan and a desperate need for fuel in the Korean countryside, had cleared away all but 10 percent of the forests that had existed before World War II.   But today, the South Korean countryside is once again thick with trees - pine, larch, cedar and fruit trees of various types. Forests encompass 16.2 million acres, two-thirds of the country's total land area. According to the Forestry Administration Bureau, there is three times as much wood available as during the Korean War.

abstract: ''We would like to use this opportunity to express our deep appreciation to Ambassador Richard Walker for his dedicated effort to bring about stability and democracy to the troubled land of our heritage, Korea,'' said the statement issued at Senate confirmation hearings on the appointment of James R. Lilley as his successor as envoy to South Korea.   ''We are confident that Mr. Lilley will be successful not only in his confirmation hearing but also in representing the U.S. and Americans to Korea and Koreans.''   The statesman-like statement came not from the South Korean Embassy on Embassy Row on Massachusetts Avenue but from a cluttered three-room office on the second story of a building across the Potomac River in Arlington, Va. It was prepared by the Korean Institute for Human Rights, whose chairman and president, Kim Dae Jung, is the leader of the Opposition New Korea Democratic Party.

abstract: North Korea today rejected South Korea's call for direct talks on easing tension on the Korean peninsula, the North Korean Central News Agency reported.   The agency, monitored in Tokyo, quoted the North Korean Workers' Party newspaper Rodong Sinmun as saying it was impossible to solve the Korean problem through talks limited to Seoul and Pyongyang.   In the proposal Tuesday, Seoul said the talks could later be expanded to include the United States, China, the Soviet Union and Japan.

abstract: WITH so many restaurateurs nowadays copying one another's dishes that ''sell,'' Trastevere gives much cause for celebration. Opened seven months ago on 83d Street just east of Second Avenue by Maurizio and Paul Lattanzi, brothers from Rome who have worked in local Italian restaurants, and their mother, Erminia, who oversees the kitchen, this tiny, rustic and friendly trattoria has quickly developed a style of its own. The Lattanzis have managed to avoid culinary cliches by using authoritative seasonings and original presentations and it makes one think that nouvelle-cuisine Italianstyle is not far off.   Not for the faint-palated are the lusty accents of garlic and herbs in dishes such as the linguine with a briny, parsley flecked white clam sauce or in any of the wonderful seafood preparations adrift in a peppery, garlic-laden tomato broth. This fragrant tomato brodetto does as much for the appetizer of shiny black mussels as it does for such main courses as the mixed fish and seafood (zuppa de pesce) or the calamari Trastevere, thoughtfully underlined with thick toasted bread slices to absorb the heady sauce. Of these seafood dishes, only the zuppa de pesce, served in an undersized bowl, is somewhat difficult to maneuver.
lead_paragraph: WITH so many restaurateurs nowadays copying one another's dishes that ''sell,'' Trastevere gives much cause for celebration. Opened seven months ago on 83d Street just east of Second Avenue by Maurizio and Paul Lattanzi, brothers from Rome who have worked in local Italian restaurants, and their mother, Erminia, who oversees the kitchen, this tiny, rustic and friendly trattoria has quickly developed a style of its own. The Lattanzis have managed to avoid culinary cliches by using authoritative seasonings and original presentations and it makes one think that nouvelle-cuisine Italianstyle is not far off.

abstract: South Korean dissident leaders, responding to criticism over their agreement to negotiate constitutional changes with the ruling party, pledged today to work for the release of political detainees.   The dissident leaders, Kim Dae Jung and Kim Young Sam, who control the main opposition New Korea Democratic Party, said during a meeting with about 60 relatives of prisoners that they would seek a Government promise that all political prisoners would be released before they started discussions with the Government.   The party, which agreed Saturday to form a parliamentary committee with President Chun Doo Hwan's party to work on a new Constitution, had earlier said some 1,500 dissidents remained in prison.
lead_paragraph: South Korean dissident leaders, responding to criticism over their agreement to negotiate constitutional changes with the ruling party, pledged today to work for the release of political detainees.

abstract: Five leading South Korean dissidents ended a 19-day hunger strike today but pledged to continue their fight for the restoration of democracy.   The dissidents, including the Rev. Moon Ik Hwan, a civil rights campaigner, had joined a hunger strike by the former opposition leader, Kim Young Sam, to press for the release of jailed dissidents, relaxation of curbs on political activity, freedom of the press and direct presidential elections.   The police said on Friday that they had charged Mr. Kim's chief secretary under a law barring certain people from politics until 1988.

abstract: The United States is restricting the re-entry visas it issues to North Korea's United Nations diplomats in retaliation for the harboring by North Korea's United Nations Mission of a North Korean official wanted on a charge of sexual abuse, diplomats from both countries said today.   The United States has imposed the restriction because a North Korean third secretary, O Nam Chol, has refused to leave his country's mission at 40 East 80th Street since last September, when an arrest warrant was issued charging him with sexually abusing a woman in a park in Eastchester, N.Y. He can be arrested only if he leaves the mission.
lead_paragraph: The United States is restricting the re-entry visas it issues to North Korea's United Nations diplomats in retaliation for the harboring by North Korea's United Nations Mission of a North Korean official wanted on a charge of sexual abuse, diplomats from both countries said today.

abstract: South Korea's martial law command announced today that it would ease its seven-month-old ban on political activities, beginning Monday, for presidential elections that are expected by spring.   The Government banned political parties and meetings on May 17 when it arrested prominent politicians after large anti-Government demonstrations across the country. South Korea has been under martial law since the assassination of President Park Chung Hee in October 1979.

abstract: Prosecutors today dropped charges and freed one-third of the 1,275 students arrested for taking part in four days of violent anti-Government and anti-American protests.   A spokesman said 413 students, half of them women, were released to their parents from six prisons in Seoul and nearby towns today because they ''took part in the demonstrations only passively and repented for their action.''   They were among students from 27 schools who demonstrated against the Government of President Chun Doo Hwan and the United States on Oct. 28 to 31, holed up in five campus buildings at Kunkook University in Seoul.

abstract: About 200 plainclothes policemen stormed a civil rights organization's headquarters in Seoul today and detained three leading South Korean dissidents, witnesses said. Moon Ik Hwan, had begun a hunger strike earlier today to support Kim Young Sam, a former opposition leader who has been fasting for two weeks to press for a return to full democracy in South Korea.

abstract: The police sought arrest warrants today for six people accused of negligence in a hotel fire in South Korea's second largest city that killed at least 38 people and injured 74. abstract: President Chun Doo Hwan today lifted a ban on political activity by 250 prominent South Koreans, but he kept the eight-year-old ban in force for 305 others, including two opposition leaders, Kim Dae Jung and Kim Young Sam. abstract: Hundreds of anti-Government protesters clashed with riot policemen at a university and in the streets of Seoul today, and about 20 people were arrested, witnesses said.   The protesters shouted slogans demanding the resignation of President Chun Doo Hwan and hurled stones at the police, who responded by firing tear gas.   At Hanyang University in Seoul, the police battled students demanding the release of 191 protesters arrested Monday after occupying and damaging a training center operated by the ruling Democratic Justice Party.

abstract: The Supreme Commander of North Korea's Army today ordered all military units to take up "combat mobilization" positions, the official North Korean press agency said.   Takeshi Takesada of Japan's Institute of Defense Studies said North Korea regularly took such a posture to counter the annual joint military exercises of South Korea and the United States, called Team Spirit. The mobilization "has been used as propaganda to say how the military exercises pose a threat to North Korea," Mr. Takesada said.    The North Korean press agency, monitored in Tokyo, quoted a communique of the North Korean Army's supreme command as saying, "This is a legitimate self-defensive step to cope with the new war provocation moves of the United States and the South Korean puppets."
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Commander of North Korea's Army today ordered all military units to take up "combat mobilization" positions, the official North Korean press agency said.

abstract: North Korea and South Korea agreed today to allow 100 members of families separated by the Korean War to cross the border next month to locate relatives on the other side.   Last May, North Korean and South Korean Red Cross representatives agreed in principle to permit ''free travel'' by people searching for relatives lost during the 40-year partition of the peninsula.   At the time, both sides also agreed in principle to discuss ways to reunite separated Korean families as part of a ''comprehensive'' package, as the North Koreans had recommended.
lead_paragraph: North Korea and South Korea agreed today to allow 100 members of families separated by the Korean War to cross the border next month to locate relatives on the other side.

abstract: LEAD: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt announced yesterday that it had signed an exclusive affiliation agreement with Korea First Advertising, the largest ad agency in South Korea, with the equivalent of $200 million in billings last year. Under the agreement, K.F.A., a subsidiary of the Samsung Group of Companies, will use Bozell's international network for advertising outside South Korea.
lead_paragraph: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt announced yesterday that it had signed an exclusive affiliation agreement with Korea First Advertising, the largest ad agency in South Korea, with the equivalent of $200 million in billings last year. Under the agreement, K.F.A., a subsidiary of the Samsung Group of Companies, will use Bozell's international network for advertising outside South Korea. Bozell will also begin exploring acquiring an equity stake in the Korean agency. One of the first results of the agreement was also announced yesterday: Bozell will become the worldwide agency for Samsung's corporate account.

abstract: In Pagoda Park today, old men leaned on their canes and remembered the day 40 years ago when Japan surrendered and Korea was freed.   The small green park, dedicated to those who resisted Japan's 35-year occupation, drew families too young to remember but anxious to learn. Students came too, dreaming that they would be the generation to reunite the country split in two as soon as it was set free.   Forty years ago, Japan's surrender ended an occupation under which Koreans were forbidden to speak their own language and keep their own names. While Japanese wept before the Imperial Palace in Tokyo, exuberant crowds in Seoul waved the forbidden Korean flag, shouting and laughing and crying.
lead_paragraph: In Pagoda Park today, old men leaned on their canes and remembered the day 40 years ago when Japan surrendered and Korea was freed.

abstract: LEAD: ONCE again, South Korea's students have taken to the streets. But this time, rather than pressing for internal democratic change as they did last year, the students are forging a potent link between anti-Americanism and the desire to reunite South Korea with North Korea. Throughout the week, demonstrators, who called for the removal of American troops from South Korea, fought with riot policemen.
lead_paragraph: ONCE again, South Korea's students have taken to the streets. But this time, rather than pressing for internal democratic change as they did last year, the students are forging a potent link between anti-Americanism and the desire to reunite South Korea with North Korea. Throughout the week, demonstrators, who called for the removal of American troops from South Korea, fought with riot policemen. On Friday, the police blocked a planned meeting with North Korean students at the border village of Panmunjom.

abstract: There are no countries in the world that are held in lower esteem by the Reagan Administration than North Korea, State Department officials said today.   According to the officials, North Korea has a brutal, repressive government that continually schemes through a mixture of threats, terrorist actions and occasional conciliatory gestures to put an end to the pro-Western South Korean Government.   In Washington's view, only the combined South Korean-United States military force deters North Korea from launching a second Korean War. Also restraining the North Koreans, they said, is the clear unwillingness of China and the Soviet Union to run the risk of a world war started by North Korea.
lead_paragraph: There are no countries in the world that are held in lower esteem by the Reagan Administration than North Korea, State Department officials said today.

abstract: Recent Soviet statements about their shooting down of a South Korean airliner in 1983 have raised hopes that Moscow might provide missing official data on where the jumbo jet crashed and whether the bodies of any of the 269 victims were recovered. abstract: A Chinese military vessel whose crew apparently mutinied entered South Korean waters today and was taken into port, according to the American Embassy in Seoul.     No hostilities were reported between the Chinese ship and South Korean vessels. Six of the 18 Chinese crew members were killed in the mutiny and three were wounded, according to Harry Dunlop, political counselor of the American Embassy.

abstract: The South Korean Government has notified Michael K. Deaver's lobbying company that it will not renew a $475,000 contract that expired today, according to a South Korean official.   ''We decided not to extend the contract with Michael Deaver,'' the official said. ''The initial contract ended today. We will not have a new contract. They were informed.'' Government officials in Seoul were described as hopeful that termination of the contract would lessen the significance of a scheduled debate in the National Assembly over Mr. Deaver's role on behalf of Korea. The debate is expected to begin shortly after the Assembly reconvenes on Oct. 6.

abstract: LEAD: FOR four decades, North Korea has confined its trade relations and barter arrangements mostly to Communist nations. Now it seems to be trying to open up parts of its economy to the rest of the world. But the effort does not appear likely to produce a transformation as dramatic as its neighbor China has experienced; here, new visions of economic openness remain tightly restricted by older dreams of self-sufficiency and ideological purity.

abstract: The cold war may be over in Europe, but the political frost is still on Korea. How that nation came to be divided, why it remains so and its prospects for reunification after almost a half century are among the matters addressed in "Korea: The Unknown War." Most of its six hours, however, are given to an eventful account of the war itself.    The series, which begins tonight from 9 to 11 on Channels 13 and 49 and continues into tomorrow and Wednesday, has already been criticized for a revisionist tone that is unduly kind to North Korea and gives insufficient credit to American forces in the field. The writers have complained in turn that the original script has been changed under pressure from such critics. I must leave that quarrel to the specialists. To this congenitally suspicious reviewer, however, the documentary, produced by Thames Television of Britain in association with WGBH, Boston's public station, is filled with sharp and memory-jogging details and does not seem to be pushing any extreme line at the expense of the record.
lead_paragraph: The cold war may be over in Europe, but the political frost is still on Korea. How that nation came to be divided, why it remains so and its prospects for reunification after almost a half century are among the matters addressed in "Korea: The Unknown War." Most of its six hours, however, are given to an eventful account of the war itself.

abstract: Despite a new exchange of letters and a spate of messages in which each side says it wants to be reunified with the other, North Korea and South Korea seem unlikely to get together even to talk about getting together.    If anything, diplomatic activity in the last two months points up how deeply divided the two Koreas are as they, in effect, sermonize to each other across 31 years of distrust and recrimination.   In a statement issued last weekend, South Korea's Prime Minister, Chin Iee Chong, repeated a demand that if North Korea is serious about unification talks it must first apologize for the bombing in Rangoon, Burma, last October that killed 17 South Koreans, including top-echelon Government officials. The Burmese blame North Korea for the incident.
lead_paragraph: Despite a new exchange of letters and a spate of messages in which each side says it wants to be reunified with the other, North Korea and South Korea seem unlikely to get together even to talk about getting together.

abstract: The South Koreans killed in a bombing last Sunday in Rangoon, Burma, were buried today after an outdoor funeral service that turned into a huge rally denouncing North Korea for what one speaker called its ''evil schemes.''    North Korea is generally assumed here to be responsible for the bombing, although the Government has not officially offered any evidence of this.   Sixteen South Koreans were killed instantly in the explosion, which tore through a mausoleum in Rangoon dedicated to Burmese martyrs. It was announced this morning that a 17th person, Deputy Finance Minister Lee Ki Uk, had died at an American Air Force base in the Philippines where he was being treated for serious injuries.
lead_paragraph: The South Koreans killed in a bombing last Sunday in Rangoon, Burma, were buried today after an outdoor funeral service that turned into a huge rally denouncing North Korea for what one speaker called its ''evil schemes.''

abstract: President Reagan and President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea expressed concern today over the continued forward deployment of North Korean troops closer to the demilitarized zone separating the two Koreas.   But after a White House meeting, the two leaders also said that they were encouraged by steps toward reconciliation now being made between North and South Korea.   A senior Administration official, who took part in the meeting, said that although North Korea's military moves and its agreement to meet next month to hold talks on trade relations seemed contradictory, they probably reflected North Korea's uncertainty over how to achieve its longstanding goal of Korean unification.

abstract: For a Westerner, there is a strangeness about entering the demilitarized zone between the two Koreas from the Communist side.   At the point where north and south meet, just across a three-inch concrete ridge that marks the demarcation line, American soldiers in helmets ringed with the twin blue bands of the United Nations gaze northward. Shouted greetings in English from a distance of 50 yards brought only silence.   In moments, half a dozen soldiers have binoculars trained on Panmun Pavilion, the three-story structure built by the North Koreans as an administrative center and viewing point. An American officer appears in sunglasses, watching as the visitors from the north survey the scene in the company of an officer in the olive-drab tunic of the North Korean Army.
lead_paragraph: For a Westerner, there is a strangeness about entering the demilitarized zone between the two Koreas from the Communist side.

abstract: We found the ducks in a cluttered shop on a back street in Seoul one Sunday afternoon. Perched on a dusty shelf, necks arched so they stared at each other, the wooden ducks were unmistakably a pair. We were actually cheating, buying them ourselves, for in South Korea everyone knows that such matched ducks are to be given as wedding presents, not purchased after the wedding by the couple themselves. But the ducks, tokens of the fidelity and constancy that should grace married life, seemed an apt and pleasant souvenir.

abstract: This is the haunting image of the new South Korean student activism: Lee Dong Soo, 22 years old, slowly and deliberately douses himself with gasoline and sets himself on fire. As the flames engulf him, he shouts, ''Out with U.S. imperialists!'' and throws himself from a third-story ledge at Seoul National University.   The time-honored tradition of Korean student protest has emerged in a new, unpredictable and sometimes violent form. In recent weeks, three students have immolated themselves; clashes between riot policemen and student protesters have left two policemen dead and some students blinded, and small groups of students have tried to occupy the United States Embassy, a Korean-American bank and an American cultural center.   For most of modern South Korean history, to be a student has also meant to be a protester. Student demonstrations in 1960 brought down the Government of Syngman Rhee, and students have risked imprisonment and injury in subsequent protests against two military coups. The ranks of the Korean establishment - economists, businessmen, even Government officials - are filled with people who say they once were student protesters but who left activism behind when they left college.
lead_paragraph: This is the haunting image of the new South Korean student activism: Lee Dong Soo, 22 years old, slowly and deliberately douses himself with gasoline and sets himself on fire. As the flames engulf him, he shouts, ''Out with U.S. imperialists!'' and throws himself from a third-story ledge at Seoul National University.

abstract: For the first time since the end of the Korean war 32 years ago, North and South Koreans met and embraced long-separated relatives living on the other side of the fortified Korean border.   Tearful reunions, at times intensely emotional, were held in a large hotel room in eastern Seoul as 15 North Koreans met brothers, sisters, cousins and uncles they had not seen for decades.   Several learned for the first time that their parents had died. Most of them, like a 51-year-old North Korean man named Lee Yun Koo, sobbed hard.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since the end of the Korean war 32 years ago, North and South Koreans met and embraced long-separated relatives living on the other side of the fortified Korean border.

abstract: At a recent meeting in Honolulu, senior officials of the United States and South Korea discussed what once would have been unthinkable: a nuclear-free zone covering the Korean Peninsula. Such a zone would require withdrawal of U.S. nuclear weapons from th
snippet: At a recent meeting in Honolulu, senior officials of the United States and South Korea discussed what once would have been unthinkable: a nuclear-free zone covering the Korean Peninsula. Such a zone would require withdrawal of U.S. nuclear weapons...
lead_paragraph: At a recent meeting in Honolulu, senior officials of the United States and South Korea discussed what once would have been unthinkable: a nuclear-free zone covering the Korean Peninsula. Such a zone would require withdrawal of U.S. nuclear weapons from the South and the dismantling of nuclear weapons facilities in the North. Pyongyang denies that it is building nuclear weapons, but then so did Iraq.

abstract: South Korean analysts and foreign diplomats say they see possible policy changes in North Korea that are pushing it toward more regular contact with non-Communist governments, including the one in Seoul.  The start of economic talks between the two Koreas last week and their agreement to resume the discussions in early December have produced a broadly held view here that a shift in Korean relations could be occurring.    ''This might be a turning point,'' a political scientist at Seoul National University said.   The assessment was offered with extreme caution. For one thing, it is hard to determine unequivocally almost anything that goes on in North Korea, one of the world's more closed societies. For another, any sudden opening of trade between the Koreas would not undo nearly four decades of mutual hate and suspicions.
lead_paragraph: South Korean analysts and foreign diplomats say they see possible policy changes in North Korea that are pushing it toward more regular contact with non-Communist governments, including the one in Seoul. The start of economic talks between the two Koreas last week and their agreement to resume the discussions in early December have produced a broadly held view here that a shift in Korean relations could be occurring.

abstract: Neither North Korea nor South Korea likes to admit it, but the fate of their divided peninsula continues to be shaped by the big powers, directly and otherwise, as events last week made clear. A young Russian, Vasily Yakovlevich Matuzok, had defected to the West on Nov. 23, choosing one of the world's more dangerous routes.     While on a tour of Panmunjom in the inaptly named, heavily armed Korean demilitarized zone, Mr. Matuzok ran suddenly from the North Korean sector to the South. North Korean guards, violating the bundle of rules in effect at the Panmunjom truce village, chased him deep into southern territory, some firing automatic rifles. In the ensuing gun battle, the defector escaped unharmed but three North Korean guards and one South Korean were killed and an American soldier assigned to the United Nations Command was wounded.
lead_paragraph: Neither North Korea nor South Korea likes to admit it, but the fate of their divided peninsula continues to be shaped by the big powers, directly and otherwise, as events last week made clear. abstract: LEAD: NORTH KOREA has lost faith in its ability to reunify Korea under Communist rule and is prepared to negotiate peace with South Korea and the United States following next month's presidential election in the South. This was my conclusion after 10 days of conversations in Pyongyang last month with a variety of North Korean leaders, including Prime Minister Li Gun Mo, Foreign Minister Kim Yong Nam and Hwang Chang Yop, the powerful secretary of the Workers (Communist) Party Central Committee responsible for foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: NORTH KOREA has lost faith in its ability to reunify Korea under Communist rule and is prepared to negotiate peace with South Korea and the United States following next month's presidential election in the South. This was my conclusion after 10 days of conversations in Pyongyang last month with a variety of North Korean leaders, including Prime Minister Li Gun Mo, Foreign Minister Kim Yong Nam and Hwang Chang Yop, the powerful secretary of the Workers (Communist) Party Central Committee responsible for foreign policy. Economic pressures appear to be compelling North Korea to pursue two closely related priorities: a reduction of military spending through an accommodation with Seoul and Washington, and a rapid influx of advanced industrial technology, facilitated by a China-style economic opening to the West.

abstract: The rumors, now dispelled, that Kim Il Sung, the North Korean leader, had been assassinated were based largely on announcements by North Korean loudspeakers at the border. Here are excerpts, provided by the South Korean Government, from loudspeaker announcements said to have been made by North Korea over three days. The loudspeakers were said to have been positioned at points along the Korean demilitarized zone, most of them in the western sector near the truce village of Panmunjom.  Sunday     12:50 P.M. - Somber music is played on the air.

Press reports received here from Washington today quoted a State Department spokesman, Alan Romberg, as urging North Korea to reconsider its decision.

abstract: President Reagan was preparing for a three-hour tour today in the grim demilitarized zone between the two Koreas, planning to address American troops and look by binoculars at what he called the forces of ''hatred and oppression'' across the demarcation line in North Korea.    An advance battalion of news personnel crowded into this camp nestled in foothills not far from North Korean military outposts as Mr. Reagan prepared to depart from Seoul, the South Korean capital, 26 miles to the south.    ''You are on the front lines of freedom,'' the President declared in remarks prepared for the visit. ''The Communist system to the north is based on hatred and oppression.''

abstract: A Federal judge yesterday dismissed damage suits brought against United States Government agencies by families of the passengers killed when a Korean Air Lines Boeing 747 jet was shot down by a Soviet fighter in 1983. All 269 people on board were killed.  The judge, Aubrey E. Robinson Jr., said in Federal District Court in Washington that neither the Federal Aviation Administration nor the Defense Department had failed to perform any required duties in connection with the flight, in which the airliner strayed more than 300 miles off course into Soviet airspace.   Even if Government officials had been negligent in not somehow warning the South Korean crew, the judge said, the Soviet action in downing the craft would remove any liability from Federal employees.

abstract: From the ever-present Border Patrol cars to the the shops selling used clothes, the southern end of downtown El Paso is the ultimate Texas border strip: part Mexico, part Texas, part Texan-Mexican hybrid.   The supermarkets advertise mayonnaise as Mayonesa Kraft and lunch meat as Treet carne para lonche. The Woolworth's store calls itself a ''cinco y diez'' rather than a five and ten. And these days the proprietors are often buckaroos like Hochan Kim, Sang Lee and Chong H. Yi.

abstract: The meeting was modern but the arrangements for it, in a way, go back a thousand years.   Lee Wook Soo and his wife, Lee Jung Ja, gathered quietly one recent evening with 14 other Korean couples at the Young Bin Kwan restaurant in midtown Manhattan. They ate and they drank and they carried forward a centuries-old custom of mutual trust that has made it possible for hundreds of Korean immigrants to open businesses in the city, businesses that have revitalized neighborhoods and increased the impact that this particular ethnic group has had on New York.   The custom is called a ''gyeh,'' a practice in which a group of people -like the couples in the restaurant -pool their money to form something much like a credit union. Each month someone else uses the collected money - usually interest free. This time it was the Lees' turn, and the $7,500 they took home was welcome. Their kitchen needed work and their dry-cleaning business in Harlem could use the extra capital.
lead_paragraph: The meeting was modern but the arrangements for it, in a way, go back a thousand years.

abstract: The police broke up demonstrations today by hundreds of youths at five universities in support of 60 students occupying a United States Government office here.   Witnesses said some demonstrators hurled gasoline-filled bottles at the police, who responded with tear gas.   The takeover at the four-story United States Mission building continued tonight, with the 60 students still barricaded in the second-floor library while American officials spent a second day trying to persuade the protesters to leave.

abstract: On a street corner in Hiroshima, near a small bridge, a stone monument stands in memory of 20,000 Koreans killed in the 1945 atomic bomb attack.     Thousands of Koreans, whose country was then under Japanese colonial rule, were involuntarily brought to Japan during World War II to make up for labor shortages. About one of every four civilians who died in Hiroshima that day in August 1945 was a Korean.   Near the street corner by the bridge is the famous Hiroshima Peace Park, with a cenotaph dedicated to the many thousands of Japanese who died in the nuclear blast. Korean groups have tried to have their monument moved into the main park, but city officials turn them down. They say that there is room for only the cenotaph and that they rebuff not only Koreans but also many other groups seeking space inside.
lead_paragraph: On a street corner in Hiroshima, near a small bridge, a stone monument stands in memory of 20,000 Koreans killed in the 1945 atomic bomb attack.

abstract: Some things have not changed here after 32 years. Searchlights still play every night over the fingers, crags and ravines of midpeninsula mountains in the demilitarized zone.   The loudspeakers still blare out the metallic music and propaganda messages from the regime of the North Korean leader, Kim Il Sung.   Bunkers still honeycomb the hills. They are made of reinforced concrete now instead of sandbags piled helter-skelter on top of engineering stakes. Some bunkers are painted blue and green. Cosmos flowers grow nearby.
lead_paragraph: Some things have not changed here after 32 years. Searchlights still play every night over the fingers, crags and ravines of midpeninsula mountains in the demilitarized zone.

abstract: United States officials accused North Korea today of being ''unreasonable and inhumane'' for refusing to allow an American soldier to speak with his Army superiors and relatives about whether he had defected to the Communist nation.   In a terse exchange during a public session of the Korean Military Armistice Commission, North Korea again ruled out any meeting between representatives of the United Nations Command and Pfc. Joseph T. White of St. Louis.

abstract: North Korea today dismissed as ''sheer fabrication'' an official Burmese finding that it was responsible for the Oct. 9 bombing in Rangoon that killed 21 people, including four South Korean Cabinet ministers.    The North Korean Government in Pyongyang also said the Burmese decision to sever diplomatic ties and to order North Korean Embassy officials to leave the country by noon Sunday was ''unjustifiable.''   Breaking off relations was ''a dangerous act seriously endangering peace in Asia and the world,'' the North Korean Foreign Ministry said in a statement broadcast by the official Central News Agency and monitored in Tokyo.   The statement, coupled with new denunciations of North Korea in Seoul, increased tensions on the Korean peninsula at a time when they were already extremely high.
lead_paragraph: North Korea today dismissed as ''sheer fabrication'' an official Burmese finding that it was responsible for the Oct. 9 bombing in Rangoon that killed 21 people, including four South Korean Cabinet ministers.

abstract:
DURING the recent commemoration of the end of the war in Vietnam, commentators frequently pointed out that troops in that war were treated differently. They went into action younger, their average age was seven years less than the troops in World War II. They were isolated. They dribbed into the country as replacements and left as individuals whose tour was up. And when they came home, there were no brass bands. They were forgotten.

The commemoration left me with mixed emotions.

abstract: A South Korean court sentenced 20 college students today to as much as seven years in prison for occupying the United States Information Service building in downtown Seoul last May.   The sentences were considerably harsher than those generally imposed on student demonstrators in recent years.   They seemed to reflect a tougher Government attitude toward all forms of dissent. Many foreign diplomats in South Korea trace the attitude to the four-day takeover of the American building by 73 students.
lead_paragraph: A South Korean court sentenced 20 college students today to as much as seven years in prison for occupying the United States Information Service building in downtown Seoul last May.

abstract: SEOUL, South KoreaThe Korean War, at least the war according to ''M*A*S*H,'' is finally winding down in Korea. The end is due in early April, and as far as the South Korean Government is concerned, it comes none too soon.    ''M*A*S*H,'' television's indefatigable antiwar satire, has been broadcast for years by the American Forces Korea Network as entertainment for the 40,000 United States service men and women stationed here.   But it means that week after week, Koreans, too, get to watch a program that many officials believe portrays their country unfairly as a somewhat backward, troublesome American dependent. They fail to see the humor. ''We didn't protest,'' one official said. ''Let's say we expressed our annoyance.''
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South KoreaThe Korean War, at least the war according to ''M*A*S*H,'' is finally winding down in Korea. The end is due in early April, and as far as the South Korean Government is concerned, it comes none too soon.
