abstract: 'S IN 3-DAY VISIT By RICHARD HALLORAN   SEOUL, South Korea, March 28 -Secretary of Defense Caspar W.  Weinberger arrived here today from Japan for a three-day visit in which officials said he would encourage President Chun Doo Hwan to continue improving human rights.   Mr. Weinberger also plans to ask the South Korean Government to increase its financial support for United States forces stationed here. The South Korean Government plans to spend $160 million this year to improve living and operating standards for American forces.   A Pentagon briefing paper given to reporters on Mr. Weinberger's plane said the Korean ''political situation will be reviewed with special emphasis on protection of human rights and other measures to insure continued domestic stability.''

abstract: It has become well-nigh impossible for a woman to walk down a street in midtown Manhattan without being handed a flier for a manicure shop. They seem to be proliferating the way Korean greengrocers did in the recent past. By what may or may not be a strange coincidence, the nail salons also seem to be staffed mainly by Koreans.   No one, least of all the manicurists themselves, can trace the origins of this phenomenon. The vast majority of Koreans giving manicures and pedicures in New York learned the trade here, not in their native country. Most say they read an ad for training in a Korean-language newspaper.

abstract: Kwon Sun-chon of South Korea became the first flyweight champion of the International Boxing Federation today by knocking out Rene Busayong of the Philippines in the fifth round of a scheduled 15- round fight.   At 2 minutes 48 seconds of the fifth round, Kwon knocked down Busayong for the third time in the round, and the Filipino was counted out.

abstract: The South Korean Foreign Minister today demanded a public apology from the Soviet Union over the downing of a Korean Air Lines Boeing 747 and insisted that Moscow offer full financial compensation for the losses and guarantee that such an act would never be repeated.     In a briefing this afternoon, Foreign Minister Lee Bum Suk called on the United Nations Security Council to press for these demands.   Still unexplained by Korean Government officials and aviation authorities is why the Korean plane was so far off course. Speculation here on that point centers on two possibilities: an unusual malfunction of the plane's navigation system or the chance that Soviet fighters forced the plane off course. ''But we are not sure yet,'' Mr. Lee said.
lead_paragraph: The South Korean Foreign Minister today demanded a public apology from the Soviet Union over the downing of a Korean Air Lines Boeing 747 and insisted that Moscow offer full financial compensation for the losses and guarantee that such an act would never be repeated.

abstract: North and South Korea blamed each other today for an exchange of gunfire across the demilitarized zone early this morning.   The troops fired across the DMZ for four hours and North Korea said that an unspecified number of its civilian policemen had been killed in the battle.   Amid conflicting reports on what happened, South Korea's Defense Ministry said in a statement here that four North Korean soldiers were attempting to flee south across the DMZ and were either killed or wounded by mines.
lead_paragraph: North and South Korea blamed each other today for an exchange of gunfire across the demilitarized zone early this morning.

abstract: A South Korean opposition leader said last week that United States support for the Government of President Chun Doo Hwan had inflamed anti-American sentiment in South Korea.   The opposition leader, Kim Young Sam, a possible opposition candidate for President, said in an interview, ''In the eyes of the Korean people, the Government of the United States is supporting the military dictatorship more than it is supporting democratization.''   Mr. Kim's remarks, which he plans to include in a speech tomorrow at Harvard University, drew criticism from United States Government officials.
lead_paragraph: A South Korean opposition leader said last week that United States support for the Government of President Chun Doo Hwan had inflamed anti-American sentiment in South Korea.

abstract: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea urged American business leaders yesterday to redouble their efforts to strengthen economic ties with his country.   About 75 flag-waving South Koreans greeted their President's motorcade at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where a large contingent of Federal security officers mingled with the policemen assigned to guard the freed Amercian hostages who are also staying there.   In comments prepared for a dinner given in his honor by David Rockefeller, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, Mr. Chun said that the United States receives 26.3 percent of South Korea's exports and supplies 19.8 percent of its imports.
lead_paragraph: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea urged American business leaders yesterday to redouble their efforts to strengthen economic ties with his country.

abstract: In the Korean folk epics known as Pansori songs, one performer - accompanied only by a drummer - sings, acts and narrates all the roles in a narrative that might last nine hours. New Yorkers had a rare opportunity to hear Pansori excerpts and other Korean folk music in a two-hour concert Friday at the Alternative Museum.

abstract: Enveloped head to toe in protective suits, researchers bend over machines at the Lucky-Goldstar Research and Development Center here, checking silicon wafers that will be made into semiconductors. In these stark white rooms filled with equipment that towers over the researchers, the company is testing its own limits, pushing to develop better and more sophisticated semiconductors.   Lucky-Goldstar, like other South Korean semiconductor manufacturers, is racing to catch up with the technological levels of its United States and Japanese competitors. Although South Korean manufacturers still lag behind, they have established themselves as important players.   Estimates of sales of South Korean semiconductors, the electronic chips that process or store data in computers, range from $100 million to more than $1 billion. This year, according to the Yonhap news agency, manufacturers hope to nearly double their 1984 sales.

abstract: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea appointed a new Prime Minister today and replaced five other ministers in his first major Cabinet shuffle since becoming head of state in September 1980.   A presidential spokesman said that Mr. Chun made the changes to achieve better progress under South Korea's new five-year development plan.   The decision to replace Prime Minister Nam Duck Woo, a respected economic technician, with Yoo Chang Soon, a former head of the Korean Traders Association, appeared to reflect Mr. Chun's dissatisfaction with the state of the economy.

abstract:
MOOL Lae Bang Ah, or Water Wheel, is the second Korean restaurant to settle in the county, and very welcome it is. The restaurant features both Korean and Japanese cuisine; but in these visits we concentrated on the Korean dishes listed on the extensive menu. Newcomers to this cuisine shouldn't be shy. First of all, the menu, written in both Korean and English, provides diners with descriptions of every dish. And second, with its Mongolian-Chinese influence, Korean food is familiar. Bite-sized meats or fish mingle with finely sliced or shredded vegetables and rice. Ginger, soy sauce, scallions and garlic season most dishes. What makes the difference, however, are the fillips of searing chilies -- sometimes added directly to a dish, sometimes mixed into a paste that can be applied to taste -- and the side dishes of briny kimchee (pickled Chinese cabbage) that appear at every meal. The range of tastes is broad, from mild and soothing to incendiary. Be sure to state your preference every time, as the kitchen's hand isn't consistent in dealing out peppery heat.

 A particular attraction at Mool Lae Bang Ah are the grills, set flush into almost every table top and all ready for the ritual of Korean barbecue, a must.  The beef was excellent and made a much better choice than chicken, which, besides having little flavor, dried out on the grill. The waiter will start the grilling process, but once it has begun, try to take over, or at least remove the meat when done to your liking. We found the waiter's continued hovering over the grill intrusive, and we didn't share his taste for well-done beef, although even that remained juicy and full of meaty flavor.Classic, hearty soups are treated like main dishes here; find them hidden among the entree listings.  To be sure, Korean soups can be meals in themselves; simply add a bowl of rice. We enjoyed dumplings and rice cake slices in a full-flavored, soothing broth (duk mandoo guk).

Bite-sized meats or fish mingle with finely sliced or shredded vegetables and rice. Ginger, soy sauce, scallions and garlic season most dishes. What makes the difference, however, are the fillips of searing chilies -- sometimes added directly to a dish, sometimes mixed into a paste that can be applied to taste -- and the side dishes of briny kimchee (pickled Chinese cabbage) that appear at every meal. The range of tastes is broad, from mild and soothing to incendiary. Be sure to state your preference every time, as the kitchen's hand isn't consistent in dealing out peppery heat.

abstract: The Defense Department said today that the Air Force had erased a radar tape that traced part of the flight of a South Korean airliner shot down over Soviet territory in 1983, but that the tape had recorded the plane's fate.   A total of 269 people died when the plane, on a New York-to-Seoul flight, was downed by a Soviet jet after it went off course and entered Soviet airspace north of Japan.

abstract: LEAD: A folk orchestra playing new music implies contradictions, but the Choongang Traditional Korean Orchestra stayed close to its roots when it performed on Monday night at Alice Tully Hall. The 42-piece orchestra is conducted by Bum Hoon Park, a professor of music at Choongang University in Seoul, South Korea.
lead_paragraph: A folk orchestra playing new music implies contradictions, but the Choongang Traditional Korean Orchestra stayed close to its roots when it performed on Monday night at Alice Tully Hall. The 42-piece orchestra is conducted by Bum Hoon Park, a professor of music at Choongang University in Seoul, South Korea. It includes percussion (drums and gongs), winds (flutes and reeds) and strings (fiddles and zithers), and its repertory transforms music for soloists and small groups into extended showpieces.

abstract: Politicians, intellectuals and diplomats here say continuing talks on the crucial issue of constitutional revision offer changes that might ease growing political tensions and allow Koreans more say in choosing their Government.   They add that although they do not believe a recent surge of violent protest will spark a broader uprising, failure to forge an acceptable compromise would risk more widespread protest.   ''Right now there isn't one clear issue that can serve as a catalyst like a fraudulent election,'' said a longtime foreign resident of South Korea who witnessed the disturbances that preceded the last two military coups. ''There's still hope that the question of constitutional revision can be worked out through a process of negotiation and compromise.''
lead_paragraph: Politicians, intellectuals and diplomats here say continuing talks on the crucial issue of constitutional revision offer changes that might ease growing political tensions and allow Koreans more say in choosing their Government.

abstract: A dozen deafening drills were turned off at a Seoul subway construction site so that the foreman could make himself heard.   The foreman, Cho Myung Chae, who said his gang was ''making one yard a day'' at one of the 84 construction sites where work is proceeding on a second subway line, recalled tunneling of a different kind that he did three years ago.   He was one of a team from a South Korean engineering group that cut an interception tunnel going north to meet an ''invasion tunnel'' built by North Koreans under the demilitarized zone.
lead_paragraph: A dozen deafening drills were turned off at a Seoul subway construction site so that the foreman could make himself heard.

abstract: Among the first sights to catch the visitor's eye are the crosses.    It is not just that there are so many of them, perched upon buildings and forming rooftop latticework across many blocks. What startles in South Korean cities is how the crosses are set on pyramid steel towers, struggling, in advertisement for themselves, to reach higher than those atop neighboring churches. At night, they glow in red neon against the sky.
lead_paragraph: Among the first sights to catch the visitor's eye are the crosses.

abstract: Japanese patrol boats and American military planes searched the northern Sea of Japan today but were unable to find wreckage or any other trace of the Korean Air Lines jumbo jet that was downed after being fired on by a Soviet fighter plane early Thursday morning.    One ship reportedly discovered a 330- foot-wide oil slick on waters 18 miles west of Sakhalin Island, where the Boeing 747 apparently went down. A sample was taken to a Government laboratory for testing, but by tonight it was still not clear whether the oil had any connection with the Korean plane.

abstract: Japan has agreed to sell more than 400,000 tons of surplus rice, valued at close to $200 million, to South Korea following the failure of much of the 1980 Korean rice crop, officials announced here last weekend.   The agreement, which was apparently held up by political differences last year, was seen here as a sign that the two nations are moving cautiously to patch up their disagreements. Since January the Japanese have also offered to resume economic aid to South Korea, and last week Foreign Minister Masayoshi Ito went to Seoul in an effort to improve relations.

abstract: South Korean intelligence officials say that at least 105,000 North Koreans are being held in camps for ideological offenders.   The existence of the camps, long suspected by intelligence officials, was disclosed in recent interviews here with three North Korean defectors and with high-ranking officials of the South Korean Agency for National Security Planning, formerly the Korean Central Intelligence Agency.   Until recently, the intelligence officials said, it was difficult to check the existence of the camps. But now, with the aid of the defectors from North Korea, and with information that is believed to derive from American aerial reconnaissance, eight major camps for political offenders have been located, according to experts in Seoul, in addition to 25 separate conventional prisons for ordinary criminals.
lead_paragraph: South Korean intelligence officials say that at least 105,000 North Koreans are being held in camps for ideological offenders.

abstract: North Korea has become the leading supplier of arms to Iran in an arrangement that has helped Iran finance its continuing war with Iraq, according to a high-ranking American defense official.   The official, Francis J. West, Assistant Secretary of Defense for Intern@ational Security Affairs, said Iran had been paying North Korea partly in cash and partly in oil.   Military analysts, who provided details at Mr. West's request, said North Korea had provided about 40 percent of the approximately $2 billion worth of weapons, ammunition and equipment Iran acquired abroad this year. Ignoring OPEC Guidelines   To pay for the arms imports, oil industry analysts said, Iran has increased its oil production beyond the limits set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. They said it had also cut prices below those of OPEC and established the guns-for-oil bartering arrangement with North Korea. North Korea has maintained good relations with Moscow and with Peking and has accepted military aid from both. North Korea, according to Andrew J. Pierre in his book, ''The Global Politics of Arms Sales,'' has ''received assistance from Moscow in developing co-production and assembly plants for weapons, especially artillery pieces.''
lead_paragraph: North Korea has become the leading supplier of arms to Iran in an arrangement that has helped Iran finance its continuing war with Iraq, according to a high-ranking American defense official.

abstract: Somehow, winter's first dusting of snow this week softened the landscape and made it less bleak. Not much less, though.    At its best, the Korean demilitarized zone has little to offer, unless one has an insatiable appetite for craggy terrain and minefields and concertina barbed wire stretching across more miles than the eye can take in.   It can be boring.   Most of the time, the American and South Korean soldiers on one side of the two-and-a-half-mile-wide DMZ do little more than peer through long-range lenses at the North Koreans on the other side. They get to do this in summers that are airless and in winters that have no pity.
lead_paragraph: Somehow, winter's first dusting of snow this week softened the landscape and made it less bleak. Not much less, though.

abstract: A peaceful anti-Government rally and march by thousands of South Koreans ended this evening with riot policemen firing tear gas to disperse several hundred students who attacked them with clubs and rocks.   So much tear gas was used that fumes filled the broad streets of this southern industrial city for hours. The police reported that 20 officers were injured and that 28 students were arrested in the confrontation.
lead_paragraph: A peaceful anti-Government rally and march by thousands of South Koreans ended this evening with riot policemen firing tear gas to disperse several hundred students who attacked them with clubs and rocks.

abstract: Koreans and Korean-Americans living and working in New York said yesterday that strong pressure was put on them by South Korean employers and, indirectly, the South Korean Government, to participate in welcoming the visiting South Korean President, Chun Doo Hwan, and show support for his regime.   Most Korean companies and banks in New York were closed Friday, the day of President Chun's arrival, and employees were ''ordered'' to go to Kennedy International Airport to provide a welcoming throng, waving South Korean flags.   Some people said that they had been told to take relatives along, including in at least one case native-born Americans, and that they felt there was an implicit threat that their standing in the company, and even their jobs, would be affected if they did not obey.

abstract: First United Methodist Church of Flushing is really two congregations, one of Americans with deep roots in this country and the other of Korean immigrants.   The English-speaking congregation is small, barely 30 members in all, and lacks the wherewithal to maintain the ample church building in Queens. But the Korean congregation has 450 members, so many that it is spread out over two Sunday services and can field a choir of 40 singers. They have been the salvation of First Methodist.   Immigrants may see America as a land of opportunity, but for hundreds of churches like First Methodist, the immigrants themselves have been an opportunity.
lead_paragraph: First United Methodist Church of Flushing is really two congregations, one of Americans with deep roots in this country and the other of Korean immigrants.

abstract: THESE are heady days for opposition leaders here. Encouraged by recent events, they dream of assuming the national power they have sought for years.   Tens of thousands of Koreans have turned out at rallies across the country to back opposition demands for constitutional change. President Chun Doo Hwan has reversed direction, endorsing some change before his term expires. And although the obstacles that remain are legion, a tentative step toward political dialogue was taken last week when Mr. Chun met with Lee Min Woo, the president of the opposition New Korea Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: THESE are heady days for opposition leaders here. Encouraged by recent events, they dream of assuming the national power they have sought for years.

abstract: THE downing of the South Korean airliner that strayed into   Soviet airspace last week sent angry shock waves around the world. President Reagan called it ''a terrorist attack.'' He questioned ''Soviet credibility when they so flagrantly lie.''   ''The Soviet Union,'' Mr. Reagan insisted, ''owes the world the fullest possible explanation and apology for their inexcusable act of brutality.'' Korea demanded full compensation and there were stern denunciations in other world capitals, from NATO allies to Communist China and also from Communist Party officials in France and Italy.

abstract: The Government stepped up its war of words against North Korea today, blaming it for the ''barbarous'' bombing in Burma Sunday that killed 19 people, including some of South Korea's highest-ranking officials.   President Chun Doo Hwan, who apparently escaped harm only because a traffic delay kept him from the scene of the explosion, said upon his return to Seoul this morning that the incident was a ''carefully premeditated plot against the life of your President.''   'Not Talking From Evidence'    However, Government officials acknowledged they had no evidence that North Korea was behind the bombing, in which 47 people were wounded, many of them seriously. A principal Government spokesman, Choi Tae Soon, said, ''We are not talking from evidence but from the past record of the North Korean conspiracy.''
lead_paragraph: The Government stepped up its war of words against North Korea today, blaming it for the ''barbarous'' bombing in Burma Sunday that killed 19 people, including some of South Korea's highest-ranking officials.

abstract: A leading South Korean Protestant minister has been on a hunger strike in prison since mid-Au@gust to protest the policies of President Chun Doo Hwan, according to Japanese Christian leaders.   The Rev. Moon Ik Hwan, a noted theologian and translator of the Bible into Korean, who is serving a 20-year sentence for sedition, began fasting to protest continuing arrests of students in South Korea and what he charges is President Chun's failure to achieve a promised ''national reconciliation,'' the Japan Emergency Christian Conference on Korean Problems, a Protestant group, announced at a news conference here.   ''There is concern that he plans to continue his fast until at least Sept. 22,'' a spokesman for the group said.  ''Even if he ends his fast then, there are fears that his body may not be able to stand it,'' the spokesman said. Dr. Moon is 63 years old and is said to have lost weight rapidly during his three weeks of not eating. The fast is the second this summer by a political prisoner linked to Kim Dae Jung, South Korea's most prominent dissident, to draw attention to grievances of the opposition.
lead_paragraph: A leading South Korean Protestant minister has been on a hunger strike in prison since mid-Au@gust to protest the policies of President Chun Doo Hwan, according to Japanese Christian leaders.

abstract: South Korea's President ended a landmark visit to Japan today with leaders of both countries pledging to reinforce their relationship ''as mutually mature partners.''    But the trip here by President Chun Doo Hwan also seemed to underline subtle, yet potentially important, differences between the two countries on how best to deal with North Korea and to achieve peace on the Korean peninsula.   Mr. Chun returned to Seoul this afternoon after spending 49 hours in Tokyo on the first official visit to Japan by a South Korean leader. For both Mr. Chun and Japan's Prime Minister, Yasuhiro Nakasone, the journey had domestic political ramifications as well as diplomatic significance, and they chose to emphasize their points of agreement rather than discuss differences.

abstract: Seven leaders and members of a ring accused of extorting money from Korean-American restaurant and bar operators in Manhattan and Queens and engaging in gambling conspiracies and other crimes have been arrested.   Five more members of the ring are being sought, law-enforcement officials said yesterday, adding that they have broken up the ring.   All the suspects are of Korean background, reflecting the problem, one official said, that ''every ethnic group has its hoodlums who victimize their own.''

abstract: After 30 years, Japan is moving to eliminate one of its most blatant forms of official discrimination against 280,000 Korean and 8,000 Taiwanese residents. Many of them were brought to Japan for forced labor before World War II or were born here.   Proposed changes in the immigration law would rectify what the Koreans and Taiwanese claim is one of the most annoying forms of discrimination against them - a requirement that they reapply every three years for permission to stay in Japan.   The Justice Ministry has drafted legislation to grant permanent residence to minorities who lost their Japanese citizenship when Japan renounced its claim to two former colonies, Korea and Taiwan, with the signing in 1951 of the San Francisco Peace Treaty, formally ending World War II against all the allies except the Soviet Union.  The change also covers children and grandchildren living here.
lead_paragraph: After 30 years, Japan is moving to eliminate one of its most blatant forms of official discrimination against 280,000 Korean and 8,000 Taiwanese residents. Many of them were brought to Japan for forced labor before World War II or were born here.

abstract: South Korea today became the last of the major suppliers of steel to the United States to conclude an export restraint arrangement, apparently assuring the achievement of President Reagan's plan to limit steel imports so that they account for less than 20 percent of domestic consumption.   Administration trade officials said that Seoul had agreed to limit shipments for the next five years to 1.9 percent of the domestic market, after having rejected an American demand last week that shipments be held to 1.7 percent.    Korea's chief trade negotiator, Chulsu Kim, broke off the steel talks with the United States last week, saying that Washington's negotiating position with Korea had been tougher than it had been with Japan.
lead_paragraph: South Korea today became the last of the major suppliers of steel to the United States to conclude an export restraint arrangement, apparently assuring the achievement of President Reagan's plan to limit steel imports so that they account for less than 20 percent of domestic consumption.

abstract: After Maj. Gen. Chun Doo Hwan seized power and imposed strict martial law four years ago, students in this southwestern city took to the streets. By the end of their uprising in late May 1980, Government troops had killed nearly 200 people by official count, and far more than that according to Kwangju residents.    About 130 victims were buried in neat rows in an unmarked corner of the main public cemetery east of the city. While there is no formal memorial to the Kwangju victims, Koreans and foreign visitors make regular trips along bumpy back roads to look at the gravesites clustered on a gentle hillside.

abstract: A South Korean opposition leader said last week that President Chun Doo Hwan could face a ''serious uprising'' and possibly the disruption of the Summer Olympic Games in Seoul in 1988 unless he is willing to accept changes to the Constitution.   The Korean, Kim Sang Hyun, a former legislator who said he represented the views of other opposition leaders, including Kim Dae Jung and Kim Young Sam, has met with State Department officials and members of Congress during a two-week visit to the United States.   In an interview Friday, he said through an interpreter that Mr. Chun must accept a constitutional amendment allowing direct elections for President. Mr. Chun, who came to power in a military coup in 1980, was confirmed in office a year later by an electoral college controlled by the ruling Democratic Justice Party. Mr. Chun has said that he will step down when his seven-year term expires.
lead_paragraph: A South Korean opposition leader said last week that President Chun Doo Hwan could face a ''serious uprising'' and possibly the disruption of the Summer Olympic Games in Seoul in 1988 unless he is willing to accept changes to the Constitution.

abstract: The South Korean Government today released four of five opposition leaders they had placed under house arrest. But Kim Dae Jung, the most prominent critic of the Government, remained under house arrest tonight and under the threat of imprisonment.   The release of some of the opposition leaders came a day after the United States criticized the Government crackdown as ''inconsistent with basic democratic principles.''   In an interview published today, the South Korean Justice Minister said Mr. Kim, who is under a suspended jail sentence, could be sent back to prison if the Government found he had broken the law by signing a petition to revise the nation's Constitution and permit direct presidential elections.
lead_paragraph: The South Korean Government today released four of five opposition leaders they had placed under house arrest. But Kim Dae Jung, the most prominent critic of the Government, remained under house arrest tonight and under the threat of imprisonment.

abstract: The South Korean Government has arrested 56 students and is seeking more than 20 others for what it termed anti-Government activities that aid North Korea, according to reports reaching here.   Foreign diplomats in Seoul said the arrests represented a crackdown on student activism and a retreat from a recent policy of allowing more open student dissent. South Korean Government officials said the arrests were aimed only at radicals who were trying to topple the Government.   All of the students arrested were members of a student organization that planned the occupation May 23 of a United States Government building in Seoul, according to Yu Tae Wan, a spokesman for the South Korean Government. Mr. Yu said that some of the students in jail today were released after the occupation ended and then rearrested.
lead_paragraph: The South Korean Government has arrested 56 students and is seeking more than 20 others for what it termed anti-Government activities that aid North Korea, according to reports reaching here.

abstract: A defector from North Korea stood on the southern border of the demilitarized zone near here recently, looking north across a no man's land of grasses and reeds two and a half miles wide.   The defector, 31-year-old Kim Yong Joon, had returned to the area he crossed in the early morning of Jan. 7, wanting to see again the men here who had given him refuge. Mr. Kim, a short, wiry man in a blue suit, who accompanied South Korean officers on a five-hour tour along the zone that divides North Korea from the South, may be one of the last to have made his way through an obstacle that has been made increasingly difficult to cross.   Late in April, North and South Korean forces traded fire for four hours near here after four men, apparently Northern defectors, were spotted in the zone. Some bloody clothing was retrieved in the morning from the southern side. The four men - or their bodies - were gone.
lead_paragraph: A defector from North Korea stood on the southern border of the demilitarized zone near here recently, looking north across a no man's land of grasses and reeds two and a half miles wide.

abstract: South Korea's most important sports official said yesterday that Soviet sports authorities indicated they were ready to talk with South Korea about participating in the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul. We don't expect him to say Seoul is a great place. What we liked is he said he was ready to talk to us.''

abstract:
The Republic of Korea (South Korea) has unveiled the designs of 20 special coins it will issue to commemorate the 1988 Summer Olympic Games in Seoul. The set will include eight coins in gold and 12 in silver. All will have legal tender status.

The 20 coins will share a common obverse design honoring the lotus, a South Korean national symbol. Some of the reverses will spotlight Olympic sports, such as volleyball, wrestling, diving, archery and marathon running. One will depict the main Olympic stadium in Seoul. In a departure from past Olympic coinage, most will feature subjects drawn from Korea's culture and lifestyle including folklore and children's games.

abstract: Barring a sudden change of plans, Kim Dae Jung, South Korea's most important dissident politician, will return here Friday after more than two years of exile in the United States. What happens to him afterward will shape the immediate course of South Korea's politics and its relations with Washington.    Government officials have threatened to throw Mr. Kim back into prison to finish the 17 years he has left to serve on a 1980 conviction on sedition charges. The State Department has suggested that such an action could undermine a visit to Washington that President Chun Doo Hwan is planning for April. In a recent interview, a senior aide to Mr. Chun called Mr. Kim a ''revolutionary,'' said that imprisonment was definite and warned that worrying too much about foreign reaction would be ''a big mistake.'' Still, other officials insist that nothing has been decided. The possibilities include placing Mr. Kim under house arrest or forcing him back to the hospital from which he was released in December 1982 to go to the United States.
lead_paragraph: Barring a sudden change of plans, Kim Dae Jung, South Korea's most important dissident politician, will return here Friday after more than two years of exile in the United States. What happens to him afterward will shape the immediate course of South Korea's politics and its relations with Washington.

abstract: ''See you soon,'' said Chun Byung In, a 45-year-old Korean Air Lines pilot, when he left his family in Seoul on Aug. 27 for what he thought would be another routine trip.   But Mr. Chun was the pilot of Flight 7 last Thursday on its run to Seoul. His plane, a Boeing 747 jet carrying 269 people, first was reported missing, then was said to have landed - perhaps to have been forced down - on the Soviet Union's Sakhalin island, and finally was reported hit and destroyed by a Soviet missile.

abstract: One of the funniest events of the dance season took place on Thursday at Asia Society's Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium, when the Hyun Ja Kim Dance Company presented a sample of sundae-dogam or masked dance drama from Kyung Sang Province in South Korea. It isn't surprising to learn that the theater form was banned from the Korean court during the 17th century. There can seldom have been such raucous goings-on at Asia Society.

abstract: Following are statements by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union and Secretary of State George P. Shultz of the United States at the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe yesterday in Madrid, covering what they said about the downing of a South Korean airliner. Mr. Gromyko's remarks are excerpts from his speech as reported by Reuters. Mr. Shultz's comments were recorded by The Associated Press. Gromyko's Statement    Pronouncements are being made from this rostrum about the incident with the South Korean aircraft. This incident - and this is well known - is being deliberately exploited by certain circles in the United States to exacerbate the international situation. They have unleashed a wave of slander and shameless insinuations against the U.S.S.R. and the socialist countries.
lead_paragraph: Following are statements by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union and Secretary of State George P. Shultz of the United States at the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe yesterday in Madrid, covering what they said about the downing of a South Korean airliner. abstract: Yang Yong, one of China's highest-ranking military officials, died Jan. 6 in Peking, according to Chinese press reports received in New York. He was 70 years old.   A veteran Red Army commander, Mr. Yang led units of the so-called Chinese volunteers in at least the final stages of the Korean War and then commanded the Chinese forces until they withdrew from North Korea in 1958.

abstract: A week after a South Korean 747 airliner took off from Kennedy International Airport on a journey that was ended by a Soviet air-to-air missile, there are many unanswered questions.   Although American officials have pieced together much of what happened to Flight 7 over East Asia, there are still these questions:     - Why did a South Korean jetliner with 269 people aboard enter Soviet airspace, apparently in disregard of well- known aviation warnings? Was it an accident or was it deliberate?     - Did air traffic controllers or intelligence people know that the jetliner was off course before its final communications with the control tower at Narita airport near Tokyo?     - What did air controllers do when they determined that the jetliner was missing?     - Did the pilot of the Soviet SU-15, who had visual contact with the jetliner, fail to identify the Boeing 747 as a commercial airliner before shooting it down?
lead_paragraph: A week after a South Korean 747 airliner took off from Kennedy International Airport on a journey that was ended by a Soviet air-to-air missile, there are many unanswered questions.

abstract: The South Korean airliner that the United States says was shot down by a Soviet fighter was equipped not only with three computerized navigation systems but with radar that enables pilots to follow coastlines and other terrain features.    Furthermore, the crew would normally have been able to verify the proper functioning of the navigation systems perhaps two hours after takeoff when their Boeing 747 jumbo jet flew past a powerful radio fix at the end of the Aleutian Island chain.   The availability of such electronic aids only magnified the puzzlement among safety experts as to why the South Korean crew deviated from course and strayed deep into Soviet territory.   Some experts asked whether there might have been a major malfunction that could have knocked out or distorted the readings of these electronic aids. If so, why then would the crew not have reported trouble when making radio reports to air-traffic-control facilities?
lead_paragraph: The South Korean airliner that the United States says was shot down by a Soviet fighter was equipped not only with three computerized navigation systems but with radar that enables pilots to follow coastlines and other terrain features.

abstract: Four architects who won a national competition for their design for a Korean War Veterans Memorial and a Washington architectural firm that wants to change it brought their dispute to the Commission of Fine Arts on Thursday to determine which design will eventually pay homage to Americans who fought in Korea.   "It's a very unusual situation," said Charles H. Atherton, the commission secretary. "We generally do not look at two designs on one issue, but as a matter of fairness we felt we should do this."

abstract: Following is a transcript of Secretary of State George P. Shultz's news conference today, as recorded by the State Department: OPENING STATEMENT    At 1400 hours Greenwich mean time yesterday, a Korean Air Lines Boeing 747 en route from New York to Seoul, Korea, departed Anchorage, Alaska. Two-hundred sixty-nine passengers and crew were on board, including Congressman Lawrence P. McDonald.   At approximately 1600 hours Greenwich mean time, the aircraft came to the attention of Soviet radar. It was tracked constantly by the Soviets from that time.
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of Secretary of State George P. Shultz's news conference today, as recorded by the State Department: OPENING STATEMENT

abstract: Chin Kim is an experienced violinist from South Korea who has had the great part of his training in the United States. Such influences as Ivan Galamian, Dorothy Delay and Josef Gingold -- add also, of course, his own inclinations -- have turned him into an honorable practitioner of the strongly Romantic Eastern European style of violin-playing so prevalent in the first half of this century. The technique is strong, the pressure on the strings firm and heavy. Weight and dark color predominate.   Mr. Kim, along with his partner at the piano, Hae Sook Rhee, played a largely familiar program at Weill Recital Hall last Saturday afternoon. There were Tartini's "Devil's Trill" Sonata, the Prokofiev F-minor Sonata and Ravel's Duo Sonata. Added to them were the Paganini Variations on "Nel cor piu non mi sento" and a bit of high-altitude fluff by Jeno Hubay called "Le Zephir."
lead_paragraph: Chin Kim is an experienced violinist from South Korea who has had the great part of his training in the United States. Such influences as Ivan Galamian, Dorothy Delay and Josef Gingold -- add also, of course, his own inclinations -- have turned him into an honorable practitioner of the strongly Romantic Eastern European style of violin-playing so prevalent in the first half of this century. The technique is strong, the pressure on the strings firm and heavy. Weight and dark color predominate.

abstract: The Chang Mu Dance Company, a group of Korean dancers and Korean- born dancers now living in New York, came to the Theater of the Riverside Church Wednesday night with a program of traditional Korean dances. All were stately in manner and sweet in choreographic flavor.    Many were solos for the company's director, Kim Maeja, a professor of dance at Ewha Woman's University in Seoul. In each of them, intense, or even stormy, emotions were channeled into a ritualized form. Thus ''Salpuri,'' a dance of exorcism, involved wavings of a white cloth and dignified steps in a billowy white gown. ''Sanjo,'' a solo of melancholic moods ranging from longing to sorrow, consisted of variations on gliding, and joy was expressed in ''Tae- Pyong-Mu,'' a dance of peace, by slow turns and a few demure raisings of the skirt above the ankles.
lead_paragraph: The Chang Mu Dance Company, a group of Korean dancers and Korean- born dancers now living in New York, came to the Theater of the Riverside Church Wednesday night with a program of traditional Korean dances. All were stately in manner and sweet in choreographic flavor.

abstract: President Chun Doo Hwan's ruling party announced sweeping changes in its leadership today, less than two weeks after a new opposition party had unexpected success in parliamentary elections.   Roh Tae Woo, a former general with close ties to Mr. Chun, was named party chief, and 22 of the other 29 top posts in the ruling Democratic Justice Party also changed hands. On Monday, Mr. Chun reorganized his 22-member Cabinet, appointing new officials for 13 positions.

abstract: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea is proposing that his nation and North Korea exchange ambassadors as a first step toward eventual reunification.   According to the text of a speech prepared for delivery on Friday in Seoul, Mr. Chun is urging that South Korea and North Korea ''each appoint a plenipotentiary with the rank of cabinet minister to head a resident liaison mission to be established in Seoul and Pyongyang.''   The proposal from Mr. Chun, who came to power in a military coup after the assassination of President Park Chung Hee in 1979, was contained in a text of the speech that was made available by the Korean Information Service at the United Nations.   Since the end of the Korean War in 1953, le aders on each side have from time to time suggested ways to go about reunifying their dividednation. But most of those proposals have been intended to score propaganda points and have not been so concre te as President Chun's latest statement.
lead_paragraph: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea is proposing that his nation and North Korea exchange ambassadors as a first step toward eventual reunification.

abstract: The United States, with its main competition at home in the Soviet Union, easily won its first gold medal in women's basketball tonight, defeating South Korea, 85-55.     The Americans controlled the game with their work on the backboards, where they outrebounded the South Koreans, 46-20. The Americans held a 3-to-1 advantage in offensive rebounds, and repeatedly used second and third shots to help build a lead that grew to its high of 30 points in the final seconds.   Despite that severe disadvantage, South Korea came within 10 points with 15 minutes 50 seconds to play, but then Cheryl Miller led a 14-0 spurt that put the United States in control. Miss Miller scored 16 points to lead the Americans. She made 7 of 10 shots, grabbed 11 rebounds, and had 5 assists. She was the tournament's leading scorer with an average of 16.5 for the six games, and was the inspiration for one of the two displays at the end of the game.
lead_paragraph: The United States, with its main competition at home in the Soviet Union, easily won its first gold medal in women's basketball tonight, defeating South Korea, 85-55.

abstract: Nearly eight months after returning from exile in the United States, Kim Dae Jung has yet to make it all the way back home.   Mr. Kim, probably South Korea's best-known dissident, has regained an unofficial leadership role in the political opposition, as he had expected. However, restraints imposed by the Government and his own sense of caution have kept him from fully finding his niche.   He is, above all, a politician, but he is forbidden to join an organized political party. He is a gifted stump speaker, but he avoids delivering public speeches out of fear of annoying the Government. He is, technically, a free man, but that does not keep him from being placed under occasional house arrest.
lead_paragraph: Nearly eight months after returning from exile in the United States, Kim Dae Jung has yet to make it all the way back home.

abstract: An international inquiry into the downing of a South Korean airliner by a Soviet fighter plane has resulted in a report that rejects the Soviet assertion that the jumbo jet was on an espionage mission.    The Russians have said the plane's takeoff and flight path were calculated to enable a military satellite to record Soviet defensive reactions. But the inquiry team reported to the International Civil Aviation Organization that the takeoff from Alaska would have brought the Boeing 747 to its destination in Seoul at its regularly scheduled time. So the team did not pursue the issue of a ''premeditated deviation from the flight plan'' for intelligence purposes.
lead_paragraph: An international inquiry into the downing of a South Korean airliner by a Soviet fighter plane has resulted in a report that rejects the Soviet assertion that the jumbo jet was on an espionage mission.

abstract: Government officials, chagrined over a breach of security for Pope John Paul II, ordered mental tests today for a young man accused of brandishing a cap gun near the Pope.    The national police immediately strengthened its guard, which was considerable, with thousands of officers already on full alert in response to unconfirmed reports of a plot to kill the Pope in South Korea.   After the cap-gun incident, which occurred this morning, men in dark suits carrying attache cases lined the base of an enormous altar from which John Paul elevated 103 Christian martyrs to sainthood. The cases, their latches open, were of a type often used to carry automatic weapons.
lead_paragraph: Government officials, chagrined over a breach of security for Pope John Paul II, ordered mental tests today for a young man accused of brandishing a cap gun near the Pope.

abstract: A huge anti-Government rally went off peacefully here today, but late tonight violence erupted as a small band of students burned placards and threw stones at riot policemen.   Earlier, tens of thousands of people gathered on the city's main thoroughfare as opposition leaders staged their third rally in recent weeks.   The rally appeared to be the largest anti-Government gathering in Kwangju since troops killed several hundred protesters here in May 1980. Rally organizers said more than 100,000 people took part today, but Government officials put the figure at 20,000 to 30,000. Independent observers gave estimates of 50,000 to 60,000.

abstract: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea has warned that student disorders on university campuses will be dealt with sternly if they threaten to create what he called social instability.    Mr. Chun asserted on Wednesday that his Government's recent policy of loosening controls on campus protests had led to student violence, including attacks on professors.   He did not make clear what specific incidents he had in mind, but he cautioned during a visit to the city of Taejon that they would be dealt with severely. He did not say how.

abstract: It's a shrewd director who knows the effect of his work as well as Lee Chang Ho. At a press conference after ''The Man With Three Coffins,'' the first South Korean film to be shown at the New York Film Festival, he said through an interpreter, ''Thank you for your patience'' - a bluntly honest remark. ''The Man With Three Coffins'' is the kind of film that must be seen twice before it makes sense. But only the most committed and curious students of world cinema may feel that Mr. Lee's artistic rigor is reward enough for struggling through the film's taxing narrative strategy and its obscurity to most Western viewers.   In summary, the plot sounds compelling. Three years after his wife's death, a man travels north to her hometown to scatter her ashes. Along the way he crosses paths more than once with a nurse also heading north with her elderly charge and encounters a prostitute who dies soon after he sleeps with her. All three women, including the wife seen in flashbacks, are played by the same actress, creating mysterious echoes. Is the hero imagining this similarity? Or are the women reincarnations of the wife?
lead_paragraph: It's a shrewd director who knows the effect of his work as well as Lee Chang Ho. At a press conference after ''The Man With Three Coffins,'' the first South Korean film to be shown at the New York Film Festival, he said through an interpreter, ''Thank you for your patience'' - a bluntly honest remark. ''The Man With Three Coffins'' is the kind of film that must be seen twice before it makes sense. But only the most committed and curious students of world cinema may feel that Mr. Lee's artistic rigor is reward enough for struggling through the film's taxing narrative strategy and its obscurity to most Western viewers.

lead_paragraph: Jungwon Park, a South Korean soprano trained at the Juilliard School, made a further step into her career with a recital at Merkin Concert Hall Wednesday night. Miss Park emerges from her education with a substantial set of attributes. The voice is full and secure in all its registers; decisions on phrasing, accents and tempo are good ones, and if Wednesday evening is an example, the repertory is tasteful and suitable to her strengths.

abstract: North Korea said today that the United States was planning large-scale naval exercises off the Korean Peninsula during the 1986 Asian Games, to be held in Seoul for 16 days beginning Sept. 20.   In a report monitored here, the official press agency quoted the Government newspaper as saying the United States was ''mobilizing the nuclear-powered aircraft carrier Carl Vinson and about 30 other warships with battleship New Jersey and many planes to stage large-scale mobile exercises in the Sea of Japan during the 1986 Asian Games.''

abstract: President Chun Doo Hwan lifted a political ban on 84 people today, three months before scheduled National Assembly elections, but left 15 better-known dissidents on a four-year- old blacklist.   Among those still barred from politics are Kim Dae Jung, who recently announced plans to return to South Korea from voluntary exile in the United States, and Kim Young Sam, former head of the now-banned New Democratic Party, who is regarded as the leader of Korean dissidents at home. Others left on the blacklist included Kim Jong Pil, former Prime Minister; Lee Hu Rak, former Korean Central Intelligence Agency director; Kim Sang Hyun, a political protege of Kim Dae Jung, and Kim Duk Yong, chief secretary of Kim Young Sam.
lead_paragraph: President Chun Doo Hwan lifted a political ban on 84 people today, three months before scheduled National Assembly elections, but left 15 better-known dissidents on a four-year- old blacklist.

abstract: The official North Korean press agency said today that a United States Air Force SR-71 reconnaissance plane had violated North Korean airspace twice in a ''high-handed encroachment'' on North Korea's sovereignty.   The agency said the spy plane entered North Korean airspace at 12:04 P.M. Friday south of Kangryong Peninsula and again above territorial waters east of Kosong at 1:42 P.M.   The report, which was monitored in Tokyo, said, ''The air intrusion and espionage of the U.S. imperialist aggressors were a gross violation of the armistice agreement and a high-handed enroachment on the sovereignty.''
lead_paragraph: The official North Korean press agency said today that a United States Air Force SR-71 reconnaissance plane had violated North Korean airspace twice in a ''high-handed encroachment'' on North Korea's sovereignty.

abstract: North Korea said today that it would suspend economic and political talks with South Korea to protest joint military maneuvers scheduled next month by the United States and South Korea.   The suspension was announced about a week after North Korea offered to halt military exercises in February and called on the United States and South Korea to postpone their annual war games.   A statement carried by the North Korean Central News Agency received in Tokyo said talks with the South would resume after the maneuvers ''when a favorable atmosphere is created.''
lead_paragraph: North Korea said today that it would suspend economic and political talks with South Korea to protest joint military maneuvers scheduled next month by the United States and South Korea.

abstract: A group of major Protestant churches accused the military-backed Government today of ''utter disregard'' for basic rights and declared its support for constitutional changes demanded by the political opposition.   The National Council of Churches in Korea, an alliance of six major Protestant denominations, said in a statement by the Rev. Kim Jee Giel, its chairman, that true democracy had been delayed more than 40 years, and that ''we cannot wait any longer.''

abstract: Vice President Bush watched American soldiers at this forward base today prepare to patrol the Demilitarized Zone between South Korea and North Korea.   ''Most impressive,'' Mr. Bush said after talking with troops and looking at their weapons, ''and very, very important.'' Mr. Bush first toured the headquarters of the combined field army for a briefing, then went to a South Korean hill post overlooking North Korea, and finally to Warrior Base, headquarters of the First Battalion, 23d Infantry, of the American Second Division, about two miles south of the zone.

abstract: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang accepted an invitation today to visit North Korea and said the United States should withdraw its troops from South Korea and conclude a peace agreement with the Pyongyang Government.   At a banquet honoring a North Korean delegation headed by Prime Minister Li Chong Ok, who arrived today for a five-day visit, Mr.  Zhao also called on the United States to ''stop pursuing a 'two Koreas' policy.''   The date for the visit was not settled.

abstract: THE destruction of Saddam Hussein's nuclear capability in the opening hours of the Persian Gulf war was met with more than a little cheering here. It was the right idea, a senior South Korean official said recently, adding with a wry smile, "too bad it was the wrong reactor."   The candidate for destruction that he and many other Asians have in mind sits in a heavily guarded complex near Yongbyon, a town 60 miles north of Pyongyang, North Korea's capital. By various estimates, the increasingly isolated government of Kim Il Sung, North Korea's aging "Great Leader," may be only four or five years away from producing a crude but effective atomic bomb. If true, Mr. Kim is already far closer to becoming a nuclear power than Mr. Hussein ever was. And that prospect figures in virtually every disaster scene that the Americans, Japanese and now even the Soviets dream up about the balance of power in Asia in the 1990's.
lead_paragraph: THE destruction of Saddam Hussein's nuclear capability in the opening hours of the Persian Gulf war was met with more than a little cheering here. It was the right idea, a senior South Korean official said recently, adding with a wry smile, "too bad it was the wrong reactor."

abstract: The two Koreas clashed on the soccer field today in a game dedicated to friendship, watched by the largest crowd to see a South Korean sports event since the 1988 Olympics.   South Korea won 1-0, but the score was insignificant beside the diplomatic coup in having two enemy nations share a playing field for only the second time since World War II. The first time was two weeks ago in North Korea, when the northern team beat the South 2-1.
lead_paragraph: The two Koreas clashed on the soccer field today in a game dedicated to friendship, watched by the largest crowd to see a South Korean sports event since the 1988 Olympics.

abstract: LEAD: For decades, North Korea has lived up to its reputation as a police state specializing in terrorism, intimidation and bizarre versions of history.
lead_paragraph: A significant opening occurred last week when, after a year of sputtering delays, Prime Minister Yon Hyung Muk of North Korea led the highest-level delegation to South Korea since the end of World War II. The two sides failed to narrow their differences but agreed to continue efforts to reduce tensions, meeting next in North Korea. More important was the fact that a dialogue had begun. Clearly part of what compelled the North to visit the South was the changing global environment brought about by the collapse of the cold war. But there were also signs of extraordinary internal and external pressures on the ossified regime of the 78-year-old self-proclaimed Great Leader, Mr. Kim.

abstract: South Korea announced today that it had accepted dates proposed by North Korea for resuming talks on economic issues and Red Cross cooperation. abstract: North and South Korean Red Cross representatives ended two days of talks today, agreeing in principle to permit ''free travel'' by people searching for relatives lost during the 40-year partition of this peninsula.   The concept of ''free travel'' had been offered Tuesday by the North Koreans in the first high-level negotiation to be held by the two Red Cross societies since 1973.   Both sides also agreed in principle to discuss ways to reunite separated Korean families as part of a ''comprehensive'' package, as the North Koreans had recommended.   But no details were settled, or even discussed significantly. In fact, even the basic concepts were so vague that there was no way to tell whether they could eventually lead to reunions of millions of Korean families.
lead_paragraph: North and South Korean Red Cross representatives ended two days of talks today, agreeing in principle to permit ''free travel'' by people searching for relatives lost during the 40-year partition of this peninsula.

abstract: South Korea tonight rejected a proposal from North Korea that the two countries and the United States join in three-way talks to unify the Korean peninsula.   The South Korean Minister of Unification, Sohn Jae Shik, said in Seoul that, before talks could begin, North Korea must first admit responsibility and apologize for the bombing in Rangoon, Burma, on Oct. 9 that killed 21 people, including aides to President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea.   But Mr. Sohn suggested the Seoul Government would be interested at some point in an ''enlarged meeting,'' which presumably would include China as well as the United States.   The Chinese Foreign Ministry in Peking, according to The Associated Press, endorsed the North Korean proposal for three- way talks.
lead_paragraph: South Korea tonight rejected a proposal from North Korea that the two countries and the United States join in three-way talks to unify the Korean peninsula.

abstract: After Japan formally annexed Korea 74 years ago, it went on to ban the use of the Korean language, force Koreans to adopt Japanese names and compel school children to do obeisance at Shinto shrines.    ''It was an intense sort of psychological cruelty,'' said Edwin O. Reischauer, the Harvard historian who was America's Ambassador to Japan from 1961 to 1966. ''It still looms large in the Korean mind.''

abstract: North Korean troops and soldiers of the United Nations Command opened fire on each other Friday in a clash that erupted over an apparent defection by a Soviet citizen at the Demilitarized Zone.     It was the most serious incident at the Panmunjom truce village in eight years.    At least two North Korean soldiers and one South Korean were reported killed, and an American soldier, identified as Pfc. Michael A. Burgoyne, 20 years old, of Portland, Mich., was wounded.  A military spokesman said Friday night that the condition of the American soldier was ''stable.''
lead_paragraph: North Korean troops and soldiers of the United Nations Command opened fire on each other Friday in a clash that erupted over an apparent defection by a Soviet citizen at the Demilitarized Zone.

abstract: Groups of North and South Korean visitors recrossed the border today and returned home after historic reunions with separated families they had not seen since before the Korean War.   Red Cross officials on both sides called the highly unusual exchange of families a success, and said they hoped that more would follow.   But it was evident, too, that the two Koreas had not forgotten their mutual distrust, and they issued complaints and protests even as their citizens were boarding buses for home.

abstract: The United States criticized the South Korean Government today for thwarting an opposition demonstration over the weekend.   The State Department spokesman, Charles E. Redman, suggested that the Seoul Government had breached its own Constitution in preventing a rally by sending tens of thousands of riot policemen into the streets to halt it.   ''Under the Korean Constitution, the Government has the obligation not only to protect security and public order, but also the freedom of association and speech,'' Mr. Redman said.

abstract:
As the war in the Persian Gulf grows in intensity, Americans might find it useful to hear from a citizen of South Korea, where American soldiers fought against Communist aggression 40 years ago.

The Korean War is generally believed by U.S. policymakers to have achieved its objectives, which were to destroy the armed forces of an aggressor nation, North Korea, and to restore a legitimate government in the region. These goals are similar to those articulated by President Bush. However, while American objectives in the gulf seem plausible and morally compelling, their underlying assumptions do not. If South Korea was a "success," the U.S. should think twice about the gulf.

abstract: Yong Lee, 31 years old, gets up at 3:30 every morning to buy the fresh fruit that he will sell until dark at his sidewalk vendor's stand in the heart of Center City. He hopes to save enough to open a permanent store in four or five years.   A few blocks away, almost in the shadow of City Hall, Bo M. Lee, a designer-entrepreneur who is not related to the street vendor, directs more than 70 employees as they make women's clothes. Mr. Lee started his business in 1979 with $1,000 he had saved. Last year it grossed $1.75 million. When business tension becomes too great, Mr. Lee retires to a small Buddhist temple on the top floor of his factory.   All over Philadelphia, thousands of Korean immigrants like the two Lees have moved beyond the greengrocer trade for which their countrymen are noted in New York City. Here they operate grocery stores, dry-cleaning shops, discount stores, seafood stands and small clothing factories.
lead_paragraph: Yong Lee, 31 years old, gets up at 3:30 every morning to buy the fresh fruit that he will sell until dark at his sidewalk vendor's stand in the heart of Center City. He hopes to save enough to open a permanent store in four or five years.

abstract: Human-rights abuses in South Korea have sharply risen since Secretary of State George P. Shultz visited Seoul three weeks ago and praised President Chun Doo Hwan, two human-rights organizations said last week.   The two groups, the Korean Institute for Human Rights and the North American Coalition for Human Rights in Korea, both based near Washington, said they had received reports that more than 50 people had been arrested without charge since Mr. Shultz's visit May 7 and that more than two dozen people had been tortured.   ''Secretary Shultz praised the Chun Government in its fine job on democratization in Korea and did not mention at all the human-rights violations,'' said Sim Kisop, a spokesman for the Korean Institute for Human Rights. As a result, Mr. Sim said, ''the Chun regime thinks the United States Government doesn't care about the human rights situation, and Chun thinks he can do anything.''
lead_paragraph: Human-rights abuses in South Korea have sharply risen since Secretary of State George P. Shultz visited Seoul three weeks ago and praised President Chun Doo Hwan, two human-rights organizations said last week.

abstract: A typhoon weakened into a tropical storm today after killing at least 13 people and injuring 100 others on South Korea's southwestern coast, officials said.   The police reported 12 people still missing after flash floods and landslides caused by the typhoon, which dumped up to 16 inches of rain in southwestern Korea on Thursday and Friday.   The Seoul weather bureau said that another typhoon was approaching.
lead_paragraph: A typhoon weakened into a tropical storm today after killing at least 13 people and injuring 100 others on South Korea's southwestern coast, officials said.

abstract: LEAD: The Emille Opera Company, an organization that promotes Korean performers studying and working in America, presented ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' in concert and in Korean on Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall. It was not exactly a memorable performance except from the standpoint of linguistic novelty, but it was throughly professional and assured.
lead_paragraph: The Emille Opera Company, an organization that promotes Korean performers studying and working in America, presented ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' in concert and in Korean on Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall. It was not exactly a memorable performance except from the standpoint of linguistic novelty, but it was throughly professional and assured. First credit should probably go to Jeongsoo Kim, the very young-looking conductor, who led from memory, made no apparent slips, and kept his cool when his singers were occasionally less lucky. At the moment he has a certain tendency to nail down nuances that might be more airily floated by, but he is a confident leader and may well develop into an idiomatic opera conductor.

abstract: LEAD: My job renovating housing for the homeless often takes me into the most devastated and dangerous neighborhoods of our city. I have sometimes feared for my safety, but I've always felt that my ''neutral'' skin color afforded me more protection than that of my white co-workers.

abstract: There is only one Living National Human Cultural Treasure in dance in the Republic of Korea and her name is Han Young-Suk. Miss Han was given the honor by the South Korean Government in 1969, as part of its continuing program to preserve traditional Korean culture in its pure form. This week, for the first time in more than two decades, the 65-year-old dancer will appear on the East Coast of the United States. Audiences will have a rare chance to see Miss Han when the American Dance Festival presents her in performances on Monday and Tuesday in Durham, N.C., and on Thursday at the Korean Cultural Service in New York City.   ''My grandfather, Han Sung-Joan, developed a unique style of Buddhist dance nearly a century ago,'' Miss Han explained, speaking through a translator in a recent conversation in Seoul. ''He did not have a daughter, so when I was 12 years old, he began to train me to become the sole inheritor of his form of seung-mu - a dance technique and style adapted from Buddhist rituals and some elements of other traditional Korean dances.'' There are three basic forms of traditional dances in Korean history: folk, shaman and Buddhist, but today, said Miss Han, they are intermingled.
lead_paragraph: There is only one Living National Human Cultural Treasure in dance in the Republic of Korea and her name is Han Young-Suk. Miss Han was given the honor by the South Korean Government in 1969, as part of its continuing program to preserve traditional Korean culture in its pure form. This week, for the first time in more than two decades, the 65-year-old dancer will appear on the East Coast of the United States. Audiences will have a rare chance to see Miss Han when the American Dance Festival presents her in performances on Monday and Tuesday in Durham, N.C., and on Thursday at the Korean Cultural Service in New York City.

abstract: United States and North Korean military officers met today in the Korean demilitarized zone and blamed each other for the exchange of gunfire at Panmunjom on Friday that left four soldiers dead and as many as six others wounded.    North Korea also traded angry words with South Korea, although the North made it plain that its true unhappiness was with the United States. The state- controlled radio in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, called the gun battle a ''premeditated, deliberate criminal act'' committed by American soldiers assigned to the United Nations Command, whose forces patrol the DMZ.    In turn, a senior South Korean official accused the North of ''an unpardonable, provocative barbarity.'' The official, Lee Jin Hie, Minister of Culture and Information, said that North Korean soldiers were responsible for a ''grave violation'' of the armistice that was signed at Panmunjom in 1953, ending the Korean War.
lead_paragraph: United States and North Korean military officers met today in the Korean demilitarized zone and blamed each other for the exchange of gunfire at Panmunjom on Friday that left four soldiers dead and as many as six others wounded.

abstract: Evidence introduced in lawsuits filed in connection with the Soviet downing of Korean Air Lines Flight 007 suggests that American radar operators knew hours beforehand that the jetliner was off course and heading into Soviet airspace.   The words, ''We should warn him,'' presumably referring to the plane's pilot, were heard at the Government's civil air-traffic control station in Alaska as the Boeing 747 strayed off course toward its fatal encounter with a Soviet fighter plane two years ago today, according to the documents.   The documents were submitted Friday as evidence in damage suits filed against the United States Government by relatives of the 269 people who died in the incident.   The official United States position has been that no one knew the Korean airliner was veering hundred of miles from its prescribed route and that therefore no warning could have been considered.
lead_paragraph: Evidence introduced in lawsuits filed in connection with the Soviet downing of Korean Air Lines Flight 007 suggests that American radar operators knew hours beforehand that the jetliner was off course and heading into Soviet airspace.

abstract: North Korea renewed a lapsed nongovernmental agreement today that allows small Japanese fishing vessels to use its 200- mile offshore economic zone freely for the first time in more than two years.   The expiration of the accord in 1982 had been a serious blow to the dozen or so Japanese ports along the Japan Sea coast that depend on the area off North Korea for their catch.
lead_paragraph: North Korea renewed a lapsed nongovernmental agreement today that allows small Japanese fishing vessels to use its 200- mile offshore economic zone freely for the first time in more than two years.

abstract: China, embarrassed by the first successful hijacking of one of its civil airliners, today dispatched an official delegation for discussions with authorities in South Korea on the return of the hijackers as well as the plane, its crew and passengers.   Shen Tu, the director of the China's Civil Aviation Administration, left for Seoul with the delegation at 8 A.M. aboard a special plane.  It will be the first such face-to-face meeting between the Chinese and the South Koreans, who were enemies in the Korean War. The two countries still do not have diplomatic relations, since Peking recognizes only North Korea, but they have quietly conducted trade through Hong Kong and other Asian countries.
lead_paragraph: China, embarrassed by the first successful hijacking of one of its civil airliners, today dispatched an official delegation for discussions with authorities in South Korea on the return of the hijackers as well as the plane, its crew and passengers.

abstract: The Prime Minister of Japan told South Korea's President Friday that efforts must be made to end North Korea's ''isolation'' if there is to be stability on the Korean peninsula.    The Prime Minister, Yasuhiro Nakasone, offered no specific proposals in his remarks to President Chun Doo Hwan, and Japanese Government officials emphasized that his comments did not signal a Japanese shift away from basic support for South Korean diplomatic positions.   Japan has some economic ties but no formal relations with the North Korean Government in Pyongyang. Mr. Nakasone reportedly said there was ''no reason why this policy should change unless there is a major change in the international situation.''   Nevertheless, any reference to possible fresh initiatives to North Korea - no matter how thickly veiled - is enough to raise concern among South Korean officials. Mr. Chun, who met with Mr. Nakasone for an hour Friday morning, was said to have called on Japan to act ''prudently and cautiously'' in dealing with Pyongyang.
lead_paragraph: The Prime Minister of Japan told South Korea's President Friday that efforts must be made to end North Korea's ''isolation'' if there is to be stability on the Korean peninsula.

abstract: President Reagan, ending a two- day visit to this country, pledged ''steadfast support'' today for South Korea and said he would strengthen the United States forces stationed here.    Mr. Reagan, in a joint statement with President Chun Doo Hwan, called Northeast Asia a ''region of critical strategic significance'' and said the United States would meet its ''responsibilities as a Pacific power.'' The statement was issued this morning shortly before Mr. Reagan took off for Washington after a seven-day trip to Japan and South Korea.   Speaking with reporters Sunday night, Secretary of State George P. Shultz said there were no plans to add to the 40,000 American soldiers based in South Korea.
lead_paragraph: President Reagan, ending a two- day visit to this country, pledged ''steadfast support'' today for South Korea and said he would strengthen the United States forces stationed here.

abstract: DURING his 18 years as a Buddhist monk, Kim Yon Shik grew into an ardent fan of temple cooking, the distinctive cuisine based upon fresh vegetables gathered in the country's woods and mountains. And when, at the age of 32, he left the monastery in which he had lived since he was 14, he decided that this cuisine deserved a wider audience.   The result is Sanchon, an attractive restaurant offering temple fare for lunch and dinner with nightly samples of Korean dance and music.   Temple cuisine grew out of Korean religious history, Mr. Kim said. During the Yi Dynasty (from 1392 to 1910), Confucianism edged out Buddhism as the predominant religion in Korea, and Buddhist monks were ousted and forced to live in remote mountains. Without much money, Mr. Kim said, monks had to forage for their meals, and they discovered many wild, edible plants.
lead_paragraph: DURING his 18 years as a Buddhist monk, Kim Yon Shik grew into an ardent fan of temple cooking, the distinctive cuisine based upon fresh vegetables gathered in the country's woods and mountains. abstract: A car called the Excel is to go on sale in the United States for the first time Thursday morning. It is an unremarkable looking vehicle, resembling many of the small, efficient Japanese cars that have wrested a large share of the market from the domestic Big Three.   The Excel, though, is not from Japan. It is being imported from Korea, where its manufacturer, the Hyundai Corporation, is one of the nation's leading manufacturing groups. The Hyundai Excel is the first of what could be a torrent of small cars made in Korea and other Asian countries headed for American shores.
lead_paragraph: A car called the Excel is to go on sale in the United States for the first time Thursday morning. It is an unremarkable looking vehicle, resembling many of the small, efficient Japanese cars that have wrested a large share of the market from the domestic Big Three.

abstract: South Korea is seeking $10 billion in aid and loans from Japan over a five-year period starting in 1982, according to South Korean officials here.   The request is unlikely to be fully met, Japanese officials say, but Tokyo will consider a major increase in aid or loans and is sending a group of senior officials to Seoul today for what are expected to be talks on economic matters.   The Tokyo response is apparently an attempt to reestablish close relations with Seoul after a period of confusion that followed the murder of Park Chung Hee, the South Korean President, in October 1979.
lead_paragraph: South Korea is seeking $10 billion in aid and loans from Japan over a five-year period starting in 1982, according to South Korean officials here.

abstract: LEAD: FOR all the drama and talk of political miracles, democracy did not come to South Korea last week. Nor is it likely to come next week or the week after. abstract: MODERN dance and the traditional were blended with an usual smoothness on Thursday when The Korean Contemporary Dance Company appeared in its New York debut at the New York University Theater, Most impressively, neither the new nor the old lost any inherent vitality, though thier combination had an integrity of its own.   That theme was clearly stated in the program's opening dance, ''Invocation for the Daed Spirit,'' a solo created and performed by Myungsook Park to traditional-sounding music by Young Dong Kim. Miss Park maintained the centered stilness of traditional Korean dance lunging slowly with the kind of expressive focus, attack and us of stage space most commonly to be seen in modern dance.
