abstract: The police checkpoints that had encircled Kim Dae Jung's house only a few weeks ago are gone. Street advertisements for a magazine carry his picture along with that of another leading dissident politician, Kim Young Sam.   Both men assume they are still followed by the police, and Kim Dae Jung remains barred from open political activity because he is under suspended sentence for a 1980 conviction on sedition charges. Still, he acknowledges, he has come a long way back for someone whose photographs were forbidden and who had treated as virtually a nonperson for five years.

abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, arriving here for a 24-hour visit, said today that the Reagan Administration strongly supported the South Korean Government's efforts to make changes and assailed those in the opposition who ''incite violence.''   At the same time, the Secretary, who is to meet Thursday with a cross-section of Koreans, declined to meet with Kim Dae Jung and Kim Young Sam, two of South Korea's most prominent political figues.   Mr. Shultz seemed to go out of his way not to indicate any lessening of Washington's backing for President Chun Doo Hwan. Ties to U.S. Stressed    The reasoning for this strategy, American officials said, is that Washington believes it is important for stability here for the Chun Government to carry out its stated intention to carry out a peaceful democratic power transfer in two years.   They said Washington believed that the Seoul Government, which has been accused of human rights abuses, and of trying to limit the opposition's ability to present its views, will only move ahead if it feels secure in its military, economic and political ties to the United States.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, arriving here for a 24-hour visit, said today that the Reagan Administration strongly supported the South Korean Government's efforts to make changes and assailed those in the opposition who ''incite violence.''

abstract: LEAD: AS Roh Tae Woo, the man almost certain to be South Korea's next President, was talking about his desire for political reconciliation at a news conference last week, members of his ruling party sat behind him, coughing and dabbing their eyes with handkerchiefs. Unexpectedly, they had taken in nasty gulps of tear-gas fumes that clung to the clothing of reporters and photographers.

abstract:
ONLY in America -- maybe only in Bergen County -- is there likely to be a high-quality restaurant atop a valet parking lot that serves both authentic Korean and Japanese fare and is busy enough to be open 24 hours a day. Where else would you be able to pull in at 3 A.M. and be served a pan-Asian combination of tekkamaki, the Japanese tuna rolls, from a sushi bar and Korea's famous beef dish, bulgogi, with a side of kimchi?

Yea Jeon, which is Korean for Olden Times, was opened just off Main Street in Fort Lee a few months ago by Chang Soon Park, a chef with some 40 years of experience, in the former premises of Kiku, a Japanese steakhouse. Most of the cooking tried on recent visits was first rate; only a couple of Japanese dishes fell short, like the greasy tempura with its heavy batter.

abstract: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea today commuted the death sentences of two men convicted of setting fire to a United States cultural center last March, killing a student and injuring three others.   A Presidential spokesman announced in Seoul, the South Korean capital, that the two defendants - Moon Bu Shik, a 23-year-old theology student, and Kim Hyon Jang, 32, a lay worker at a Roman Catholic education center - would now serve life sentences in prison.    The President's action followed quiet appeals for mercy from the United States Government and a public campaign led by South Korea's National Council of Churches, a Protestant group, and the Catholic Church. Both American and church officials were said to fear that if the two men were put to death, violent protests might erupt at the nation's universities in the spring.
lead_paragraph: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea today commuted the death sentences of two men convicted of setting fire to a United States cultural center last March, killing a student and injuring three others.

abstract: Up in the hills to the north of this city, at the back of a narrow valley, lies the tomb of a 14th-century king, Guang Min, where the only sounds are those of cuckoos. Along the valley floor, and in flatter country to the south and east, travelers drive for miles between emerald-green rice paddies tended by weathered peasants. Here, a few miles north of the demilitarized zone, visitors are offered an extended look at rural life. After a lull of several years, this tightly sealed country is opening its doors to American journalists. The message is one of peace and reconciliation. In this area where war between North and South Korea would start, almost the only soldiers in sight have rolled up their pants to work alongside the peasants.   In Pyongyang, a capital of monumental buildings and sweeping avenues to delight any Stalinist's eye, spokesmen for the Government of Kim Il Sung speak in magnanimous terms of the war that devastated the country more than 30 years ago. Official publications continue to say that it was the South and ''U.S. imperialist aggressors'' who precipitated the war, but in the carpeted grandeur of vast meeting halls, polemics are set aside for arguments judged more likely to interest Westerners.
lead_paragraph: Up in the hills to the north of this city, at the back of a narrow valley, lies the tomb of a 14th-century king, Guang Min, where the only sounds are those of cuckoos. Along the valley floor, and in flatter country to the south and east, travelers drive for miles between emerald-green rice paddies tended by weathered peasants. Here, a few miles north of the demilitarized zone, visitors are offered an extended look at rural life. After a lull of several years, this tightly sealed country is opening its doors to American journalists. The message is one of peace and reconciliation. In this area where war between North and South Korea would start, almost the only soldiers in sight have rolled up their pants to work alongside the peasants.

abstract: Shortly after 7:30 P.M. last Wednesday, Korea's Ambassador to the United States, Lew Byong Hion, arrived at his home off Massachusetts Avenue, unlocked the door and heard the telephone ringing. It was an official of the Foreign Ministry in Seoul.   ''He asked if I had heard anything about the plane, any news or information,'' Mr. Lew recalled today. ''I began checking all over. None of the U.S. agencies knew anything yet. Then we started to get calls from journalists.''

abstract: Although nations have complete control of the airspace over their land and territorial waters, they may shoot down intruders during peacetime under only the most extraordinary circumstances, authorities on international law said yesterday.    uf813 Whether the Soviet Union violated international law and custom by shooting down a Korean Air Lines jet, as Secretary of State George P. Shultz said it had, may ultimately depend, however, on facts that are still in dispute - particularly whether the Soviet jets issued warnings to the South Korean plane and whether those warnings were ignored by the Korean pilot.     ''Shooting down a civilian passenger plane without warning is clearly contrary to international law,'' said Oliver J. Lissitzyn, professor emeritus of international law and diplomacy at Columbia Law School. ''But if a warning was given to land and the South Koreans disobeyed that order, then the matter becomes much more controversial.''
lead_paragraph: Although nations have complete control of the airspace over their land and territorial waters, they may shoot down intruders during peacetime under only the most extraordinary circumstances, authorities on international law said yesterday.

abstract: South Korea continued tonight to hold a Chinese torpedo boat that drifted into its waters with six dead crew members, killed in what some reports described as a mutiny after some crewmen tried to defect.    The South Korean Government made no direct response to a Chinese request for the return of the naval vessel and its crew ''as soon as possible.''    (China and South Korea were reportedly holding talks on the return of the boat and crew through officials they maintain in Hong Kong.)         2 Reportedly in Hospital    Two crew members, reportedly shot but not critically wounded, were in a hospital in the South Korean port of Kunsan, on the Yellow Sea. A total of 10 or 11 other crewmen were also believed to have been taken to Kunsan, but their whereabouts could not be determined. Their boat was apparently offshore.
lead_paragraph: South Korea continued tonight to hold a Chinese torpedo boat that drifted into its waters with six dead crew members, killed in what some reports described as a mutiny after some crewmen tried to defect.

abstract: Kim Dae Jung, the South Korean political dissident, said today that he believed most South Koreans felt betrayed by the United States. He asserted the United States had failed to demand a return to democratic government in his country.   Mr. Kim, who arrived here from Seoul last Thursday, spoke in an interview at a small Roman Catholic retreat center in a Virginia suburb of Washington. He was ''very grateful'' that Americans had welcomed him to this country.

abstract: Kim Il Sung, the North Korean leader, is preparing a lavish celebration of his 70th birthday next month to pave the way for his son's succession to the leadership, according to South Korean intelligence sources.   Mr. Kim, who has led North Korea since 1945, has already delegated much authority to his 40-year-old son, Kim Chong Il, the intelligence sources said. The high point of the mammoth birthday ceremony on April 15, they said, will be the public appearance of the son at his father's side in front of an audience of 100,000 that will include dignitaries from China, the Soviet Union and the third world.   ''Almost the entire North Korean Cabinet is in orbit right now,'' said a spokesman for the South Korean Agency for National Security Planning, an intelligence group. ''They are traveling in Africa, Central and Latin America and elsewhere, seeking to drum up support.'' The sources said that the ministers were offering to charter aircraft to bring guests to Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, if they could not otherwise afford to travel.
lead_paragraph: Kim Il Sung, the North Korean leader, is preparing a lavish celebration of his 70th birthday next month to pave the way for his son's succession to the leadership, according to South Korean intelligence sources.

abstract: Along a worn concrete road gone to weeds, hundreds of North Korean trucks entered South Korean territory today carrying the first supplies to pass between the two countries since the Korean War ended 31 years ago.     The North Koreans drove in convoys through the truce camp of Panmunjom and continued for nearly a mile to the farm hamlet of Taesongdong, created by South Korea as a showcase in the demilitarized zone. There, 370 open trucks dropped off tons of rice, medicine and cloth that the North had volunteered as relief aid to victims of recent floods in the South.    Northern sincerity in making the offer could only be guessed at.
lead_paragraph: Along a worn concrete road gone to weeds, hundreds of North Korean trucks entered South Korean territory today carrying the first supplies to pass between the two countries since the Korean War ended 31 years ago.

abstract: The Defense Department announced today that the search had been called off for wreckage of the Korean Air Lines 747 shot down over the Sea of Japan Sept. 1 by a Soviet fighter plane.   The search, which had been conducted by United States and Japanese ships that were trailing bottom-scanning devices, was aimed mainly at recovering the airliner's flight recording boxes. But the only thing ever turned up was an old cooking pot lost long ago by some seagoing ship.   ''We've looked everywhere we think it might be and we haven't found a thing,'' a Pentagon spokesman said this afternoon. ''Maybe it's lying within Russian waters. But that's another thing. They won't let us in.''
lead_paragraph: The Defense Department announced today that the search had been called off for wreckage of the Korean Air Lines 747 shot down over the Sea of Japan Sept. 1 by a Soviet fighter plane.

abstract: The Soviet Union handed over to United States and Japanese authorities today five wooden boxes containing debris from the South Korean plane shot down by a Soviet fighter on Sept. 1.   No bodies were said to have been included in the transfer, nor any sensitive material such as the in-flight data and voice-recording systems that United States and Soviet ships are searching for in the northern Sea of Japan. All 269 people aboard the Korean plane were killed.   Most of the 76 items handed over today appeared to be similar to wreckage from Korean Air Lines flight 007 that has been floating ashore along the northern rim of the Japanese island of Hokkaido. Soviet officials told the Americans and Japanese that all the debris had been found in the water or washed up on two Soviet-controlled islands north of Japan - Sakhalin Island and the small Moneron Island, 30 miles to the southwest.
lead_paragraph: The Soviet Union handed over to United States and Japanese authorities today five wooden boxes containing debris from the South Korean plane shot down by a Soviet fighter on Sept. 1.

abstract: WHAT promises to be one of the most charming programs of the season took place on Friday at Town Hall, when Pungmul Nori Madang presented an evening of Korean folk music and dance. Neither the music nor the dance was entirely unfamiliar, but the program stood out for the amiable high spirits that matched the performers' impressive technique.   Presented by an ensemble of six young men now on tour in the United States, the program began with a traditional prayer and donations of money from some audience members, who knelt on the stage before a small table stacked with rice cakes, which were later distributed to the audience, and drank from bowls of peasant wine. A musical segment followed, with pieces that displayed the drumming styles of four provinces of South Korea. The music, played by seated musicians on a variety of drums and gongs, was tremendously exciting, with quick-changing rhythms and shifting dynamics that built to shimmering, gut-crunching loudness and subsided to a deep, almost breathing sonority.
lead_paragraph: WHAT promises to be one of the most charming programs of the season took place on Friday at Town Hall, when Pungmul Nori Madang presented an evening of Korean folk music and dance. Neither the music nor the dance was entirely unfamiliar, but the program stood out for the amiable high spirits that matched the performers' impressive technique.

abstract:
IT was the classified advertisement seeking ''Veterans of the

 Korean War'' that caught my

eye. Having survived some of the battles of the war, I replied; soon I received an invitation from the Korean Veterans Association for an all- expense-paid trip, except airfare, to the country in whose defense I had fought three decades earlier. With other ex-G.I.'s and their wives from around the nation, including two others from the county, I made the trip.


I remember the moment. July 27, 1953, at 10 P.M.

All fighting stopped across the front lines of Korea.

abstract: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea replaced his Prime Minister and three other ministers today.  The new Prime Minister, Kim Sang Hyup, 62 years old, is a Japanese-educated law professor and head of Korea University in Seoul. He served once before in the Cabinet, as Education Minister for eight months in 1962.

abstract: At least 19 people, including two leading advisers to President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea and four of his Cabinet ministers, were killed Sunday when a bomb exploded as they prepared for a wreath-laying ceremony in Rangoon, Burma. Forty-seven people were wounded, many seriously.    President Chun, who was on an official visit to Burma, escaped harm because his car was delayed in traffic. He arrived five minutes late at the site of the ceremony.    By this morning no group had taken responsibility for the bombing. But President Chun blamed North Korea after returning to Seoul early this morning, cutting short what was to have been an 18-day trip to six Asian and Pacific countries. He arrived in Rangoon from Seoul on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: At least 19 people, including two leading advisers to President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea and four of his Cabinet ministers, were killed Sunday when a bomb exploded as they prepared for a wreath-laying ceremony in Rangoon, Burma. Forty-seven people were wounded, many seriously.

abstract: A couple who are leading figures in the South Koean movie world and who disappeared into North Korea under mysterious circumstances eight years ago emerged here today and said they had been kidnapped on the direct orders of the son of President Kim Il Sung of North Korea.   The couple, Shin San Ok, a director, and Choi Un Hui, an actress, met with two reporters here and told a story that they found more bizarre than any screenplay.   They said Kim Il Sung's son, Kim Jong Il, who is widely regarded as the most important Communist Party official in North Korea today and the likely successor to his father, was a movie buff, with a personal collection of 20,000 films. The elder Mr. Kim is both head of the Government and the party.   ''Kim Jong Il told us later he had ordered our kidnapping,'' Mr. Shin said. The four-and-a-half hour interview was conducted through an interpreter, with Mr. Shin occasionally using English.
lead_paragraph: A couple who are leading figures in the South Koean movie world and who disappeared into North Korea under mysterious circumstances eight years ago emerged here today and said they had been kidnapped on the direct orders of the son of President Kim Il Sung of North Korea.

abstract: Senior Reagan Administration officials said today that, two hours before shooting down a South Korean airliner off its coast, the Soviet Union spotted a United States reconnaissance plane in the general area and apparently thought that both aircraft were American reconnaissance planes.   But White House and State Department officials insisted that whatever initial confusion might have existed, the reconnaissance plane, an RC-135, was 1,000 miles from the scene of the shooting down of the South Korean 747 jetliner. They said the Soviet military had had ample time to discern that the plane they tracked into their airspace was a commercial jetliner. The Administration continued to maintain that there was no way the Russians could have mistaken the identity of the plane at the time they shot it down.   Both The Associated Press and United Press International quoted Administration officials as saying that at one stage the reconnaissance plane had come within 75 miles of the Korean airliner.
lead_paragraph: Senior Reagan Administration officials said today that, two hours before shooting down a South Korean airliner off its coast, the Soviet Union spotted a United States reconnaissance plane in the general area and apparently thought that both aircraft were American reconnaissance planes.

abstract: A South Korean pilot who took off behind Korean Air Lines Flight 007 on its flight into Soviet airspace in 1983 believes that an airline policy of punishing crew errors deterred the crew from turning back and led to the plane's being shot down, according to an article published in Seoul.   Concern for loss of face could also have been a factor, the article suggests on the basis of interviews with the pilot, Capt. Y. M. Park, and other pilots from the airline.   Captain Park, now retired, is quoted as saying that he radioed the pilot of the doomed plane to ask why his flight was slipping behind schedule.   The answer from the pilot of Flight 007, Capt. S. I. Chun, was, ''The wind is strong.'' This indicated to Captain Park that something was not right aboard, the article says.
lead_paragraph: A South Korean pilot who took off behind Korean Air Lines Flight 007 on its flight into Soviet airspace in 1983 believes that an airline policy of punishing crew errors deterred the crew from turning back and led to the plane's being shot down, according to an article published in Seoul.

abstract: Only a few days after President Reagan's departure after a six-day visit, China has turned its attention to its northern Communist neighbors.   The Chinese Communist Party leader Hu Yaobang, whom Mr. Reagan saw last Friday, arrived today in North Korea on an official visit and was met at Pyongyong's railway station by the North Korean leader Kim Il Sung.   In mid-May the Chinese will also receive First Deputy Prime Minister Ivan V. Arkhipov, the highest-ranking Soviet visitor in 15 years.   Both visits were expected and have no direct connection with Mr. Reagan's visit to China. But they underscore the extent to which China is trying to balance official contacts between Western and Communist countries.
lead_paragraph: Only a few days after President Reagan's departure after a six-day visit, China has turned its attention to its northern Communist neighbors.

abstract: The South Korean Government announced the release today of more than 1,000 prisoners, mostly common criminals and juvenile offenders, in an amnesty to mark the 36th anniversary of Korea's liberation from Japan in 1945.   ''Those who repent and are judged capable of taking part in shaping the new era'' under President Chun Doo Hwan were being progressively released from prison in amnesties, an official statement said.   Those benefiting from this third amnesty in 1981 include 834 prisoners released on parole after sentencing on charges ranging from murder to robbery, 158 juveniles and 72 mainly political offenders, the Government said.
lead_paragraph: The South Korean Government announced the release today of more than 1,000 prisoners, mostly common criminals and juvenile offenders, in an amnesty to mark the 36th anniversary of Korea's liberation from Japan in 1945.

abstract: For the first time since he took power nearly two years ago, President Chun Doo Hwan is facing some organized opposition.   It comes from Christian dissidents who played an important role in creating the climate of unrest in which his predecessor, Park Chung Hee, was slain in 1979 by the chief of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency.   Mr. Chun's hold on power appears to be secure, but he is responding warily to requests by the Christian dissidents for small, new prerogatives.   Recently, at talks with church leaders, he agreed to allow prayer meetings to be resumed at the headquarters of the Korean National Council of Churches, once a center of resistance to Mr. Park. Such meetings had been banned there since 1979. But President Chun permitted only biweekly meetings, not the weekly sessions that had been requested.
lead_paragraph: For the first time since he took power nearly two years ago, President Chun Doo Hwan is facing some organized opposition.

abstract: Sang Chun stood among nearly 100 Korean greengrocers at the Hunts Point Market in the Bronx earlier this week and waved a crumpled pink summons at the city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs.     ''I came because this is the land of opportunity, but I receive tickets almost daily,'' he said through a translator. ''The inspectors come with no warning, they fine for what I do not think I did wrong. I wonder if I should just pack up and leave and go home.''

abstract: Oh Se Eung, fighting for his political life, walked down the main street, shook hands with the Mayor and greeted several hundred other citizens of this town in the hazy valleys some 20 miles southeast of Seoul.   He handed flowers to women, patted babies strapped by brightly colored blankets to their mothers' backs, made promises, criticized his opponents and otherwise acted in ways many American voters would find familiar.   Like 633 other South Koreans, Mr. Oh, 46 years old, is running as a candidate in the election next Wednesday for the country's new National Assembly. There are 194 seats in 92 electoral districts at stake in the balloting.
lead_paragraph: Oh Se Eung, fighting for his political life, walked down the main street, shook hands with the Mayor and greeted several hundred other citizens of this town in the hazy valleys some 20 miles southeast of Seoul.

abstract: Former marines who survived the costly withdrawal from the Chosin Reservoir in North Korea held their first national reunion in 35 years last week, to remember lost buddies and meet a new generation of marines.   Membership in the group is limited. A man had to have been at the reservoir in November 1950 when 120,000 Chinese soldiers invaded and to have survived a withdrawal in subzero weather.
lead_paragraph: Former marines who survived the costly withdrawal from the Chosin Reservoir in North Korea held their first national reunion in 35 years last week, to remember lost buddies and meet a new generation of marines.

abstract: Pong Ok Jang stocked the front of his small grocery the usual way yesterday: a little before 8 A.M. he and other workers cranked up the store's metal gate and hauled crates of fresh apples, tomatoes and plantains to the sidewalk.   The day after he was acquitted of assaulting a black customer, Mr. Pong, who is Korean and the manager of the store, opened it with a renewed hope that more people would begin to shop there. He said he hoped his acquittal would end the long boycott of the store that had whipped up tensions between blacks and Asian-Americans in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn and almost destroyed the business.
lead_paragraph: Pong Ok Jang stocked the front of his small grocery the usual way yesterday: a little before 8 A.M. he and other workers cranked up the store's metal gate and hauled crates of fresh apples, tomatoes and plantains to the sidewalk.

abstract: President Chun Doo Hwan, completing his first year as head of state under South Korea's new Fifth Republic, appears to have won the confidence of his allies abroad and much of the military and business elite at home.   After taking office on March 3, 1981, and making a slow start marked by discord and official repression, Mr. Chun, a former army general, has injected a sense of vigor into his administration, and the economy is reviving after a bad spell. He has emerged as a rival to Kim Il Sung, the North Korean President, on the emotional issue of Korean reunification and, in consequence, as a forceful leader in the Korean peninsula.   Meanwhile, he has apparently persuaded a reluctant Japanese Government to grant him several billion dollars in long-term credits. His quest for international acceptance received further impetus from the International Olympic Committee's surprise decision to bestow the l988 Olympic Games on Seoul and not on the Japanese city of Nagoya, which fully expected the games.
lead_paragraph: President Chun Doo Hwan, completing his first year as head of state under South Korea's new Fifth Republic, appears to have won the confidence of his allies abroad and much of the military and business elite at home.

abstract: South Koreans voted yesterday for members of an electoral college that later this month will give President Chun Doo Hwan a full seven-year term.   About 16 million voters, or 78 percent of those eligible, cast ballots for candidates aligned with President Chun's Democratic Justice Party or three other new parties. Each of the four parties submitted a slate of candidates for President and the 5,278-member electoral college.

abstract: The South Korean Government said today that it would not send the opposition leader Kim Dae Jung back to prison when he returns home Friday from two years of exile in the United States.   ''It is the policy of the Government not to return him to prison when he returns,'' a Government spokesman said in a terse announcement.    ''In December 1982 Kim petitioned to go to the U.S. for medical treatment, and the Government conditionally released him and granted his petition on humanitarian grounds,'' the announcement said.
lead_paragraph: The South Korean Government said today that it would not send the opposition leader Kim Dae Jung back to prison when he returns home Friday from two years of exile in the United States.

abstract: Kim Dae Jung, South Korea's leading dissident politician, was confined to his house here today as a dispute swelled over a roughing-up that he and supporters suffered at the hands of the police when he returned home from exile in the United States.     Two United States Representatives and two other Americans who accompanied Mr. Kim said officers beat them as they left the airplane that brought them to Seoul this morning from Narita, Japan.   They walked off the plane arm- in-arm, they said, but a squad of policemen rushed in to separate them. Several of them said later that they and Mr. Kim had been punched and kicked and that one of them, possibly two, had been hurled to the ground.
lead_paragraph: Kim Dae Jung, South Korea's leading dissident politician, was confined to his house here today as a dispute swelled over a roughing-up that he and supporters suffered at the hands of the police when he returned home from exile in the United States.

abstract: A year after the civil insurrection in Kwangju and despite recent minor demonstrations, President Chun Doo Hwan appears to have consolidated his grip on power, according to Western diplomats.   As a result, the diplomats said, South Korea and its 38 million people should enjoy a period of comparative calm and stability.  Government officials said that Mr. Chun and his supporters have begun capitalizing on this and devoting their efforts mainly to the country's economic performance.   ''The only sector they have to worry about now is the economy,'' a Western diplomat said, adding that political opponents, religious dissidents and student militants ''are having trouble getting people to do much.''
lead_paragraph: A year after the civil insurrection in Kwangju and despite recent minor demonstrations, President Chun Doo Hwan appears to have consolidated his grip on power, according to Western diplomats.

abstract: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's speech in Washington last night, as recorded by The New York Times:    My fellow Americans, I'm coming before you tonight about the Korean Air Line massacre - the attack by the Soviet Union against 269 innocent men, women and children aboard an unarmed Korean passenger plane. This crime against humanity must never be forgotten, here or throughout the world.   Our prayers tonight are with the victims and their families in their time of terrible grief. Our hearts go out to them - to brave people like Kathryn McDonald, the wife of a Congressman whose composure and eloquence on the day of her husband's death moved us all. He will be sorely missed by all of us here in government.   The parents of one slain couple wired me: ''Our daughter and her husband died on Korean Air Line Flight 7; their deaths were the result of the Soviet Union violating every concept of human rights.''

abstract: The culture and traditions of another land and other times were the wellspring for the compelling modern dance presented by the Myung-Ok Han Dance Company on Friday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater. The program began with an early-19th-century Korean court-dance solo, "Choon Aeng Jeon," a dance of stately measure with small eddyings of activity like the opening up and out of the arms and the dipping of the torso. It was performed in traditional dress to traditional music by Ms. Han, whose furrowed brow suggested the solo might be something of a labor of love for her.    There was no such distraction in Ms. Han's new "Rising Sun," set to a haunting score by Kitaro. An intense, richly textured solo for herself, the dance looked like an artistic statement of belief. It was also a fascinating study in building and changing dynamics.
lead_paragraph: The culture and traditions of another land and other times were the wellspring for the compelling modern dance presented by the Myung-Ok Han Dance Company on Friday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater. The program began with an early-19th-century Korean court-dance solo, "Choon Aeng Jeon," a dance of stately measure with small eddyings of activity like the opening up and out of the arms and the dipping of the torso. It was performed in traditional dress to traditional music by Ms. Han, whose furrowed brow suggested the solo might be something of a labor of love for her.

abstract: Following is a transcript of an address yesterday by Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, to the Security Council, as recorded by The New York Times:      Following is a transcript of an address yesterday by Jeane J.  Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, to the Security Council, as recorded by The New York Times:     Thank you, Mr. President.   Most of the world outside the Soviet Union has heard by now of the Korean Flight 7, carrying 269 persons between New York and Seoul, which strayed off course into Soviet airspace, was tracked by Soviet radar, was targeted by a Soviet SU-15 whose pilot cooly and after careful consideration fired two air-launched missiles which destroyed the Korean airliner and apparently its 269 passengers and crew.   This calculated attack on a civilian airliner - unarmed, undefended, as civilian airliners always are - has shocked the world.   Only the Soviet people have still not heard about this attack on the K.A.L. 7 and the death of the passengers, because the Soviet Government has not acknowledged firing on the Korean airliner. Indeed, not until Sept. 5 did Soviet officials acknowledge publicly that K.A.L. 7 had disappeared in its icy waters.
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of an address yesterday by Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, to the Security Council, as recorded by The New York Times:

abstract: The Soviet Union shot down a South Korean airliner at a time when American intelligence had a vast array of listening devices directed at that area of East Asia, including installations in Japan unknown to the Japanese Government, according to a new book.   The book, ''The Target Is Destroyed,'' says intercepted communications gathered by these listening devices were not available to intelligence officials until hours and days after the attack on Sept. 1, 1983, too late to save the lives of the 269 people aboard the airliner. The plane had strayed hundreds of miles off course and into Soviet airspace, where it flew over sensitive military installations.   The book, by Seymour M. Hersh, is based on two years of research and includes interviews in the United States, the Soviet Union and Japan. Soviet officials are quoted as saying they spoke with Mr. Hersh because they wanted him to prove that the plane's off-course flight path was part of an intelligence mission for the United States.
lead_paragraph: The Soviet Union shot down a South Korean airliner at a time when American intelligence had a vast array of listening devices directed at that area of East Asia, including installations in Japan unknown to the Japanese Government, according to a new book.

abstract: BY now many people assume that even if the label in front is that of an American company, the innards of a computer are manufactured in the Far East. Although Japan has yet to make inroads on the sales of whole personal computers  under its own brand names, the country is a recognized master of all the components, from disk drives to memory chips. It is also on the leading edge of  such newer technologies as compact disk memory, which essentially involves converting the more familiar musical version of the entity into something to which a computer can listen.         Japanese goods, however, are becoming expensive, even considering the strong  dollar. In the personal computer marketplace, where a recent ''They will buy anything'' euphoria has suddenly been replaced by a cost consciousness, the trade finds itself desperately searching for less-expensive suppliers.
lead_paragraph: BY now many people assume that even if the label in front is that of an American company, the innards of a computer are manufactured in the Far East. abstract: A drinking party among friends in the city of Taejon last January started out innocently enough. But after things deteriorated into a drunken brawl, the police were called in and the result was a scandal that has shaken people across the nation.   In the last month, it was revealed that the party included several gangsters, politicians, army security officers, judges and prosecutors. For Koreans, it was a rare glimpse into the cozy relationship of criminals and the people who are supposed to protect society from them.
lead_paragraph: A drinking party among friends in the city of Taejon last January started out innocently enough. But after things deteriorated into a drunken brawl, the police were called in and the result was a scandal that has shaken people across the nation.

abstract: Ambassador Richard Walker of the United States said today that Washington would continue discussions with China, and possibly the Soviet Union, to bring about a dialogue between North and South Korea.   ''We are committed to the de-escalation of tensions on this tragically divided peninsula and to its reunification through peaceful means,'' he said in an interview with The Korea Herald.   He said the United States supported efforts by President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea to reopen negotiations with North Korea, discontinued since the early 1970's.
lead_paragraph: Ambassador Richard Walker of the United States said today that Washington would continue discussions with China, and possibly the Soviet Union, to bring about a dialogue between North and South Korea.

abstract: North Korea has joined the 1968 nuclear nonproliferation treaty, Reagan Administration officials said today.   The move by North Korea was described by Government officials and private experts as an important development in efforts to prevent the spread of the ability to make nuclear weapons to the Korean peninsula.   North Korea formally acceded to the treaty in Moscow on Dec. 12. The The Soviet Union informed the United States of the action on Dec. 19, a State Department official said.

abstract: Chun Doo Hwan, the former military leader of South Korea, is to end a period of voluntary internal exile on Sunday, his lawyer said today. abstract: The Chrysler Corporation and   the Samsung Industrial Group   have drawn opposition from   South Korean auto makers as   they work out details of a joint   auto-building agreement.  Executives of the two companies are holding meetings at   Chrysler headquarters in suburban Detroit on how to win the   South Korean Government's   approval for the venture, which   has been criticized by South   Korean auto makers, according to a Chrysler officer who requested anonymity. According to unidentified   Samsung officials quoted in the   South Korean press, the two   companies plan to build a $350   million assembly plant in   Changwon, south of Seoul.

abstract: North Korea today denied American charges that its forces fired a missile Wednesday at a United States SR-71 reconnaissance plane flying in what the Pentagon called ''South Korean and international airspace.''   But North Korea said nothing about whether such an attack had been made in what it defines as its own airspace.  Issuing its first direct statement on the incident, the official North Korean press agency charged that the SR-71 had violated ''the territorial air of the northern half of our republic,'' meaning North Korea. The statement did not elaborate.

abstract: A spurt of anti-Japanese protest has arisen in South Korea after the arrest of a Korean resident of Japan who refused to be fingerprinted for an identity card.   On Sunday, a man anonymously called the Japanese Consulate in the South Korean city of Pusan and threatened to blow up the building. Two days earlier, a caller to the Japanese Embassy in Seoul warned that he would kill all its officials.

abstract: After several turnabouts and unexpected moves, North and South Korea appeared today to have settled their differences on how the North could send relief supplies to flood victims in the South.     If the material is brought across the border between the two implacable enemies, it would be the first such exchange since before the Korean War.   But whether a delivery of goods would actually be made remained a question. The history of relations between the countries suggests a good possibility that fresh impediments will arise or that new details will emerge, requiring resolution and delaying final agreement.

abstract: More than 30 years after the Korean War ended, a Federal commission has suggested that the Government, instead of a private group, build a monument here to honor veterans of the war.   The American Battle Monuments Commission's recommendation to Congress has angered a private organization that was formed in 1981 and has already raised more than $400,000 for the project.   Michael Panayotopoulos, who said he was a paid consultant to the private group, the National Committee for the Korean War Memorial, said recently he considered the Federal panel's plans ''an affront, to say the least.''
lead_paragraph: More than 30 years after the Korean War ended, a Federal commission has suggested that the Government, instead of a private group, build a monument here to honor veterans of the war.

abstract:
The violence, anti- Americanism and polarization that have marked the rising tide against South Korea's military dictatorship ought to cause the United States to rethink its policies, which are as much a cause of this worrisome trend as is President Chun Doo Hwan.

Mr. Chun's opponents were recently buoyed by the prospect of support from Washington after the fall of the Marcos dictatorship in the Philippines. Their exuberance, however, died quickly, because the Administration has continued to back the South Korean dictatorship while shunning the democratic opposition. This shortsighted approach has only encouraged extremism, with students and workers urging increasingly radical responses. Moderates who have denounced violence, including Kim Dae Jung and Kim Young Sam, find themselves abandoned by the United States.

abstract: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea, assuring American business leaders that his country had overcome the political and economic turmoil of the last year, yesterday urged greater economic cooperation between the two nations.   The appeal for more American investment in South Korea, and trade with it, has been a major theme of Mr. Chun's two-day stopover in New York before he holds talks with President Reagan in Washington tomorrow. Mr. Chun said his Government was easing restrictions on foreign investment, a task he said would lead to a ''drastic improvement'' in its investment climate.
lead_paragraph: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea, assuring American business leaders that his country had overcome the political and economic turmoil of the last year, yesterday urged greater economic cooperation between the two nations.

abstract: North Korea reported today that its leader, Kim Il Sung, greeted a foreign group this morning. The report, also carried by the Chinese press agency, was apparently intended to dispel rumors that Mr. Kim had been killed.   But confusion over the fate of the North Korean leader persisted amid reports in South Korea that his Defense Minister had seized power.   The North Korean press agency said Mr. Kim had ''warmly met'' a visiting Mongolian delegation at the airport in Pyongyang and then joined his guests in reviewing a military honor guard. Thousands of people were on hand, the report said.
lead_paragraph: North Korea reported today that its leader, Kim Il Sung, greeted a foreign group this morning. The report, also carried by the Chinese press agency, was apparently intended to dispel rumors that Mr. Kim had been killed.

abstract: Flushing, Queens, isn't a spot that one normally thinks of as exotic, but Oriental food shops and Korean restaurants are sprouting there among the diners and the delis like cloud mushrooms after a heavy rain.   Flushing and another Queens neighborhood, Kew Gardens, have the heaviest concentrations of Koreans in New York City - community leaders put the number at 20,000. And in a city where, according to the latest census, 110,000 Koreans live, there is scarcely a neighborhood that does not now have a Korean greengrocer or fishmonger or dry cleaner.   The Koreans are among the city's most visible immigrants because of their remarkable emergence in small businesses. For these 110,000 people, their dreams and difficulties are part of the old, old story of immigrants to the United States.
lead_paragraph: Flushing, Queens, isn't a spot that one normally thinks of as exotic, but Oriental food shops and Korean restaurants are sprouting there among the diners and the delis like cloud mushrooms after a heavy rain.

abstract: Since his military takeover of the South Korean Government four years ago, President Chun Doo Hwan has endured a civil uprising that his soldiers suppressed with considerable loss of life, financial scandals touching his wife's family, hundreds of student protests and an assassination bombing in Burma that killed some of his closest aides. Anyone who could survive all that might be reasonably expected to prevail through anything.    But now Mr. Chun is taking what some think is a big risk. He is gambling that he can give South Koreans a touch more freedom than they are used to under him, and that not only will he not regret the decision, but perhaps he will emerge stronger than before.
lead_paragraph: Since his military takeover of the South Korean Government four years ago, President Chun Doo Hwan has endured a civil uprising that his soldiers suppressed with considerable loss of life, financial scandals touching his wife's family, hundreds of student protests and an assassination bombing in Burma that killed some of his closest aides. Anyone who could survive all that might be reasonably expected to prevail through anything.

abstract: In a carefully worded statement, the South Korean Embassy here said today that the Seoul Government was detaining more than 3,000 people under a law that permits the authorities to hold prisoners without trial and without charges.   The statement appeared to be intended to rebut reports here that South Korea is holding 15,000 people in forced-labor camps run by the army.   ''As of Sept. 20 the number held under the Social Protection Law was 3,228,'' said Cha Yun, a spokesman for the embassy. The statement did, however, confirm the existence of the camps, something Seoul had previously never acknowledged.
lead_paragraph: In a carefully worded statement, the South Korean Embassy here said today that the Seoul Government was detaining more than 3,000 people under a law that permits the authorities to hold prisoners without trial and without charges.

abstract: Kang Ryang Uk, one of North Korea's three vice presidents and chairman of the Central Committee of the Communist Party, has died at the age of 79, the official Korean Central News Agency reported today.   In a dispatch monitored in Tokyo, the agency said the veteran Communist died Sunday after a long bout with an unspecified illness.  Mr. Kang was described as a ''patriotic fighter and prominent political figure.''
lead_paragraph: Kang Ryang Uk, one of North Korea's three vice presidents and chairman of the Central Committee of the Communist Party, has died at the age of 79, the official Korean Central News Agency reported today.

abstract: A New Jersey soldier has been charged with murder for turning his M-16 rifle on five fellow G.I.'s, killing four of them and injuring the fifth at a rifle range in South Korea, military officials said today.   Army spokesmen said that the suspect, Specialist 4 Archie Bell 3d, of Long Branch, N.J., had been accused of four counts of murder and one count of attempted murder. They said that the 21-year-old soldier, an army generator mechanic assigned to South Korea only a month ago, was undergoing psychiatric tests at an Army hospital in Seoul.
lead_paragraph: A New Jersey soldier has been charged with murder for turning his M-16 rifle on five fellow G.I.'s, killing four of them and injuring the fifth at a rifle range in South Korea, military officials said today.

abstract: SEOUL South Korea, Monday, Feb 2 (Reuters) -- The United States and South Korea have begun the first joint military exercise since the inauguration of President Reagan, the Korean-United States Combined Forces Command said today.   The two-month exercise, named Team Spirit '81, is part of a series involving 161,500 troops of the Western alliance, including 33,800 American soldiers. About 100,000 members of South Korean Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Air Force are participating in the war games.  said Campy Russell, who scored 16 points.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL South Korea, Monday, Feb 2 (Reuters) -- The United States and South Korea have begun the first joint military exercise since the inauguration of President Reagan, the Korean-United States Combined Forces Command said today.

abstract: A new party of anti-Government politicians picked up surprisingly strong support and emerged today from general elections as South Korea's leading opposition group.    The ruling Democratic Justice Party, as expected, retained its majority in the National Assembly. But potentially the most significant result of Tuesday's legislative elections was the success of the New Korea Democratic Party, formed by opposition figures who only three months ago were banned from political life by President Chun Doo Hwan.    The new party's strong showing created a possibility that the fundamentally weak legislature could become a more vigorous political forum.
lead_paragraph: A new party of anti-Government politicians picked up surprisingly strong support and emerged today from general elections as South Korea's leading opposition group.

abstract: Documents released today give details on a decision by President Dwight D. Eisenhower's Administration in 1953 to use atomic bombs in North Korea and Communist China, if necessary, to end the Korean War.   Once the armistice was achieved, on July 27, 1953, the Eisenhower Administration continued to define plans to use nuclear weapons if the Communists renewed the war, which the North Koreans started in 1950.   President Eisenhower took office in January 1953 after talks for a cease-fire had dragged on for two years and the war had settled into a standoff, with casualties being incurred but with no change in the front line, which today still separates North and South Korea.   The fact that the Eisenhower Administration was ready to use nuclear weapons is not new. President Eisenhower, in his memoirs, said he came into office prepared to use them, if necessary, to break the deadlock. What is new in the 2,000 pages of documents now made public is the high level of planning and the detail of discussion on possible use of these weapons, and Mr. Eisenhower's interest in overcoming reluctance to use them.
lead_paragraph: Documents released today give details on a decision by President Dwight D. Eisenhower's Administration in 1953 to use atomic bombs in North Korea and Communist China, if necessary, to end the Korean War.

abstract: After 10 months in seclusion, a North Korean diplomat left his refuge at his country's mission today and surrendered to Westchester County authorities on a charge of sexual abuse.   The diplomat, O Nam Chol, pleaded guilty to third-degree sexual abuse, a misdemeanor, and was released in the custody of his attorney and a senior diplomat on the understanding that he would soon leave the United States and never return. Today was the first time Mr. O had left his mission at 40 East 80th Street since last September.   For the State Department, whose officials have been negotiating here since Thursday with North Korean aides, Mr. O's surrender was viewed as tacit confirmation of their doctrine of partial or functional immunity.   Under this thesis, diplomats attached to missions that are observers but not members of the United Nations are immune from arrest only for acts connected with their official duties. Diplomats of United Nations members, or accredited to Washington, are immune from any arrest, though they can be expelled from the United States.
lead_paragraph: After 10 months in seclusion, a North Korean diplomat left his refuge at his country's mission today and surrendered to Westchester County authorities on a charge of sexual abuse.

abstract:
A NOBLEMAN smiles haughtily, a monk leers, a red-faced servant mugs grotesquely. These are the faces depicted on colorful masks, with humorously exaggerated features, displayed in shops, restaurants, offices and homes all over South Korea. Originally used in shamanistic rituals to ward off evil spirits and now featured in epic dance-dramas, masks have become immensely popular as decorative objects in recent years, both with Koreans and foreign visitors.

When Koreans want to shop for decorative arts and crafts, they head for the Insa-dong district in Seoul. Situated near downtown hotels, museums and ancient palaces, Insa-dong has been a popular arts center since the early 1800's, and there are dozens of publishers and artists' studios in the area. It is one of the few spots in Seoul where traditional architecture has been maintained or restored, and narrow side streets are filled with one-story houses with tiled roofs and small windows.

abstract: A group of scholars added their voices today to those calling on the Government to revise the nation's Constitution.   In a statement distributed today, 28 professors at Korea University urged the Government to revise the Constitution quickly and allow more democratic freedoms. Their move follows several other calls for constitutional reivison in past weeks by opposition politicians, Seoul's Roman Catholic Primate and the National Council of Churches, which represents three million Protestants.   The Government has pledged to consider constitutional revision in 1989, but the opposition and other groups want earlier action.
lead_paragraph: A group of scholars added their voices today to those calling on the Government to revise the nation's Constitution.

abstract: The police announced today the arrest of 15 student activists from three Seoul universities on charges of participating in unlicensed, anti-Government demonstrations this week.   The police said 10 students from Sung Kyun Kwan University were accused of scattering seditious leaflets during a demonstration Tuesday in which hundreds of fellow students clashed with riot and plainclothes policemen.   Witnesses said the leaflets demanded changes, including press freedom, a free labor movement and the release of imprisoned students.
lead_paragraph: The police announced today the arrest of 15 student activists from three Seoul universities on charges of participating in unlicensed, anti-Government demonstrations this week.

abstract: Maj. Gen. Pak Se Jik was the commanding general of Seoul. A tall, powerfully built man in his late 40's, General Pak controlled with his armored forces this city of over eight million, 25 miles south of the demilitarized zone that divides the peninsula from North Korea.   Outside his heavily guarded headquarters on Namsan, the peak above the business district here, General Pak had a quadrangle the size of a football field that was crammed with armored personnel carriers.  The general's office bristled with shaven-headed staff officers. He hung military maps and posters of calligraphy on the walls.

abstract: Some were traveling in sorrow, to attend the funerals of loved ones. Others were bound for the Far East on missions of mercy, to sit at the bedsides of ailing relatives. Some were on business or vacation trips. One was returning to his Korean homeland to find a bride.    Mothers, fathers, children, people in trades and professions - these were among the 37 residents of New York's metropolitan area and upstate New York who died when a South Korean airliner carrying 269 people from New York to Seoul was reportedly struck by a Soviet missile and plunged into the Sea of Japan in the predawn darkness Thursday.

abstract: A 23-year-old South Korean theology student has charged at his arson trial in the southern city of Pusan that the authorities tortured him to fabricate an indictment falsely depicting him as a Communist sympathizer.   The case of this defendant, Moon Bu Shik, is cited here by a Japanese church publication as part of a report charging that torture is increasingly used by South Korean ''investigative and prison officials'' against political detainees.   ''The use of torture today is, if anything, more systematic and brutal than at any previous time in modern Korean history,'' said the latest issue of Korea Communique, a magazine published by the Japan Emergency Christian Conference on Korean Problems, which has a staff of Japanese and Americans. It is an affiliate of the Japanese National Council of Churches.
lead_paragraph: A 23-year-old South Korean theology student has charged at his arson trial in the southern city of Pusan that the authorities tortured him to fabricate an indictment falsely depicting him as a Communist sympathizer.

abstract: An engineer's negligence caused the rail collision that killed 54 people and injured more than 230 yesterday, officials said today.   Five people, including the engineer, were charged with negligence in the incident, which occurred when a Seoul-bound passenger train, backing up after hitting a motorcyle at a railroad crossing, was rammed by a second train.

abstract: Gen. Frank F. Everest of the Air Force, retired, who commanded the Fifth Air Force in the Korean War in 1951 and later was commander of the air forces in Europe, died of a heart attack Oct. 10 at his home in Briarcliffe Acres, Myrtle Beach, S.C. He was 78 years old.   General Everest, who was from Council Bluffs, Iowa, was a graduate of the United States Military Academy who began his military career in June 1928 as a second lieutenant in field artillery. He quickly moved to aviation, graduating from the Advanced Flying School at Kelly Field, Tex., in September 1929.
lead_paragraph: Gen. Frank F. Everest of the Air Force, retired, who commanded the Fifth Air Force in the Korean War in 1951 and later was commander of the air forces in Europe, died of a heart attack Oct. 10 at his home in Briarcliffe Acres, Myrtle Beach, S.C. He was 78 years old.

abstract: Tapes made public by the Government today showed Korean Air Lines Flight 7 had radio troubles that forced it to relay two vital position reports to traffic controllers back in Alaska.   The reports from the Boeing 747 jumbo jet were relayed by another South Korean 747 that took off from Anchorage 14 minutes behind it and, in one case, were also relayed by an Anchorage ground station monitoring lower radio frequencies. Reports From Key Checkpoints    The reports from Flight 7 were sent when the crew reckoned they were at checkpoints about 300 and 900 nautical miles from the start of a key over- ocean airway. The airliner, with 269 people on board, was headed for Seoul by way of Japan but went off course and was shot down by a Soviet fighter off Siberia near the southern end of Sakhalin Island.
lead_paragraph: Tapes made public by the Government today showed Korean Air Lines Flight 7 had radio troubles that forced it to relay two vital position reports to traffic controllers back in Alaska.

abstract: The South Korean airliner shot down by the Soviet Air Force in 1983 was not on an espionage mission, but the Russians, in a series of blunders, believed they were attacking an American reconnaissance flight, according to a magazine article.   The article, which will be published next month in The Atlantic Monthly, is based on a review of American intelligence data and on interviews with Soviet officials. It concludes that the plane penetrated Soviet airspace because of navigational errors by the Korean Air Lines crew and not, as the Soviet Union contended, because it was on an espionage mission.   The evidence gathered by American intelligence, which has not been made public, also contradicts the United States' initial contention that the Soviet Union had knowingly shot down the airliner, killing the 269 people aboard.   The article is drawn from a new book by Seymour M. Hersh, a journalist who has reported for The New York Times on corruption in Panama and on intelligence topics and who uncovered the My Lai massacre in Vietnam for an independent news agency.
lead_paragraph: The South Korean airliner shot down by the Soviet Air Force in 1983 was not on an espionage mission, but the Russians, in a series of blunders, believed they were attacking an American reconnaissance flight, according to a magazine article.

abstract: LEAD: As a music-theater adaptation of a traditional Korean folk tale, ''The Song of Shim Chung'' is a change of pace for the Pan Asian Repertory Theater, allowing the company's proficient actors to experiment in an area distant from contemporary naturalism. The brief play, which opens the Pan Asian season at Playhouse 46 at St.
lead_paragraph: As a music-theater adaptation of a traditional Korean folk tale, ''The Song of Shim Chung'' is a change of pace for the Pan Asian Repertory Theater, allowing the company's proficient actors to experiment in an area distant from contemporary naturalism. The brief play, which opens the Pan Asian season at Playhouse 46 at St. Clement's, is earnest but unimaginative in both conception and execution.

abstract: Kim Dae Jung, the leading opponent of South Korea's military-supported Government, and 14 democratic activists convicted with him for sedition have been moved from detention in Seoul to widely separated prisons, according to Japanese Christian sources.   The sources said here during the weekend that the prisoners were dispersed last week following three recent hunger strikes staged by them to protest irregularities in their trial last year. Mr. Kim, who has been in poor health, reportedly did not participate in the protests.   The 56-year-old Mr. Kim, whose death sentence was commuted to life imprisonment by President Chun Doo Hwan on Jan. 23, was sent to a prison in Chongju, 70 miles southeast of Seoul, the sources said.   The Rev. Moon Ik Hwan, a leading theologian and human rights activist, was moved to Kyongju jail in the southeastern part of the country, the sources said, while Prof. Lee Mun Young, a liberal well known in academic circles, was transferred to Kimhae Prison, on the south coast.
lead_paragraph: Kim Dae Jung, the leading opponent of South Korea's military-supported Government, and 14 democratic activists convicted with him for sedition have been moved from detention in Seoul to widely separated prisons, according to Japanese Christian sources.

abstract: The Pentagon may have withheld for three decades evidence suggesting that 389 American soldiers classified as missing in action in the Korean War were actually prisoners left behind when the shooting stopped, according to documents in a Federal trial that is to begin Tuesday.   The trial in Federal District Court here will probably touch on the sensitive relationship in 1953 between demands for the release of American prisoners of war and negotiations to end the war.   Robert Dumas, who has been searching since then for his brother, Roger, an Army private listed as missing in action and later as presumed dead, says he feels the Government may have accepted an end to the war at the expense of a few hundred of its servicemen.   Mr. Dumas's suit, filed against Army Secretary John O. Marsh Jr., asserts the Army acted unfairly and in bad faith in denying prisoner of war status to his brother, who was reportedly seen in North Korean prison Camp No. 5 in April 1953. The armistice was signed July 27, 1953.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon may have withheld for three decades evidence suggesting that 389 American soldiers classified as missing in action in the Korean War were actually prisoners left behind when the shooting stopped, according to documents in a Federal trial that is to begin Tuesday.

abstract: Aviation experts say that a new theory has emerged as the likeliest explanation of why a South Korean airliner flew into Soviet airspace on Sept. 1.  The theory is that a one-digit, 300-mile human error was made in putting the takeoff location into onboard computers.      The Boeing 747 was shot down by a Soviet fighter plane and all 269 people on board were killed. The Soviet Union has contended that the plane was on an espionage mission and entered Soviet airspace deliberately.
lead_paragraph: Aviation experts say that a new theory has emerged as the likeliest explanation of why a South Korean airliner flew into Soviet airspace on Sept. 1. The theory is that a one-digit, 300-mile human error was made in putting the takeoff location into onboard computers.

abstract: Don Whitehead, a war correspondent for The Associated Press who won two Pulitzer Prizes for international reporting for dispatches on the Korean War, died at his home in Knoxville, Tenn. on Monday of lung cancer after a long illness. He was 72 years old.   Mr. Whitehead reported on some of the major battles and events of World War II in Europe and North Africa, including the Normandy invasion, the liberation of Paris, the Allied invasion of Sicily, and Montgomery's desert drive against Rommel.   In July 1950 he went to Korea and, with a portable typewriter carried in a rucksack slung over his back, he wrote accounts of American forces landing on the Inchon beachhead, the crossing the Han River and the capture of Seoul, all of which he had witnessed. He was awarded his first Pulitzer Prize in 1951.
lead_paragraph: Don Whitehead, a war correspondent for The Associated Press who won two Pulitzer Prizes for international reporting for dispatches on the Korean War, died at his home in Knoxville, Tenn. on Monday of lung cancer after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

abstract: When the summer sun washes over the broad boulevards and monumental buildings of this riverside capital, there is a quiet, almost deserted quality to the place, as if most of the population of 800,000 had left town for the day.   The emptiness of Pyongyang at hours when other capitals are thronged is among the most powerful impressions of North Korea, a nation that has closed its doors to much of the world since its birth at the end of World War II. The sense of being on a movie set after hours returns frequently.   In the glossy magazines and books for foreign consumption that the Government produces in prodigious quantities, the country is described as ''a paradise on earth,'' a living monument to the genius of the man who has been in control since the Soviet Army took over from the occupation forces of Japan 40 years ago. That man is Kim Il Sung, the 73-year-old President and head of the Korean Workers' Party, who is referred to by the obligatory title of ''the great leader'' even by 8-year-old schoolboys.
lead_paragraph: When the summer sun washes over the broad boulevards and monumental buildings of this riverside capital, there is a quiet, almost deserted quality to the place, as if most of the population of 800,000 had left town for the day.

abstract: LEAD: Arthur H. Dean, the lawyer-diplomat who tried to arrange a post-Korean War peace conference with the Chinese at the request of President Eisenhower in 1953, and who served as a negotiator on disarmament and other matters for three other Presidents, died of pneumonia yesterday at the Community Hospital at Glen Cove, L.
lead_paragraph: Arthur H. Dean, the lawyer-diplomat who tried to arrange a post-Korean War peace conference with the Chinese at the request of President Eisenhower in 1953, and who served as a negotiator on disarmament and other matters for three other Presidents, died of pneumonia yesterday at the Community Hospital at Glen Cove, L. I. He was 89 years old and lived in Oyster Bay, L. I. Mr. Dean succeeded John Foster Dulles as senior partner in the prestigious New York law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell in 1949, when Mr. Dulles was elected a United States Senator. He had joined the firm in 1923 after graduation from Cornell Law School.

abstract: Products made in South Korea are flooding the United States, and some experts say Korea is challenging Japan as the leading low-price supplier of everything from small cars to video recorders.   Hyundai, for example, introduced its Excel subcompact car in February, and already it is the fourth best-selling import, having passed Mazda in July. The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company are planning to import Korean-made cars for sale in this country. Assembly Plant in Alabama    In electronics, the Korean Lucky Gold Star Group opened an assembly plant in Alabama in August designed to produce up to a million microwave ovens a year. Gold Star and another South Korean company, Samsung, are each producing a million television sets annually at American plants. And an Arizona company is beginning to market Hyundai's personal computers, at a basic price of just $699.
lead_paragraph: Products made in South Korea are flooding the United States, and some experts say Korea is challenging Japan as the leading low-price supplier of everything from small cars to video recorders.

abstract: Flames swept through a two-story disco club filled with people early today in the southeastern city of Taegu, killing 24 and injuring about 70, the police reported.   The Korean Broadcasting Corporation quoted a club employee as saying that about 400 people were in the club at about 2 A.M. when fire broke out in the ceiling of the second floor.

abstract: Kim Dae Jung, the exiled South Korean opposition leader, said yesterday that the South Korean Government had taken a ''reasonable attitude'' by announcing he would not be imprisoned when he returns home from the United States on Friday. But he insisted that the promise was ''not enough.''    ''Fundamentally, I have been an innocent victim,'' said Mr. Kim, who has been living near Washington for more than two years. ''It is time for the Korean Government to completely change its attitude and give me amnesty, to give me my civil rights.''

abstract: A South Korean airliner with 269 people aboard disappeared this morning near the Soviet island of Sakhalin, off the Pacific coast of Siberia, according to reports in Tokyo and Seoul.    Early reports said the plane, a Korean Air Lines Boeing 747 jetliner on a flight from New York to Seoul with a stop in Anchorage, had been forced down by Soviet Air Force planes and that all 240 passengers and 29 crew members were believed to be safe.    But an airline official in Seoul said this afternoon that an explosion might have occurred in midair.   Radar Said to Lose Plane    In addition, Japanese Air Force officials said they had tracked a plane flying near Sakhalin that suddenly disappeared from their radar screens.  Just before that happened, the officials said, one or more other planes were observed flying close by. (South Korean officials said the plane was at 30,000 feet when it disappeared from radar, The Associated Press reported.
lead_paragraph: A South Korean airliner with 269 people aboard disappeared this morning near the Soviet island of Sakhalin, off the Pacific coast of Siberia, according to reports in Tokyo and Seoul.

abstract: North Korea is stepping up its arms sales and military training in other countries, according to diplomats and other experts on the region.    Some experts say that North Korea's need to generate cash may be a reason not only for the new arms sales but also for heightened smuggling by the Pyongyang Government's embassies abroad.   The diplomats and experts also say that a power struggle may be under way in the Pyongyang hierarchy that could partly explain the involvement of North Korea in recent violence abroad. On Oct. 9 a powerful bomb exploded in Rangoon, Burma, killing 17 South Koreans, including some of Seoul's highest-ranking officials. Burma blamed North Korea, severing relations, and even allies such as China have expressed dismay.
lead_paragraph: North Korea is stepping up its arms sales and military training in other countries, according to diplomats and other experts on the region.

abstract: Soviet authorities turned over to Japanese and American officials today 83 items, but no bodies, from the South Korean jetliner that was shot down by a Soviet fighter plane on Sept. 1.   The transfer, the second of its kind, took place at this Soviet port on the southwest end of Sakhalin Island, near the site where the Korean Air Lines jumbo jet is believed to have plunged into the Sea of Japan after the attack in Soviet airspace.   The Soviet authorities handed over five boxes containing 73 pieces of debris they said were from the airliner, seven pieces of clothing, two books and one piece of plastic Venetian blind.
lead_paragraph: Soviet authorities turned over to Japanese and American officials today 83 items, but no bodies, from the South Korean jetliner that was shot down by a Soviet fighter plane on Sept. 1.

abstract: A North Korean surface-to-air missile was fired at an American reconnaissance aircraft near the demilitarized zone of North and South Korea today, Pentagon officials said. The plane was not hit, they added.   The missile fired at the American SR-71, an advanced highaltitude, long-range surveillance plane considered one of the fastest aircraft in the world, did not come near its target, an official said.   The Pentagon refused to discuss the specific activities of the aircraft but said in a statement that the SR-71 had been flying in South Korean and international airspace. It said that the incident had posed no threat to the aircraft, which landed safely.
lead_paragraph: A North Korean surface-to-air missile was fired at an American reconnaissance aircraft near the demilitarized zone of North and South Korea today, Pentagon officials said. The plane was not hit, they added.

abstract: Korean Air Lines, whose off-course 747 carrying 269 people was shot down by the Soviet Union, has a mixed reputation among aviation officials, industry executives and pilots.   But all seem to agree that the Korean flag carrier is ''extremely aggressive'' in its quest for rapid growth, its bargain-basement pricing of tickets and its willingness to assume huge debts to finance its ambitious plans.   According to some airline officials and pilots, the corporate inclination toward aggressiveness is seen in the flying practices of Korean Air Lines pilots, nearly all of whom are alumni of the South Korean Air Force.   For example, there is a practice some pilots use to land their plane before others. Since ground control radar can reach only about 200 miles, a pilot will give a false position to the control tower from outside its tracking range, indicating that the plane is closer or better positioned for landing than it is.
lead_paragraph: Korean Air Lines, whose off-course 747 carrying 269 people was shot down by the Soviet Union, has a mixed reputation among aviation officials, industry executives and pilots.

abstract: Kim Dae Jung, the leading critic of the South Korean Government, says he plans to end his exile here and return home soon because he has been frustrated by his inability to influence South Korean politics from the United States.   Mr. Kim, who was released from prison two years ago and came to the United States for medical treatment, said in an interview that he would return home to seek improved human rights, free elections and a free press. He said he would leave sometime in January or February.    ''I've made an effort to support the cause of democracy and human rights in our country, but I don't think I've fully succeeded, especially in persuading the American Government to change its Korean policy,'' Mr. Kim said in the interview, conducted at his office in Alexandria, Va.
lead_paragraph: Kim Dae Jung, the leading critic of the South Korean Government, says he plans to end his exile here and return home soon because he has been frustrated by his inability to influence South Korean politics from the United States.

abstract: The Reagan Administration intends to use the visit of President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea to end the friction that has marred relations between the two countries in recent years and to demonstrate a more subdued approach to human rights issues than the Carter Administration used, senior Administration officials said today.   A communique to be issued after Mr. Chun meets with President Reagan on Monday will reaffirm American security commitments to South Korea and to East Asia, including the retention of the 39,000 American troops in Korea, officials said. Privately, the Korean leader will be advised that the Reagan Administration wants to open a new chapter in relations, free of the tensions that marked the Carter Administration's dealings with Seoul.
lead_paragraph: The Reagan Administration intends to use the visit of President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea to end the friction that has marred relations between the two countries in recent years and to demonstrate a more subdued approach to human rights issues than the Carter Administration used, senior Administration officials said today.
