abstract:
Some Americans have been so inspired by the fall of President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines that they have set their sights on a new target: South Korea. The answer to the ''dictatorship'' of President Chun Doo Hwan, they say, is the ''democratic'' opposition. But the United States should refrain from taking sides in the internal debate over how to reshape South Korea's Government. We can be most helpful by encouraging dialogue and moderation on both sides.

For more than a year, the opposition New Korea Democratic Party and the Chun Government have clashed over progress toward democratization, particularly on a demand to amend the Constitution. On April 30, President Chun surprised nearly everyone by offering a major concession, calling for the formation of a constitutional revision committee in the National Assembly that would study all options. Opposition leaders were caught off guard and the factions are now wrangling over their strategy. Yet, President Chun's gesture warrants a reasoned response.
snippet: Some Americans have been so inspired by the fall of President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines that they have set their sights on a new target: South Korea. The answer to the ''dictatorship'' of President Chun Doo Hwan, they say, is the ''de...
lead_paragraph: Some Americans have been so inspired by the fall of President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines that they have set their sights on a new target: South Korea. The answer to the ''dictatorship'' of President Chun Doo Hwan, they say, is the ''democratic'' opposition. But the United States should refrain from taking sides in the internal debate over how to reshape South Korea's Government. We can be most helpful by encouraging dialogue and moderation on both sides.

abstract: Few sights that officials show visitors to this Communist nation are invested with greater symbolic importance than a huge wall that snakes across the Korean Peninsula from the Yellow Sea to the Sea of Japan.   After peering at the wall through a telescope from his observation post in the hilly terrain east of Panmunjom, the truce village in the demilitarized zone, Maj. Kang Myong Su of the North Korean Army stepped back and said: ''This is our tragedy. Nobody has the right to build a barrier across our country, to try and divide our people forever.''   In Major Kang's briefing, the villain is the United States. The wall he inspects - more than 15 feet high and 30 feet wide at its base, with concrete sides and filled with earth - was completed in 1979. In conception, it is at least partly an American wall, running 150 miles along the entire length of the demilitarized zone. A Ruse or a Barricade?  From the viewpoint of the United States and its allies in South Korea, the wall's purpose is to block a North Korean invasion. To Major Kang and his superiors in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, all talk of an attack by the North is an American ruse to justify the division of Korea and insure a permanent United States military presence.
lead_paragraph: Few sights that officials show visitors to this Communist nation are invested with greater symbolic importance than a huge wall that snakes across the Korean Peninsula from the Yellow Sea to the Sea of Japan.

abstract: The Soviet Union stepped up its charges today that the United States was ultimately responsible for the fate of the South Korean airliner that was downed over Soviet Far Eastern airspace.   It accused the White House of waging a ''worldwide, rabid anti-Soviet campaign'' over the incident.   An account carried by the Soviet press agency Tass and read on Soviet television tonight continued to avoid any admission that the Korean Air Lines 747 with 269 people aboard had been shot down by Soviet interceptors. But the report went beyond previous Soviet statements in acknowledging that the aircraft, previously identified only as an ''intruder plane,'' was in fact the Korean airliner.
lead_paragraph: The Soviet Union stepped up its charges today that the United States was ultimately responsible for the fate of the South Korean airliner that was downed over Soviet Far Eastern airspace.

abstract: The America of the 1950's branded Cpl. Harold H. Webb of the Army a traitor, labeled him an informer and gave him a dishonorable discharge from the military when he refused to return to the United States from a prisoner-of-war camp after the Korean War. Now Mr. Webb wants to come home. Mr. Webb is one of the 21 American prisoners of war who chose to stay with the Chinese nearly 33 years ago. And the State Department says he is not a United States citizen anymore. State Department officials said they could not discuss Mr. Webb's case because of Federal privacy laws.   ''When I left Korea, when I said I would not return home, was the beginning of the time I wanted to return home, back in 1954,'' Mr. Webb, now a Polish citizen, said in a recent interview in Louisville, where he was visiting on a tourist visa. ''I've always had it in my mind. I've always had deep down inside in me - I am an American. I was born in this country. This is my place.'' Prisoner of War for Three Years Mr. Webb was a prisoner of the Chinese for three years. He was a voluntary resident of China for six years. He moved to Poland in 1960 after getting to know some Polish students in China, and he decided to take Polish citizenship in 1970.
lead_paragraph: The America of the 1950's branded Cpl. Harold H. Webb of the Army a traitor, labeled him an informer and gave him a dishonorable discharge from the military when he refused to return to the United States from a prisoner-of-war camp after the Korean War. Now Mr. Webb wants to come home. Mr. Webb is one of the 21 American prisoners of war who chose to stay with the Chinese nearly 33 years ago. And the State Department says he is not a United States citizen anymore. State Department officials said they could not discuss Mr. Webb's case because of Federal privacy laws.

abstract: The United States expressed ''serious concern'' today over the firing of a North Korean antiaircraft missile at an Air Force reconnaissance plane yesterday. Washington also warned that it would take ''whatever steps are necessary to assure the future safety of our pilots and planes.''   The American statement, issued by the State Department, was accompanied by a call for a special meeting of the Korean Military Armistice Commission to meet at Panmunjom in the demilitarized zone between North and South Korea on Saturday to discuss the incident.   Dean Fischer, the State Department spokesman, said the United States was able to ''confirm'' that North Korea ''fired a missile at a U.S. Air Force plane flying in South Korean and international air space.'' He said it was one of a number of ''routine'' flights conducted for years in the region.
lead_paragraph: The United States expressed ''serious concern'' today over the firing of a North Korean antiaircraft missile at an Air Force reconnaissance plane yesterday. abstract:
SEOUL, South Korea ON Wednesday, the trial of 29 bankers, business executives and moneylenders began here in what prosecutors have called ''the biggest financial scandal in Korean history.''

Considered far more important than the Tongsun Park influencebuying scandal that rocked Washington and Seoul in the late 1970's, the latest embarrassment grew out of a loan business in Seoul's shady money markets. The whole affair has gravely weakened the right-wing regime of President Chun Doo Hwan, whose wife's relatives have been linked to it.

At the center of this growing political and financial maelstrom is Chang Yong Ja, a 38-year-old Seoul socialite, who is related to President Chun's wife. Her third husband and business partner, who is also on trial, is the former No.2 man in the Korean Central Intelligence Agency. Mrs. Chang, who was taken to court bound with rope and handcuffed, pale and defiant, admits only to minor infractions of the law, such as foreign exchange regulations offenses.

abstract: Michael K. Deaver represented a foreign client at a meeting with an official of the National Security Council five months after he left his job as deputy White House chief of staff, according to a report he filed with the Justice Department.   A Government ethics official said the meeting was within the law, but Congressional critics of Mr. Deaver strongly disagreed.   David Martin, director of the Office of Government Ethics, sent a letter to the Justice Department today asking it to investigate whether Mr. Deaver had violated conflict-of-interest laws. Mr. Martin declined to produce the letter or explain what had prompted it. On Thursday five Democratic Senators sent a letter similar to Mr. Martin's to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, setting in motion a procedure that can lead to the appointment of an independent counsel to investigate Mr. Deaver's activities.   Under the law, the Attorney General must respond within 30 days and tell the senators whether he has asked a three-judge Federal court to appoint an independent counsel, or, if not, why not.
lead_paragraph: Michael K. Deaver represented a foreign client at a meeting with an official of the National Security Council five months after he left his job as deputy White House chief of staff, according to a report he filed with the Justice Department.

abstract: In Kyoon Ahn, a Korean greengrocer, is not likely to join Ernesto Miranda or Clarence Gideon on the title page of a landmark legal decision.   But the relatively meager record in a case involving Mr. Ahn illustrates many facets of contemporary New York: the ethnic and racial tensions in its changing neighborhoods, the attempts of its law-enforcement machinery to deal with them, and the way its criminal-justice system lurches to a result, sometimes in spite of itself.   Recently, Judge Ira B. Harkavy of Brooklyn Criminal Court dismissed assault and harassment charges against Mr. Ahn and one of his employees. The charges stemmed from an incident last February at Mr. Ahn's Brooklyn store, a squabble with a customer that suddenly thrust him into a wholly alien role: defendant in a criminal prosecution.   Mr. Ahn and his employee, Tae Ho Jung, were arrested after they tried to restrain a woman they said was stealing produce from their store, at 1052 Flatbush Avenue, in the Flatbush section. They were taken away in handcuffs, booked and released three hours later.
lead_paragraph: In Kyoon Ahn, a Korean greengrocer, is not likely to join Ernesto Miranda or Clarence Gideon on the title page of a landmark legal decision.

Desai, and it points one of New York's revered institutions of Asian art in a new direction.    This idea-filled yet overanxious and overambitious exhibition, organized by Dr. Hongnam Kim, an Asia Society curator who also wrote the catalogue essay, inaugurates "Objects in Context," a key part of Dr. Desai's curatorial program.

abstract: Soviet television broadcast an interview tonight with a Soviet fighter pilot who was identified as having shot down the Korean Air Lines 747 jetliner last week.   The pilot, who appeared to be about 45 years old, with graying, tousled hair, a rugged face and a raspy voice, was not named or identified by rank.   ''I had a specific task assigned me,'' he said, ''and I tried to accomplish it as well as possible - a military task, which is the meaning of my entire life.''   He sat slouched in an easy chair, dressed in a brown leather jacket, blue cotton pants and blue shirt as he spoke to the interviewer, Aleksandr Tikhomirov of Soviet state television, on a base on Sakhalin island.   The pilot described his certainty that he was dealing with an ''enemy aircraft,'' and told how he had wagged the wings of his SU-15 and fired four bursts of tracer shells along the jetliner's route.  ''This in international code signifies that 'you're an intruder,' '' he said. ''He had to answer somehow that 'yes, I'm an intruding aircraft and in trouble,' and I would've helped him if he was in trouble, and if he was an intruder he could have landed on our airfield and we would have sorted it out.''
lead_paragraph: Soviet television broadcast an interview tonight with a Soviet fighter pilot who was identified as having shot down the Korean Air Lines 747 jetliner last week.

abstract: Peter H. Ohm, founder and publisher of Korea Times, the largest Korean-American newspaper in the New York City area, and the owner of a Korean-American television station, died on Friday at the Palm Beach Gardens Medical Center in Florida. He was 59 years old and lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y.   He suffered a stroke while playing golf at the Professional Golfers Association National Golf Club at Palm Beach Gardens, where he kept a winter residence, said Hogan Yoon, chairman of Panasian Communications Inc.

abstract: South Korean officials said today that North Korea called for secret talks with the United States during President Reagan's recent visit to Peking, using China as an intermediary to convey the proposal. American officials said the proposal was rejected.    The South Koreans said North Korea apparently hoped that such talks could prepare for a possible conference on reunification that would include the United States. American officials reiterated the basic United States position on such proposals that the two Koreas should first negotiate between themselves on reunifying the peninsula, which was divided nearly four decades ago.

abstract: LEAD: SOUTH KOREAN university students were the principal force in the protests that culminated in June with street fighting in Seoul. Partly because of these protests, the Government accepted most opposition demands, notably for direct presidential elections. Yet many students say they will continue to demonstrate.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH KOREAN university students were the principal force in the protests that culminated in June with street fighting in Seoul. Partly because of these protests, the Government accepted most opposition demands, notably for direct presidential elections. Yet many students say they will continue to demonstrate. They say they mistrust almost everyone - the Government, opposition politicians, the domestic and foreign press.

abstract: The Republic of Korea - one of the success stories of international lending - is showing off this week to the economic and financial leaders of the world.   But it was not all that easy for South Korea to win approval for Seoul as the site of the 40th joint annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.   The Australian government pushed Sydney as the best place to hold the meeting, Thailand nominated its capital, Bangkok, and the West Germans campaigned for West Berlin as the host city. Berlin has just gotten the nod as the site for the 1988 annual meeting.
lead_paragraph: The Republic of Korea - one of the success stories of international lending - is showing off this week to the economic and financial leaders of the world.

abstract: The police battled hundreds of stone-throwing students for a second day today after an anti-Government demonstration marking the anniversary of South Korea's most violent uprising.   In the provincial capital of Kwangju, the center of a nine-day revolt in May 1980 in which at least 189 people died, 30 Roman Catholic priests refused food for a second day in a hunger strike to ''share the pain'' of a priest and at least 22 other people who are still jailed for last year's insurrection.   Witnesses said 300 students from Korea University, one of the largest in South Korea, clashed with the police.  Yesterday at Sungkyunkwan University in Seoul two policemen were injured and six students were arrested in a similar clash.
lead_paragraph: The police battled hundreds of stone-throwing students for a second day today after an anti-Government demonstration marking the anniversary of South Korea's most violent uprising.

abstract: State Department officials have urged Kim Dae Jung, the South Korean opposition leader, to accept a confidential guarantee from the Seoul Government that he would not be arrested if he delayed until May his return from exile in this country, Reagan Administration officials and associates of Mr. Kim said today.   But Mr. Kim said in an interview that it was too late for him to change his plans. He is scheduled to leave here on Feb. 6 and fly to South Korea, stopping overnight in Tokyo. An entourage of some 20 Americans is accompanying him to insure that he is not assassinated as was Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the Philippine opposition leader who was murdered when he returned to Manila in 1983.
lead_paragraph: State Department officials have urged Kim Dae Jung, the South Korean opposition leader, to accept a confidential guarantee from the Seoul Government that he would not be arrested if he delayed until May his return from exile in this country, Reagan Administration officials and associates of Mr. Kim said today.

abstract: Beginning in the early 1970's, foreign buyers and manufacturers flocked to South Korean shoe factories, attracted mainly by the low wholesale cost of footwear and the factories' high production.   At the same time, demand for South Korean footwear, particularly running shoes, soared in the United States as jogging gained in popularity.   But the tide has turned for Korea's shoe industry, perennially one of the nation's biggest earners of foreign exchange, and it is now facing a second consecutive year of hard times. Buyers are now beginning to bypass South Korea in favor of other producing countries with cheaper wage rates and more stable political conditions.
lead_paragraph: Beginning in the early 1970's, foreign buyers and manufacturers flocked to South Korean shoe factories, attracted mainly by the low wholesale cost of footwear and the factories' high production.

abstract: The South Korean opposition figure Kim Dae Jung arrived in Washington tonight and said that his most fervent wish was to return to his homeland and dedicate his life to the peaceful reunification of North and South Korea.   Mr. Kim was given a boisterous welcome at Washington's National Airport by about 300 South Koreans living in the Washington area, including a large contingent of South Korean journalists. Supporters sang the South Korean national anthem as Mr. Kim was escorted to a private room at the airport where he made a brief statement. Mr. Kim spoke in Korean and his remarks were translated by a companion.
lead_paragraph: The South Korean opposition figure Kim Dae Jung arrived in Washington tonight and said that his most fervent wish was to return to his homeland and dedicate his life to the peaceful reunification of North and South Korea.

abstract: South Korean Christian leaders urged the Reagan Administration today to recall the two top American officials here, because of ''increasing anti-American feeling.''   The request by 42 prominent Roman Catholic and Protestant leaders came six days before Vice President Bush is due here on a visit.The statement also called on President Chun Doo Hwan to restore democratic rule, free political prisoners, halt torture of people suspected of anti-Government activity and reinstate thousands of labor leaders, students and journalists ousted under sweeping ''purification'' campaigns.
lead_paragraph: South Korean Christian leaders urged the Reagan Administration today to recall the two top American officials here, because of ''increasing anti-American feeling.''

abstract:
Kim Dae Jung, South Korea's leading opposition figure, left Seoul today for the United States after serving two and a half years of a 20-year prison sentence for sedition.

The 57-year-old Mr. Kim was expected to seek medical treatment in the United States for arthritis. Last week he was transferred from his prison cell in Chongju, 70 miles south of Seoul, to a heavily guarded room in the National University Hospital in the capital.

The South Korean Government made no immediate announcement about Mr. Kim's departure, which was said to have taken place at 7:30 P.M.  Seoul time (5:30 A.M., New York time). Reporters were barred from the airport area just before Mr. Kim's flight left.

abstract: The road from here to Panmunjom in the demilitarized zone has a new asphalt surface, a hurry-up job completed recently.   South Korea wanted to show off its best, expecting that Red Cross representatives from North Korea would be driving down that road last week for the first full-dress talks with their South Korean counterparts in 12 years. Instead, earlier in January, North Korea announced that it was not coming - not to Seoul for the Red Cross discussions, nor to Panmunjom for negotiations that had been scheduled for mid- Januaryto discuss possibilities for trade between the long-hostile countries.   Now South Korean officials do not expect talks to resume before mid-spring, if then. After a brief period of friendlier relations in the second half of 1984, the two Koreas have returned to a pattern of mutual scorn and attacks on one another's intentions.
lead_paragraph: The road from here to Panmunjom in the demilitarized zone has a new asphalt surface, a hurry-up job completed recently.

abstract: As North Korean ships continued to deliver relief supplies to his country, South Korea's President charged today that the North at the same time was strengthening its military forces near the demilitarized zone.    President Chun Doo Hwan said there had been ''unusual movements in the North, as they have deployed large tank units, long-range guns and guided weapons in the forward areas along the truce line.'' The North Koreans also have ''intensified the training of their 100,000 commando troops,'' he said.
lead_paragraph: As North Korean ships continued to deliver relief supplies to his country, South Korea's President charged today that the North at the same time was strengthening its military forces near the demilitarized zone.

abstract: Thirty Roman Catholic priests ended a three-day hunger strike today after the authorities promised to accept their demands for the release of 23 people jailed for involvement in last year's violent Kwangju uprising, a Catholic official said.   Details of the Government's promise were not known, but the priests from the Kwangju diocese had demanded that it pay ''due homage'' to the victims of the Kwangju riot and release the Rev. Kim Seong Yong and 22 other people still imprisoned for their part in the nine-day uprising.

abstract: President Roh Tae Woo said today that after four decades of violence and bitter division, "North Korea has come to its senses" and is sending the first signals that it is preparing to "step forward into the open world."   Mr. Roh's assessment of a series of surprising announcements in recent weeks from the North Korean capital, Pyongyang, came in a wide-ranging interview today at Blue House, the presidential palace on a hillside above Seoul.
lead_paragraph: President Roh Tae Woo said today that after four decades of violence and bitter division, "North Korea has come to its senses" and is sending the first signals that it is preparing to "step forward into the open world."

abstract: President Chun Doo Hwan, moving swiftly to demonstrate the continuity of his Government, reorganized the top levels of his Cabinet tonight to replace officials who died in a bombing last Sunday in Rangoon, Burma.    The entire Cabinet resigned only a day after funeral services for the 17 South Koreans killed as a result of the explosion. The Cabinet's action was seen as a formality to allow Mr. Chun a free hand in shifting as many people as he wished. When the changes were announced hours later, it was clear that no sudden, dramatic departures in policy were under way.
lead_paragraph: President Chun Doo Hwan, moving swiftly to demonstrate the continuity of his Government, reorganized the top levels of his Cabinet tonight to replace officials who died in a bombing last Sunday in Rangoon, Burma.

abstract: LEAD:  THE WINTER REPUBLIC  By Yang Song U  (Translated by Ko Won)  Is it now winter?  The middle of night?  With what, my friend,  Shall we comfort ourselves  This winter time when our fields are frozen?  Is our great land still livable?  Is the land still as beautiful as silks?  That's a lie; that is a lie.
lead_paragraph: THE WINTER REPUBLIC By Yang Song U (Translated by Ko Won) Is it now winter? The middle of night? With what, my friend, Shall we comfort ourselves This winter time when our fields are frozen? Is our great land still livable? Is the land still as beautiful as silks? That's a lie; that is a lie. We are serfs, scarecrows Lending our ears silently to lies In a pretense of knowing nothing every day And having to tolerate whips that cut our bones. Crying out in our own dear language, Why don't we make azaleas, azaleas, azaleas Come alive and bloom out of this frozen land, Blooming all over the paddies? My friend, Why don't we have our sad winter Spoken of, time and time again? And mustn't we, shackled tight, struggle on To the last, while waiting for the spring, My friend? DAILY INSPECTION OF THE SCENE OF THE CRIME By Hwang Chi U (Translated by Sol Sun Bong) Yesterday I came back with stakes driven into my ears. Today I installed a fence of barbed wire over my eyes And bound it with bandage. Tomorrow I will throw a scoop of dirt into my mouth And plug it with a ball of cotton. Day after day, Night after night, I bury a part of me In order to annihilate the evidence of my living In order to obtain my survival. DIALOGUE BETWEEN AN AMERICAN DOG AND A KOREAN DOG By Mun Bong Ran Korean dog: Hello, American dog. Your country is a bizarre society, a dogs' paradise, where dogs live luxuriously; How ridiculous that a dog's life is pampered, while your neighbors like El Salvador have no human rights. Our master's country has been trampled by Yan- kees, Japanese and Russians who divided the territory. Hello, American dog. We are willing to sacrifice our lives for our master. We are happy. We can't un- derstand civilized Americans putting the rights of dogs over those of people. Murderous human- ism! Goodbye, happy American dog. I CANNOT FORGET By Chong Hui Song I recall The lament of the poet arrested last night . . . . He dropped his head, Weighed down by the ''poet'' Prefixed to his name. I dread the night when he returns no more. I dread the land to which he returns no more.

abstract: Unusually large waves of immigrants from Southeast Asia and South Asia in the 1980's transformed the Asian community in the United States, setting off an explosion of diversity among Asian-Americans, the nation's fastest-growing minority, figures made public today by the Census Bureau show.   The political upheavals and economic hardships that beset Asian nations from Sri Lanka and the Philippines to China and South Korea have sent more than two million immigrants across the Pacific Ocean in the past decade, according to Federal immigration figures.

abstract: A multitude of masks were on view in Pongsan Masked Dance-Drama of Korea, the program offered Sunday night at the Asia Society as part of the New York International Festival of the Arts. White blank-faced masks with tiny eyes stared impassively. There were also goggle-eyed red masks. And it was easy to tell that one character was a foolish idle nobleman because of his mask's silly crooked grin. Everyone onstage might well have been an animated doll.    But if these dancers from Seoul, South Korea, were doll-like, their offerings were not childlike. The performance was devoted to a style of Korean masked dance that began to appear in the 18th century and which radically changed in tone over the years. The masked presentations were originally religious in nature, and this one, under the artistic direction of Kim Ki Soo, began and ended with sacred ceremonies.
lead_paragraph: A multitude of masks were on view in Pongsan Masked Dance-Drama of Korea, the program offered Sunday night at the Asia Society as part of the New York International Festival of the Arts. And it was easy to tell that one character was a foolish idle nobleman because of his mask's silly crooked grin. Everyone onstage might well have been an animated doll.

abstract: South Korea's emergence as a major international exporter contrasts with its dire circumstances after the Korean War ended in 1953. In those days, the South lagged behind the Communist North, which possessed most of the country's industry.   Industry had been situated in the North because most of the mineral resources - coal, iron ore, lead and others - were there. But most of the people lived in the South, which was better suited for agriculture. The growing season was longer in the South, and the soil tended to be better.
lead_paragraph: South Korea's emergence as a major international exporter contrasts with its dire circumstances after the Korean War ended in 1953. In those days, the South lagged behind the Communist North, which possessed most of the country's industry.

abstract: Transcript of Shultz remarks, page 4.          WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 - Secretary of State George P. Shultz accused the Soviet Union today of continuing to ''cover up the facts'' of the apparent shooting down of a South Korean airliner.   Rejecting the latest Soviet statement on the loss of the Korean Air Lines 747, in which 269 people died, Mr. Shultz said, ''The world is waiting for the Soviet Union to tell the truth.''   In Moscow, the official press agency, Tass, distributed a statement asserting that the Korean Air Lines plane was carrying out a ''preplanned act'' for ''special intelligence aims'' in crossing into Soviet airspace. Tass also said a Soviet plane had fired tracer shells to warn the plane, but did not admit it had shot the plane down.
lead_paragraph: Transcript of Shultz remarks, page 4.

abstract: IC    Statements by U.S., page A5.           A South Korean airliner missing with 269 people on a flight from New York to Seoul was shot down in the Sea of Japan by a Soviet jet fighter near a Soviet island off Siberia, the United States said yesterday.   There were no known survivors of the attack, in which a heat-seeking missile was said to have been fired without warning at the airliner by an interceptor that had tracked it over Soviet territory for two and a half hours.   President Reagan expressed ''revulsion'' over what he called ''a horrifying act of violence.'' He cut short his California vacation and called a National Security Council meeting in Washington today to discuss possible reprisals.

abstract: Recent events, however bad, only symbolize this crisis. There will be worse to come. In March, student dissidents torched the American Cultural Center in Pusan and attacked the American role in backing President Chun and in aiding the suppression of the Kwangju rebellion of May 1980. Theology students did this, and their Roman Catholic priests sheltered them while arranging for their surrender. Now the fathers are on trial under the harsh National Security Law, and the students are termed Marxists. In May came the worst financial scandal in Korean history. Shady manipulations on the informal money market running into the hundreds of millions of dollars shook an economy that exists on state-controlled credit. Several companies went bankrupt, much of the Cabinet resigned and President Chun drew the wagons around the Blue House, stonewalling amid allegations that the loan sharks had close ties to him and his wife. In early June, women who are electronics workers held two Americans hostage for nine hours, until the American Embassy notified the Korean police and had the workers arrested.

Theology students did this, and their Roman Catholic priests sheltered them while arranging for their surrender. Now the fathers are on trial under the harsh National Security Law, and the students are termed Marxists. In May came the worst financial scandal in Korean history. Shady manipulations on the informal money market running into the hundreds of millions of dollars shook an economy that exists on state-controlled credit. Several companies went bankrupt, much of the Cabinet resigned and President Chun drew the wagons around the Blue House, stonewalling amid allegations that the loan sharks had close ties to him and his wife. In early June, women who are electronics workers held two Americans hostage for nine hours, until the American Embassy notified the Korean police and had the workers arrested.

headline.main:
DEVIL TO PAY IN SEOUL;
South Korea today is in the midst of a deeprunning, three-year-old crisis. In October 1979 this crisis brought the downfall of Park Chung Hee, and today it threatens his successor, Chun Doo Hwan. Also in jeopardy is the American relationship with Korea, now in its centennial year. Why? Because three American Presidents over the past decade have ignored, or supported, the repression of democratic dissidents.

abstract: Separate investigations by the Justice Department and the Internal Revenue Service have focused on allegations by Daniel Charboneau, a former Bechtel employee, about the activities of Joon Sik Cho, a Korean- American consultant hired by the giant construction company's Bechtel Power unit to help win contracts to build nuclear power plants in Korea. abstract: A Korean grocery in Brooklyn that was the target of a boycott last year was sold last week because the owner had become "too stressed" by the confrontations with angry protesters, Mayor David N. abstract: Where the Topiary Is Real MOST people go to Walt Disney World for the rides and exhibitions. Anthony Scopas of Port Washington went to look at the shrubs. "I was riding the monorail and I looked down and noticed this one topiary," he said. "The bush was shaped so perfectly I couldn't believe it was real."    Mr. Scopas found a way to walk back to the shrub to view it close-up. "You're not going to believe it," he said. "It was plastic. They have plastic topiary in Disney World."

abstract:
On April 26, Kang Kyung Dae, a college freshman, was beaten to death by riot policemen wielding iron pipes and clubs. Nearly a month later, his death continues to convulse South Korean society. 

Although the police killed hundreds, mostly students and others youths, in the Kwangju massacre in 1980 and in other demonstrations against successive dictatorial regimes, this is the first time in the republic's history that the riot police attacked and killed a student fleeing from them toward his campus. At least five students have set themselves on fire in protest over his death. The public, angered by police brutality, blames President Roh Tae Woo's Government.

abstract: WHEN the tear gas cleared in early 1988 and Roh Tae Woo transformed himself from a general into South Korea's first directly elected president in decades, politicians of all stripes said they knew the solution for all of the country's ills: more democracy.    More democracy would bring an end to Government repression. Democracy would narrow the gaping separation between rich and poor. Best of all, democracy would mean that South Korea's students would find more creative pursuits than hurling Molotov cocktails and rocks at the riot police, and the police in turn would no longer seek any excuse to swing their truncheons.
lead_paragraph: WHEN the tear gas cleared in early 1988 and Roh Tae Woo transformed himself from a general into South Korea's first directly elected president in decades, politicians of all stripes said they knew the solution for all of the country's ills: more democracy.

abstract: An all-day funeral procession for a student beaten to death by the police turned into some of the fiercest anti-Government street battles since President Roh Tae Woo took office three years ago, setting streets aflame and covering much of the city in tear gas.   Unlike the 1987 protests, which ousted a military government and forced the first direct elections here in decades, the middle-class and white-collar workers watched from the sidelines, rarely entering the fray. Still, by most estimates more than 60,000 students and laborers joined in the protests, calling for the ouster of Mr. Roh's Cabinet and a wide range of economic and human-rights changes.
lead_paragraph: An all-day funeral procession for a student beaten to death by the police turned into some of the fiercest anti-Government street battles since President Roh Tae Woo took office three years ago, setting streets aflame and covering much of the city in tear gas.

abstract: When President Roh Tae Woo became this country's first democratically elected leader in several decades, South Koreans said the litmus test of his commitment to reform would be how he changed the much-dreaded National Security Law, used by a succession of military governments to suppress dissent and keep political opponents and labor leaders in jail.   Mr. Roh conceded that the law needed amending to prevent new human rights abuses, even while he was invoking it to keep his harshest critics off the streets. When it was finally amended Friday night, in a debate and vote that took 40 seconds and led to a melee on the floor of the Parliament, even many of Mr. Roh's staunchest defenders described the new law as only a slightly watered-down version of the old.
lead_paragraph: When President Roh Tae Woo became this country's first democratically elected leader in several decades, South Koreans said the litmus test of his commitment to reform would be how he changed the much-dreaded National Security Law, used by a succession of military governments to suppress dissent and keep political opponents and labor leaders in jail.

abstract: One of the more revealing moments in the flare-up of violence between student demonstrators and the South Korean Government over the last two weeks was the hasty retraction of comments by a senior member of the ruling party that the much-feared plainclothes riot police should be disbanded.     The politician, Kim Chong Hoh, the Democratic Liberal Party's floor leader in the National Assembly, told reporters he had asked the Interior Minister to dissolve these forces, which were notorious for their rough tactics long before they beat a student to death with steel pipes two weeks ago. But the party spokesman later insisted no such request had been made or was planned.

headline.main: SILVER AND GOLD Playing GamesNext week, the Treasury will destroy the dies used to make souvenir gold and silver coins for the Los Angeles Olympics. The coins, like the Games, were a roaring success, netting $65 million to help develop young Americans for future Games. Now let's hope the Games don't go the way of the dies. That gloomy thought derives from the disappointing results of the International Olympic Committee's recent meeting on anti-boycott strategy. Three consecutive boycotts, led by black Africans in 1976, America in 1980 and Russia this year, have diluted three consecutive Olympics. The I.O.C. confirmed its feeble reputation by deciding to do virtually nothing. Boycott possibilities remain serious. The I.O.C. chairman, Juan Antonio Samaranch, has reported receiving veiled threats that Russia, Poland and Cuba might boycott the 1988 games in South Korea.

abstract: In an unusual show of sensitivity to public opinion in a country where the Government has usually quelled dissent with a heavy hand, President Roh Tae Woo dismissed his Interior Minister over the weekend after the police reportedly beat a student protester to death with steel pipes.    Although South Korean university students often throw firebombs during demonstrations and the police frequently fire tear gas, this is the first case in which a student has been killed by police officers since 1987. Outrage over that incident helped bring down the Government of Chun Doo Hwan.
lead_paragraph: In an unusual show of sensitivity to public opinion in a country where the Government has usually quelled dissent with a heavy hand, President Roh Tae Woo dismissed his Interior Minister over the weekend after the police reportedly beat a student protester to death with steel pipes.

abstract: The Soviet Union and South Korea continued their whirlwind courtship Friday as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived here for his third meeting with South Korea's President, Roh Tae Woo, in 10 months and the first visit to this divided peninsula by a Soviet head of state.    While South Korea pledged $3 billion in economic aid earlier this year, Mr. Gorbachev is expected to seek more aid faster. In comments shortly after his late-evening arrival from Japan, where he received no commitments for economic assistance, Mr. Gorbachev said that the Seoul Government's offer was "badly needed" and that he hoped to "secure a setting for further economic cooperation."
lead_paragraph: The Soviet Union and South Korea continued their whirlwind courtship Friday as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived here for his third meeting with South Korea's President, Roh Tae Woo, in 10 months and the first visit to this divided peninsula by a Soviet head of state.

abstract:
A 68-year-old homeless man picked up by the police here Tuesday night is being held by the Coast Guard for deserting 41 years ago, during the Korean War. 

A Coast Guard spokesman said today that the man, Daniel Villalon, who has declined to be interviewed by reporters, had acknowledged deserting from the cutter Winona at Port Angeles, Wash., on Aug. 22, 1950, and living on the streets of San Francisco and other cities virtually the entire time since then. He is being held at the Coast Guard center on Government Island across the bay from here.

abstract: South Korea's Defense Minister said last week that his country might be forced to mount a commando raid against a nuclear installation near Pyongyang that experts believe could produce crude atomic weapons within five years. In response, North Korea accused the South today of issuing "virtually a declaration of war."    The South Korean Defense Minister, Lee Jong Koo, made his comments about the installation on Friday at a meeting with Korean editors, but retracted them that evening after they were reported by the South Korean press. It was the first time that any South Korean official had publicly suggested that a pre-emptive strike might be the best way to prevent North Korea from making nuclear weapons.
lead_paragraph: South Korea's Defense Minister said last week that his country might be forced to mount a commando raid against a nuclear installation near Pyongyang that experts believe could produce crude atomic weapons within five years. abstract: One of the lasting legacies of Japan's brutal occupation of Korea for most of the first half of this century is a nearly ironclad ban on Japanese culture. South Korea's theaters are forbidden from showing Japanese movies. Japanese-language pop songs are barred from airwaves. Seoul may be the only major capital in Asia where it is virtually impossible to find a Toyota on the streets.   But ever since Japan's semiofficial television network, NHK, began beaming its signals into Japanese homes by satellite -- and, more by accident than design, casting its signal over the Korean Peninsula as well -- hundreds of thousands of South Korean households have installed special dish antennas and television tuners. While in public they lament the cultural invasion of their fiercely nationalistic country, in private millions are tuning in to Japanese news, old samurai soap operas and all the movies the neighborhood videotape stores are not allowed to stock.
lead_paragraph: One of the lasting legacies of Japan's brutal occupation of Korea for most of the first half of this century is a nearly ironclad ban on Japanese culture. abstract: To the Editor:   As a doctoral candidate writing a dissertation on Japanese-Korean relations, I was not wholly satisfied with "The Next Renegade State," Leslie H. Gelb's April 10 column on North Korea.   I agree that North Korea and its not-yet-inspected nuclear facilities at Yongbyon present a potentially destabilizing threat to the region and that Tokyo should make International Atomic Energy Agency inspection of North Korean nuclear facilities and the end of North Korean arms sales a condition for normalization of relations and Japanese economic aid.

abstract: To the Editor:     I am replying to Robert J. Schwartz and David Morris, both of whom show bias against my Government and ignorance of the progress being made in the development of a democratic society in my country (letters, March 1).    Mr. Schwartz asserts the American group that accompanied Kim Dae Jung on his return to Korea ''did not go to Korea to interfere in that country's internal affairs'' and that giving public support to Mr. Kim ''should not be construed as such interference.''    Giving support to Mr. Kim may be their prerogative. But to physically resist and obstruct officials in the discharge of their duties (as members of the group did) exceeds even the realm of interference and is nothing less than a repudiation of the Korean Government's authority.

abstract: To the Editor:   The July 20 letter of Maj. Gen. D. K. Yoon, the Korean security attache, claiming that the American-headed United Nations command in Korea has never ''commanded any element of Korean forces,'' but only exerted operational control, confirms the need for our disengagement from an alarmingly ambivalent command situation, which could fly apart (as it almost did on entry into North Korea in early October 1950) if serious military stress were placed on it.   Establishment of the U.N. command responded to a July 7, 1950, Security Council vote requesting that all armed forces resisting the northern aggression, including South Korea's, be placed ''under a unified command headed by the United States.'' The command was comprehensive militarily and rapidly spread to civilian relief. On July 14, 1950, President Syngman Rhee ''placed the security forces of the Republic under General MacArthur, the U.N. commander.'' ''General Walker directed the R.O.K. army through its own chief of staff'' (page 112, U.S. Army Office of Military History account of the Korean War). Comprehensive ''command authority'' was awarded the U.N. commander. There is no evidence that the U.N. command was not intended to command or that those voting for it had any other intention.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: To the Editor:     Secretary Shultz's address to the U.N. General Assembly (news story Oct. 1) merits broad American support if applied not only in the Middle East but to tensions elsewhere.   ake Korea.  The Secretary pleads ''realism and readiness to work long and hard ... for solutions.'' For 34 years, we and South Korea have faced a hostile North Korea under the world's second most senior leader, Kim Il Sung. We, not Seoul, signed an armistice agreement with him in 1953. He wishes to deal with us and make peace after 29 years.

abstract: To the Editor:     Bruce Cumings's article includes at least two misstatements of fact concerning events that occurred during my time in office.  Referring to an incident at the factory of an American firm in Seoul in which two U.S. executives were detained by plant workers, Mr. Cumings says that ''... the American Embassy notified the Korean police and had the workers arrested.''   he embassy did notify Korean authorities of the plight of the two Americans and asked for assistance in freeing them. This was done by the Korean police, without violence. Several leaders of the workers' group were held briefly for questioning, but not at our behest.

abstract: To the Editor:   In ''Keep an Eye on South Korea'' (editorial, May 2), you emphasize the importance of Chun Doo Hwan's pledge ''to step down from office when his term ends in 1988'' and to turn over ''the presidency to a freely elected civilian.''   All this may happen, and yet it may not be a ''landmark in South Korea's political development'' for a number of reasons. First, under the present system of presidential election, an electoral college, the National Council for Unification, selects the president.

abstract: To the Editor:    The petty and quite un-American curbing of our right to a direct hearing of both sides of important issues cited by Bill Moyers (news story April 2) with regard to the State Department's refusal to extend Georgi Arbatov's visa to allow his appearance on a public Soviet-American televised debate wearily typifies years of State Department actions in another area - the North Koreans and their supporters in Japan.   I support the presence of American troops in South Korea. No one, however, can deny that 39,000 heavily-armed American troops in a distant peninsula never salient to our defense and belonging solely to Koreans raises important and debatable issues, both sides of which Americans must hear.

abstract: To the Editor:   President Reagan may deduce from the Korean airline tragedy that the U.S.S.R is a criminal nation, but there is a far more important warning to be drawn.   The shooting down of the 747 demonstrates that a combination of human errors, bureaucratic bumbling and technological malfunction can lead to a disaster that neither side intended. And that is the way World War III most likely will start. Those who survive will look back, as we are looking back now at the loss of 269 lives, and try to reconstruct how such a global calamity ever could have occurred. There will be no black box that may hold the explanation. ''Why wasn't the hot line used?'' they will ask, as we may well ask today.

abstract: To the Editor:    As a frequent visitor to Korea and a close observer of our policy toward that country, I could recognize neither the country nor our policy in Bruce Cumings's July 6 Op-Ed article, ''The Devil to Pay in Seoul.''   It is not by factual error but by omission that the picture is distorted.  Thus, Mr. Cumings notes that the current system is much less than democratic but fails to mention that reforms large and small are liberalizing the regime:   There is a de facto widening in the freedoms of expression (though formal restrictions remain in force); the stringent midnight-to-4 A.M. curfew has been abolished; travel restrictions have been eased, and the once-pervasive security-intelligence apparatus has been substantially disestablished, so that Koreans are no longer frightened into silence (note the many criticisms of the regime reported by Mr. Cumings).

abstract: To the Editor:    Your April 8 editorial ''The Worth of a Korean Promise'' is very nearly appalling when measured against the standards The Times professes to set for itself.   You say the ''voting'' was stacked to give the Government party a two-thirds margin in the National Assembly. We have seen no reports - from any source - of voting irregularities during the campaign. In fact Western observers agree the election was remarkably free of that sort of thing.

abstract: The General Dynamics Corporation's new agreement with South Korea to supply 120 F-16 fighter aircraft will provide nearly $2 billion in additional revenue to the military contractor through 1999, or one-third the projected contract total of $5 billion, company officials said today.    A formal contract between Washington and Seoul outlining the agreement is not expected until later this year. Industry analysts said General Dynamics would probably not see any financial impact before 1994, but that the new orders would slow the pace of layoffs on the F-16 assembly line.

abstract: To the Editor:   ''Since the Korean War,'' you reported, ''the commanding officer of the United States armed forces in South Korea has also served as the operational commander of South Korea's armed forces'' (''60 Students in Seoul Occupy U.S. Office,'' May 24). Similarly, Gregory Henderson stated (letter, May 11) that a four-star U.S. general exercises command authority over the land, sea and air forces of the Republic of Korea.   During the Korean War, the forces of South Korea and 16 other countries in Korea were placed under the operational control of the United Nations Command.

abstract: To the Editor:   The much-publicized airport incident that took place when Kim Dae Jung arrived in Seoul on Feb. 8 was unfortunate and, indeed, unnecessary (''Kim Dae Jung Is Beaten by Police on Arrival in Seoul, Escorts Say'').   Mr. Kim chose to return to Korea four days before the country's national assembly election, accompanied by American friends. On hand also was a planeload of foreign journalists, whose assignment was obviously to provide some spectacular coverage of his arrival. Did they really believe that any sort of physical harm might be inflicted on Mr. Kim by the Government? Even Mr. Kim, before his departure for Korea, observed such a thing was very unlikely.

abstract: To the Editor:    In your March 16 news article ''Chun Spares 2 Doomed in Korean Arson Case,'' you say that President Chun is ''considering a plan to amend the (Korean) Constitution to permit him to stay in office longer than his present seven-year term.'' This statement I categorically deny.   The Constitution of the Fifth Republic of Korea, promulgated on Oct. 27, 1980, provides in Article 45: ''The term of office of the President shall be seven years and the President shall not be reelected.''

abstract: To the Editor:   Are Daryl M. Plunk and Choi Sung-il describing the same country in their two Op-Ed articles under the headline ''What to Do About South Korea'' (June 24)? If all the Korean names were omitted, even those who disagree with Mr. Choi (''Stop Coddling the Regime'') would still recognize South Korea, but Mr. Plunk's article (''Encourage Both Sides to Talk'') would be hard to place.   He writes, for instance, ''there is agreement that the current clash over constitutional reform should be worked out by South Koreans in an atmosphere free from direct American interference.'' Is Mr. Plunk not aware that on May 7 Secretary of State George P. Shultz interfered directly in Korean politics by strongly supporting the Chun Doo Hwan Government and refusing to meet with Kim Dae Jung and Kim Young Sam (news story, May 8)?

abstract: To the Editor:     It has come to our attention that three prominent South Koreans have been arrested by the South Korean police simply for suggesting that recent North Korean initiatives on reunification be taken seriously. They are Kang Man'gil, Yi Yonghui and Cho Sunghyok.   Kang, one of Korea's leading historians, was some years ago forced from his chair at Koryo University because of his advocacy of democratic government. We know him not only through his scholarly writings but also through personal contact over the years, and we have come to respect him for his intellectual integrity.

abstract: To the Editor:     In response to Felice D. Gaer's letter of Sept. 14, I would like to explain Japan's views and actions concerning the repatriation of Koreans on Sakhalin Island.   First, the Japanese Government's ability to act on this matter is limited by the San Francisco Peace Treaty of 1952.   Secondly, despite this limitation, the Japanese Government is doing all that it can to facilitate a solution to this problem.

Pyongyang has made it clear that it wants the Korean peninsula free of nuclear weapons and that its interest in a nuclear reactor is for peaceful purposes.

abstract: To the Editor:    In a March 4 news article on South Korea, the Chun Doo Hwan regime is credited with reviving the economy and restoring political stability. Any informed observer of South Korea affairs, however, would question the validity of such an assessment.    As proof of the economic recovery, the article refers mainly to the growth of the G.N.P., a single-digit inflation and export expansion.  Unfortunately, the facts are inaccurate, and the understanding of economic reality is rather superficial.

abstract: To the Editor:      Donald Ranard's Oct. 14 Op-Ed article, ''Korea's Edgy D.M.Z. Extends to America,'' is fundamentally wrongheaded in its attempt to damn both South Korea and North Korea equally for the continuance of tensions on the Korean peninsula. It is simply out of tune with history.   The principal cause for the continued tension is North Korea's repeated violations of the Korean Armistice Agreement. By the latest count, North Korea has accused the U.N. (which administers the agreement) of almost 328,000 violations, of which the U.N. has admitted 107. The U.N., on its part, has accused North Korea of almost 76,000 violations, of which the North admitted two.

abstract: To the Editor:   This summer, the Government of Chun Doo Hwan in South Korea dropped its opposition to constitutional revision, raising the hopes of a peaceful resolution of the crisis in that country. There was much talk -mostly from the Government side -of great compromise, sharing of power, democratizing the government and the like.   Such hopes have been dealt a blow with disclosure by the ruling Democratic Justice Party of its design for the new constitution.

abstract: To the Editor:   In his letter (''In Korea, Democracy Is Still an Illusion,'' May 11), Sung-il Choi makes several errors in fact that need correction.   He states that under the present system of presidential elections in Korea, ''an electoral college, the National Council of Unification, elects the president.'' He then goes on to say that ''the system guarantees the triumph of a Government-favored candidate'' because the delegates to the electoral college ''are elected from a slate of candidates screened by the Government and are not bound to vote in selecting the president according to the preference of the citizens.''   What Mr. Choi describes as ''the present system'' is actually the former system under the so-called Yushin Constitution of Korea, which was replaced when the Constitution of the Fifth Republic was adopted in 1980. By way of explanation, the Yushin Constitution was written by President Park Chung Hee in 1972. Among other things, its language insured the incumbency of the then-president.

abstract: To the Editor:   It is of interest to compare the recent tragic and irresponsible downing of a Korean commercial airplane with a similar incident nearly 80 years ago.  The night of Oct. 21, 1904, during the Russo-Japanese War, units of the Russian Baltic fleet en route to the Far East, apparently believing they had already sighted the enemy, opened fire on British fishing trawlers off the coast of England - sinking at least one and killing several fishermen.

abstract: The Bush Administration has found fewer trade barriers in Japan than it did last year, but more in the European Community, Canada, Mexico, China, South Korea, India, Australia and Thailand, according to a special trade report published today. abstract: To the Editor:    We are pleased by reports that the South Korean Government does not plan to reimprison the opposition leader Kim Dae Jung when he returns home from two years of exile in the United States (''South Korea Says Dissident Won't Be Seized on Return,'' news article, Feb. 4).   Mr. Kim's patriotism, courage and commitment to democracy and fundamental human rights are a matter of record. It is characteristic of him that he responded to the South Korean Government's earlier threat of imprisonment by reaffirming his intention to return according to his announced schedule, on Feb. 8. One of his declared aims in returning at this time is to help make sure that the opposition remains moderate and nonviolent and to prevent the development of extreme political polarization.

abstract: To the Editor:     With attention riveted on the Korean airliner tragedy over Sakhalin Island, few know of another tragedy affecting Koreans living below, on territory alternately held by the Soviet Union and Japan.   Ethnic Koreans on Sakhalin since World War II are unable to leave it, due to policies of both the Soviet and Japanese Governments. Resolution of the plight of these other, unnoticed victims on Sakhalin would be an important humanitarian step toward restoring trust and good relations in that strategically sensitive area.

abstract: To the Editor:     After reading your Sept. 13 news article ''Vital Mistake Laid to South Korean Dissident,'' I realized once again how necessary it is to look at both sides of a story. Had I not been close to the scenes referred to in the article, I could have easily believed that the South Korean democratic leader Kim Dae Jung was to blame for his country's current tragic situation.   he logic of the article, primarily based on an interview with former President Yun Po Sun, is simple and clear: it was the split of the democratic forces in South Korea that invited the military to take power, and this split was caused by Kim Dae Jung's leaving the New Democratic Party (N.D.P.), the opposition party of the time.

abstract: To the Editor:   William Tucker asks: "What's the quickest way we can get our children away from these ethnically divisive zealots who have captured the public school system?" ("You Call This Giving Thanks? No Thanks," letter, Nov. 22). I suggest he send his son to a private, preferably religious school.   At my daughter's Roman Catholic school, all first, second and third graders came to school on the eve of Thanksgiving dressed as Indians or Pilgrims. The newly arrived pilgrims included three Koreans; the ranks of Indians were swollen with African-American, Columbian, Cuban and Egyptian children.   Each year on United Nations Day, Oct. 24, the children wear their native costumes, eat an international lunch cooked by school mothers, hear speeches and see films on the world's children and their needs, and respond actively to these needs through discussions, essay writing, poster making and collection of food and money for the United Nations Children's Fund and for those in need locally.   The only visible unity between church and state at this institution is that the children pray regularly for their political leaders, for peace in the world, for a healthier environment and for teachers and administrators in the local school system and borough government.    Perhaps next Thanksgiving, politicians and parents ought to give thanks to religious schools for promoting the values for which our forebears most struggled: liberty, justice and equality. PATRICIA LEFEVERE Tenafly, N.J., Nov. 22, 1990

abstract: A Navy intelligence report has named at least 14 nations outside the Soviet Union and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that are believed to possess chemical weapons, including American allies like Israel, Egypt, South Korea, Taiwan and Pakistan. It says 10 other nations are believed to be seeking chemical armaments.   The report says that Saudi Arabia, a most important United States ally in the Persian Gulf crisis, may also have chemical weapons.

abstract: To the Editor:   Edward W. Poitras's well-pitched call for ''serious adjustments in United States policy toward South Korea'' (Op-Ed, April 30) is more important than most realize.   A cogent case in point is the anachronistic ''U.N. command,'' exercised for 35 years by a four-star U.S. general. It incorporates ''command authority over all land, sea and air forces of the Republic of Korea'' given to it on July 14, 1950, by President Syngman Rhee under extreme duress from the North Korean inva-sion, to last ''during the period of continuation of the present state of hostilities.'' It has continued, with slight modification, ever since. Command of any third-world military forces is inevitably an extremely political position; in Seoul, it involves its holder in the vexed, still tightly controlled politics of South Korea on the side of those limiting free political expression. Even more dangerous, we have command without control.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: North Korea rejected a South Korean proposal today to reopen talks aimed at forming single teams for future international sports events, including the 1988 Summer Olympics, the South Korean Amateur Sports Association said. The North Korean decision, conveyed in a letter delivered in Panmunjom, held South Korea responsible for the failure to field a single team for the recent Games in Los Angeles.

abstract: LEAD: The Japanese Government plans to impose sanctions on North Korea for its suspected role in the destruction of a South Korean airliner Nov. 29 with 115 people aboard, news reports said today. Newspapers, quoting unidentified Foreign Ministry officials, said the measures would include a ban on North Korean officials entering Japan, and barring most trips to North Korea by Japanese officials.
lead_paragraph: The Japanese Government plans to impose sanctions on North Korea for its suspected role in the destruction of a South Korean airliner Nov. 29 with 115 people aboard, news reports said today. Newspapers, quoting unidentified Foreign Ministry officials, said the measures would include a ban on North Korean officials entering Japan, and barring most trips to North Korea by Japanese officials. A woman identified as a North Korean said she planted a bomb on the Korean Air Lines jet. North Korea has denied involvement.

abstract: North Korean officials have repeated their demand that North Korea join South Korea as co-host of the 1988 Summer Olympic Games, but this time the officials seem to be moderating their stance. Olympic officials who met with delegations from North and South Korea in Lausanne, Switzerland, said that Kim Yu Sun, the president of the North Korean Olympic Committee, had not repeated previous threats of a Soviet-bloc boycott if North Korea's demands were not met.

abstract: South Korea's Defense Minister said today that the military did not have tape recordings of North Korean loudspeaker broadcasts that were said to have reported the death of the North Korean leader this week.   The broadcasts formed the basis of South Korea's assertion Monday that the North Korean, Kim Il Sung, had died. That assertion was proved false on Tuesday, when the North Korean leader greeted a state visitor.

abstract: A South Korean investigating team says North Korean agents used a bomb filled with about 700 small ball bearings and an incendiary device in the explosion last Sunday that killed 17 South Koreans, including 4 Cabinet members.   A detailed preliminary report, made available today by non-South Korean diplomatic sources, concluded there was ''no doubt'' that the bombing at a memorial site north of Rangoon was the work of North Koreans.   The conclusion was said to be based on the type of explosives and other equipment used in the bombing as well as material seized from three suspects.

abstract:
The United States should start talking with North Korea.  Although 27 years have passed since the end of the Korean War, and while there have been a few meetings between representatives of North and South Korea, the two sides stand no closer to an agreement that would end the dispute between them and unify the country than they did in 1953. The two Koreas maintain two of the largest armies in the world, each ready to fight the other on a moment's notice.

The United States has a vital stake in guarding against the outbreak of another Korean war. This country has 40,000 troops stationed in South Korea. A defense treaty links our two nations: If South Korea is attacked, we would be expected to come to its aid.  Moreover, the Korean Peninsula lies in an extremely strategic location, bordering on China and separated by only a few hundred miles of water from Japan.

abstract: The International Olympic Committee today offered North Korea and South Korea a ''final'' compromise proposal designed to end their dispute over the 1988 Summer Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, and avert a possible boycott.   Juan Antonio Samaranch, the I.O.C. president, said the committee had offered North Korea the table tennis and archery events, and proposed that parts of the 60-mile cycling road race and the soccer competition be held on North Korean territory.
lead_paragraph: The International Olympic Committee today offered North Korea and South Korea a ''final'' compromise proposal designed to end their dispute over the 1988 Summer Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, and avert a possible boycott.

abstract: North Korea today rejected South Korea's latest proposal for reunification, insisting that United States troops be withdrawn from South Korea first.   In response to a plan announced Friday by President Chun Doo Hwan, North Korea said, ''To our regret, it cannot be considered a 'proposal' worthy of any positive significance.''   The North Korean press agency, in announcing the rejection, transmitted a speech by Vice President Kim Il, chairman of a North Korean committee for reunification, calling for acceptance of North Korea's own plan to end the 36-year division.
lead_paragraph: North Korea today rejected South Korea's latest proposal for reunification, insisting that United States troops be withdrawn from South Korea first.

abstract: Senior Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States had urged President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea to show restraint and not retaliate with force if it turned out that North Korea was responsible for the assassination of 16 South Koreans, including four Cabinet ministers, in Burma last weekend.   The officials said the Administration had been concerned ever since the bomb explosion on Sunday that Mr. Chun would order a military strike against the North Koreans or a large-scale commando action. The officials said it was feared such an action might rekindle hostilities between the two countries, which fought a war from 1950 to 1953 that involved the United States and China on opposite sides.   There are 39,000 American soldiers in South Korea, so any conflict would inevitably involve them, officials said. Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger was sent to lead the American delegation to the funeral of the slain South Koreans so as to reaffirm the American security shield for South Korea and to reinforce the advice for restraint.
lead_paragraph: Senior Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States had urged President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea to show restraint and not retaliate with force if it turned out that North Korea was responsible for the assassination of 16 South Koreans, including four Cabinet ministers, in Burma last weekend.

abstract: LEAD: President Roh Tae Woo announced today that South Korea would open its borders to goods and transportation from North Korea and predicted reunification in 10 years. He said at a meeting with South Korean citizens broadcast live on television that the North, which is Communist, and the South should build an economic system that would help lead to unity.
lead_paragraph: President Roh Tae Woo announced today that South Korea would open its borders to goods and transportation from North Korea and predicted reunification in 10 years. He said at a meeting with South Korean citizens broadcast live on television that the North, which is Communist, and the South should build an economic system that would help lead to unity. ''The administration will unrestrictedly allow the inflow from and through the North of aircraft, ships and other means of transport, as well as goods,'' he said.

abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz briefed senior South Korean officials here today on President Reagan's talks with Chinese leaders on the problems of North and South Korea and was described as having given reassurances that this country's interests were represented.    The United States, Mr. Shultz said before leaving this afternoon, was ''unwavering in its commitment to the freedom and security'' of South Korea.   The statement from the Secretary, who began his talks with South Korean officials on Tuesday, did not represent anything new. Nor, judging from the report he was said to have given the South Koreans, was there anything new in Mr. Reagan's conversations on Korea with the Chinese.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State George P. Shultz briefed senior South Korean officials here today on President Reagan's talks with Chinese leaders on the problems of North and South Korea and was described as having given reassurances that this country's interests were represented.

abstract: A crowd officially estimated at two million participated in an anti-Communist rally here today, burning effigies of President Kim Il Sung of North Korea and his son and heir apparent, Kim Chong Il.   The demonstration was organized by the South Korea Anti-Communist League on the eve of the 31st anniversary of the North Korean attack that started the Korean War.

abstract: LEAD: The narrow streets and small wooden homes look at first like any other Japanese neighborhood. But here and there, telltale signs appear - a sticker on a door with a tiny Korean flag, bolts of brightly colored Korean silk hanging in a shop window, posters of red-cheeked girls in Korean traditional dress, the kimchi pots of spicy pickled cabbage on display in the central market.

abstract: In the wake of the destruction of a Korean airliner carrying 269 people last week, South Korea will pull back from recent efforts to open diplomatic channels to the Soviet Union and other Communist countries, Government officials and foreign diplomats said today.    ''After this terrible incident, there has to be some change,'' a senior Government official said.   South Korean officials stressed that in the immediate aftermath of the tragedy, long-term foreign policy was not being set, but they added that a shift was inevitable.   In its battle with North Korea to be recognized as the only legitimate representative of the Korean people, South Korea has constantly tried to gain greater international recognition. In recent years, Seoul has made particular efforts to begin to normalize relations with Peking and Moscow, hoping to soften the support for North Korea from its principal sponsors.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of the destruction of a Korean airliner carrying 269 people last week, South Korea will pull back from recent efforts to open diplomatic channels to the Soviet Union and other Communist countries, Government officials and foreign diplomats said today.

abstract: A Defense Department audit shows that the South Korean Government has refused to pay its full share for combined military operations in South Korea.   Although the amounts involved are small by Defense Department standards, the audit disclosed long-running irritations that a senior official said would be given priority when Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger meets with Korean leaders in Seoul during the spring.   ''When it comes to financial matters,'' a Defense Department official said, ''the Koreans are tough people to do business with.''
lead_paragraph: A Defense Department audit shows that the South Korean Government has refused to pay its full share for combined military operations in South Korea.

abstract: Defense Secretary Caspar W.  Weinberger ended a two-day meeting with South Korean military leaders today in which he promised them sophisticated weapons and economic concessions.   In a joint communique, Mr. Weinberger and the South Korean Defense Minister, Choo Young Bock, warned that continuing military buildup in North Korea poses a serious threat to South Korea. No details on the buildup were released.

abstract: LEAD:  Koreans in New York  There are, according to the Korean Grocers Association, about 1,000 Korean greengrocers in the city (and 1,000 Korean fish markets, 1,000 laundries, not more than 50 Korean grocery stores and about 45,000 Koreans). This familiar and recent New York phenomenon is the subject of today's talk in the Asia Society's continuing series of Wednesday lectures, ''Discover Asia: Asian-Americans in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Koreans in New York There are, according to the Korean Grocers Association, about 1,000 Korean greengrocers in the city (and 1,000 Korean fish markets, 1,000 laundries, not more than 50 Korean grocery stores and about 45,000 Koreans). This familiar and recent New York phenomenon is the subject of today's talk in the Asia Society's continuing series of Wednesday lectures, ''Discover Asia: Asian-Americans in New York City.'' The topic, ''Your Korean Corner Grocery,'' will be discussed by Illsoo Kim, a professor at Drew University.

abstract: The presidents of the Olympic committees of North and South Korea have agreed to meet in Lausanne, Switzerland, in early January for a new effort to reach agreement on the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, the International Olympic Committee reported. Fears had been expressed earlier that the scheduled second meeting on North Korea's demand to be co-host of the 1988 Games might never take place. But officials at I.O.C. headquarters here said Chong-Ha Kim, president of South Korea's National Olympic Committee, and Yu Sun Kim, president of North Korea's national committee, both advised Juan Antonio Samaranch of Spain, the president of the international committee, that they would attend the meeting planned Jan. 8 and 9.
lead_paragraph: The presidents of the Olympic committees of North and South Korea have agreed to meet in Lausanne, Switzerland, in early January for a new effort to reach agreement on the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, the International Olympic Committee reported. Fears had been expressed earlier that the scheduled second meeting on North Korea's demand to be co-host of the 1988 Games might never take place. But officials at I.O.C. headquarters here said Chong-Ha Kim, president of South Korea's National Olympic Committee, and Yu Sun Kim, president of North Korea's national committee, both advised Juan Antonio Samaranch of Spain, the president of the international committee, that they would attend the meeting planned Jan. 8 and 9.

abstract: After more than a year of unusually steady and even amicable negotiations, South Korean officials say no substantive progress has been made with North Korea on possible two-way trade and large-scale exchanges of war-separated families.   Despite the pessimistic assessment, however, officials say that they are not disappointed and that they will pursue talks with the North into 1986.   ''We did not anticipate that any rapid progress would be made,'' said South Korea's Foreign Minister, Lee Won-kyung, in an interview this week.   ''It will take a very, very long time,'' he said. ''But this is the best way to keep North Korea under control and to ease tensions of the Korean peninsula.''
lead_paragraph: After more than a year of unusually steady and even amicable negotiations, South Korean officials say no substantive progress has been made with North Korea on possible two-way trade and large-scale exchanges of war-separated families.

abstract: The tour President Reagan plans to take of the demilitarized zone in Korea will come at a time of renewed tension between the northern and southern portions of that divided nation. lead_paragraph: The ideal Korea is a united peninsula, neutral in the tug-of-war of great power politics and able to defend itself without reliance on foreign aid or arms. "We could be the strongest country in Asia," a Korean army officer once told me in a moment of drunken enthusiasm on a long train ride. "We will be strong again."
