abstract: After touring a segment of South Korea's front line today, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger returned to Seoul and renewed the Reagan Administration's commitment to South Korean security.   Mr. Weinberger, on the second stop of a trip through Japan, South Korea and the Philippines, flew by helicopter to the heavily fortified demilitarized zone that divides this peninsula. He had lunch with G.I.'s of the Second Infantry Division and inspected one of their outposts facing North Korea.
lead_paragraph: After touring a segment of South Korea's front line today, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger returned to Seoul and renewed the Reagan Administration's commitment to South Korean security.

abstract: North and South Korea failed today after two days of talks to find a way of sharing the 1988 Olympic Summer Games, but the countries agreed to meet again next January. abstract: U.S. NOW SAYS SOLDIER WENT OVER TO THE NORTH KOREANS VOLUNTARILY   SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 2 (UPI) - United States officials said today that an American soldier who North Korea said had defected shot a lock off a guardpost gate and voluntarily crossed the demilitarized zone to North Korea.   The North Koreans have said that the soldier, Pfc. Joseph T. White of St. Louis, deserted his unit on Saturday, crossed the border and sought political refuge after criticizing the stationing of 40,000 American troops in South Korea.
lead_paragraph: U.S. NOW SAYS SOLDIER WENT OVER TO THE NORTH KOREANS VOLUNTARILY

abstract: A succession of ''firsts,'' some of them eye-catching, have been registered recently in relations between North and South Korea. Last September, for the first time, convoys of trucks brought relief goods from North to South. Then, North Korean cargo ships, also carrying flood relief supplies, docked at a South Korean port for the first time. Soon after, the two sides opened their first negotiation on possible economic cooperation.   Technically speaking, last week's development was not a ''first.'' Nevertheless, for the first time in a dozen years, a large contingent of North Koreans came to Seoul, to resume high-level Red Cross talks mothballed in 1973. The negotiators' agenda was the elusive, arguably unattainable, goal of reuniting millions of families separated for four decades by war and the barely penetrable curtain between the two Koreas. The Red Cross delegations met twice, for a total of nearly four hours, at a Las Vegas-style hotel where the 84 North Koreans, in their identical blue-gray suits, looked out of place.
lead_paragraph: A succession of ''firsts,'' some of them eye-catching, have been registered recently in relations between North and South Korea. Last September, for the first time, convoys of trucks brought relief goods from North to South. Soon after, the two sides opened their first negotiation on possible economic cooperation.

abstract: South Korea announced today that North Korean loudspeakers along the border had reported that Kim Il Sung, the North's leader, had been shot to death.   The reports could not be independently confirmed, and the North Korean embassies in Peking and New Delhi issued denials, deepening the uncertainty. The embassy in Peking called the report ''a total fabrication.''   In New Delhi, a North Korean diplomat said, ''In my opinion these reports are not true and are actually South Korean propaganda.'' No U.S. Confirmation    A spokesman for United States forces in South Korea said that they had ''no independent confirmation'' that the North Koreans had made any announcement over the loudspeakers across the demilitarized zone.  [ In Washington, high-level military sources said the Pentagon had received reports of Mr. Kim's death as early as Saturday. They said no special alert had been ordered for American forces in the region. ]  A Cult of Personality The death of Mr. Kim would have a great effect not only on North-South relations in Korea but also on security considerations throughout the region.
lead_paragraph: South Korea announced today that North Korean loudspeakers along the border had reported that Kim Il Sung, the North's leader, had been shot to death.

abstract: The Burmese Government announced today that two North Korean army officers would go on trial Tuesday for the bombing last month that killed 21 people, including four South Korean Cabinet ministers. The Government says there is firm evidence that the two took part in the Oct. 9 bombing just before a wreath-laying ceremony at the Martyrs' Mausoleum north of Rangoon. Official sources have said the North Koreans would be tried for murder and illegal possession of weapons.

abstract: Four North Korean cargo ships loaded with relief supplies sailed into this port today, an unprecedented event that went unnoticed by virtually everyone who lives here.    Never before had a North Korean vessel entered a South Korean harbor for peaceful purposes. The four ships pulled up alongside a large cargo terminal in darkness early this morning, and then allowed dozens of South Korean laborers on board to unload 25,000 tons of cement intended to aid flood victims in nearby Seoul.   It was a landmark contact between countries that have been implacable enemies, maintaining a steady war of propaganda and mutual denunciation since their three-year shooting war ended in 1953.

abstract: Seoul Links Bombing To a Planned Invasion    WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (Reuters) - Foreign Minister Lee Won Kyung of South Korea said today that the bombing in Burma that killed 16 South Koreans last month was believed to be part of a plan meant to lead to an invasion of South Korea.   Mr. Lee said his Government believed North Korea planned to send agents to the South after the bombing to stage incidents and then invade on the pretext that it was supporting a popular uprising.

abstract: Two Chinese men have been arrested and charged with spying for South Korea, the Chinese television said tonight. It said the pair, Li Xihua and Zho Yongdou, were arrested by public security officials at Tumen, in Jilin Province near the border with North Korea. The television said the two were recruited by Seoul officials when they visited their relatives in South Korea in 1985.
lead_paragraph: Two Chinese men have been arrested and charged with spying for South Korea, the Chinese television said tonight. It said the pair, Li Xihua and Zho Yongdou, were arrested by public security officials at Tumen, in Jilin Province near the border with North Korea. The television said the two were recruited by Seoul officials when they visited their relatives in South Korea in 1985.

abstract: LEAD: South Korea's real gross national product will grow more than 10 percent this year, up from a target of 8 percent, Deputy Prime Minister Chong In Yong said today. He also said that the South Korean currency, the won, was expected to rise further. The nation's G.N.P. rose 15.6 percent in January-March 1987 from the comparable 1986 period, according to provisional Bank of Korea figures, making it the highest quarterly growth rate in eight years.

abstract: LEAD: South Korea's fledgling second airline, Asiana, made its inaugural international flight today when a Boeing 737-400 flew to Tokyo from Seoul with 147 passengers, a company spokesman said. The private airline, competing with Korean Air Lines, also privately owned, will fly to Tokyo four times a week.
lead_paragraph: South Korea's fledgling second airline, Asiana, made its inaugural international flight today when a Boeing 737-400 flew to Tokyo from Seoul with 147 passengers, a company spokesman said. The private airline, competing with Korean Air Lines, also privately owned, will fly to Tokyo four times a week. Asiana began domestic flights in December 1988 and now serves 10 domestic routes. The airline is owned by the Kumho Group, which also operates a road transport network.

abstract: LAST July 21, the Republic of Korea agreed with the United States to increase its protection of patents, copyrights and trademarks. The negotiations were difficult, in part because the changes were widely viewed in Korea as having been won by the economic power of a large country from a smaller one. The United States claimed that Korea must change its intellectual property rules in order to insure international norms of fairness.   The Korean public, however, remembers that the United States was not as preoccupied about fairness when it enjoyed a trade surplus with Korea, a situation that lasted for nearly 40 years and only ended a few years ago. And today, more than one-third of Korea's annual exports to the United States are covered by such import restrictions as quotas, excessive ''dumping'' margins and repetitious ''temporary'' relief measures.
lead_paragraph: LAST July 21, the Republic of Korea agreed with the United States to increase its protection of patents, copyrights and trademarks. abstract: THE KOREAN WAR Challenges in Crisis, Credibility, and Command. By Burton I. Kaufman. Maps. 381 pp. Philadelphia: Temple University Press. $34.95.    THE Korean conflict did for the cold war what the Japanese bombing of Pearl Harbor did for World War II - globalized it. Before the Korean War, the only American political or military commitment outside the Western hemisphere had been the North Atlantic Treaty in Europe. By 1955, the United States had several hundred bases in 36 countries. As a result of the Korean War, the United States began to perceive the struggle with the Soviet Union as broad and global rather than in terms of Europe alone.
lead_paragraph: THE KOREAN WAR Challenges in Crisis, Credibility, and Command. By Burton I. Kaufman. Maps. 381 pp. Philadelphia: Temple University Press. $34.95.

abstract: South Korea has asked Japan for $6 billion in economic aid, but officials here say that, while they plan to increase their assistance to the Seoul Government, it will be nothing like the amount requested.   In the last fiscal year Japan provided $83 million to South Korea.  South Korea's Foreign Minister, Lho Shin Yong, asked Foreign Minister Sunao Sonoda of Japan yesterday for an increase of ''official development aid,'' meaning low-interest state loans, to $6 billion over a five-year period starting in 1982.   ''It would be extremely difficult for us to meet your request,'' the Japanese press quoted Mr. Sonoda as having said. Japanese officials are expected to agree to an increase in aid in this fiscal year, which started April 1, but nothing like the amount sought by the Koreans, which would represent a 14-fold increase.
lead_paragraph: South Korea has asked Japan for $6 billion in economic aid, but officials here say that, while they plan to increase their assistance to the Seoul Government, it will be nothing like the amount requested.

abstract: Secretary of State George P. Shultz protested to the Soviet Union today and expressed regret to South Korea about the Soviet refusal to allow South Korea to be represented when debris from the downed Korean jet was turned over, State Department spokesmen said.   John Hughes, the State Department spokesman, said Mr. Shultz met at the United Nations with Lee Bum Suk, Foreign Minister of South Korea.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State George P. Shultz protested to the Soviet Union today and expressed regret to South Korea about the Soviet refusal to allow South Korea to be represented when debris from the downed Korean jet was turned over, State Department spokesmen said.

abstract: Nancy Reagan received an unexpected gift from 2,000 Korean orphans today: a chorus of ''God Bless America'' at the end of a busy day.   As Mr. Reagan toured military installations at the demilitarized zone, Mrs. Reagan watched traditional Korean dancing, met prominent South Korean women and visited an orphanage to which she donated a piano.   The visit to the Seoul Boys Town, run by the Rev. Aloysius Schwartz, a Roman Catholic priest from Washington, D.C., featured ballet and Korean songs and dances in the orphanage auditorium.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Reagan received an unexpected gift from 2,000 Korean orphans today: a chorus of ''God Bless America'' at the end of a busy day.

abstract: LEAD: South Korea's trade surplus with the United States is expected to widen to $8.5 billion in 1987, up from $7.4 billion last year, Korea's Trade Minister said Friday. The Trade Minister, Rha Woong Bae, told Parliament that the country recorded a $6 billion surplus with the United States for the first eight months of this year.
lead_paragraph: South Korea's trade surplus with the United States is expected to widen to $8.5 billion in 1987, up from $7.4 billion last year, Korea's Trade Minister said Friday. The Trade Minister, Rha Woong Bae, told Parliament that the country recorded a $6 billion surplus with the United States for the first eight months of this year. These figures suggest that South Korea will face increasing pressure from Washington, which is threatening curbs on Asian imports to the United States.

abstract: LEAD: South Korea's rapidly growing electronics industry has become the country's second business sector to exceed $10 billion in annual exports, the Trade and Industry Ministry reported today. Ministry officials said that exports of Korean electronic products since January reached $10.02 billion on Wednesday and were expected to climb to $11 billion by year-end.
lead_paragraph: South Korea's rapidly growing electronics industry has become the country's second business sector to exceed $10 billion in annual exports, the Trade and Industry Ministry reported today. Ministry officials said that exports of Korean electronic products since January reached $10.02 billion on Wednesday and were expected to climb to $11 billion by year-end. Last year, electronics exports totaled $6.7 billion. Korean textile exports since January reached $10 billion on Nov. 11.

abstract: A Soviet defector said today that he had acted of his ''own free will'' when he bolted from North Korea into South Korean territory, touching off a fatal gun battle here in the heart of the demilitarized zone.    Vasily Yakovlevich Matuzok, 22 years old, said that he had decided to defect two years ago and that he chose to act Friday while touring Panmunjom because it was his ''very first opportunity to go to the West.''    Mr. Matuzok has been kept in seclusion at a United States military hospital in Seoul. But American officers in Panmunjom showed a videotape of an interview they had held with him to counter North Korean charges that he had been taken to the south by force.
lead_paragraph: A Soviet defector said today that he had acted of his ''own free will'' when he bolted from North Korea into South Korean territory, touching off a fatal gun battle here in the heart of the demilitarized zone.

abstract: The Soviet refusal to participate in the Olympic Games in Los Angeles this summer has raised concern among South Korean officials about possible effects on the 1988 Games to be held in Seoul.    South Korea is investing much of its prestige on its ability to organize the 1988 Games successfully and perhaps also to draw teams from Communist countries aligned with North Korea. The Soviet-bloc boycott of the Los Angeles Olympics, however, has raised questions in Seoul about whether these countries will now even consider going to South Korea.   A less immediate worry, but one that some South Koreans say they believe cannot be ignored, is a possible international drive to end the Games or to move them permanently to a politically neutral site.
lead_paragraph: The Soviet refusal to participate in the Olympic Games in Los Angeles this summer has raised concern among South Korean officials about possible effects on the 1988 Games to be held in Seoul.

abstract: For the last three weeks the Japanese police have been preoccupied with what could be called the Great Balloon Mystery.   Hundreds of vinyl balloons, most of them more than 20 feet high, have fallen on fields and towns across the length of Japan. By Friday afternoon the National Police Agency put the total at 323, including one that had landed overnight near the runway of the international airport at Narita, outside Tokyo.   No one was certain what it all meant, but from the Korean lettering found on a few balloons, some Japanese suspected they were getting the fallout from the latest round in the endless propaganda war between North and South Korea.
lead_paragraph: For the last three weeks the Japanese police have been preoccupied with what could be called the Great Balloon Mystery.

abstract: In a bold drive to line up with several more prosperous Western nations helping the Soviet Union, South Korea has started talks with Moscow that officials here say could lead to several billion dollars in trade, investment and aid in the next five years.    On Thursday, President Roh Tae Woo is to become the first leader of South Korea to visit the Soviet Union, a trip scheduled less than three months after the two countries established diplomatic relations, formally ending a long period of hostility dating from the Korean War 40 years ago.

abstract: Around the World; Korean Dissidents Burn A U.S. Mission in Pusan   SEOUL, South Korea, March 19 (UPI) - Dissidents demanding that Washington withdraw its 40,000 troops from South Korea set fire to an American Government office in the first attack on an American mission in South Korean history.   Leaflets distributed at the mission in Pusan just before the fire on Thursday warned of more anti-American attacks, the police said.

abstract: An explosion apparently caused by a powerful bomb killed 5 people and wounded 36 others, 21 seriously, Sunday as they stood outside a terminal building at Kimpo International Airport here.   The chief of the South Korean national police, Kang Min Chang, strongly suggested that North Korea was responsible, although he stopped short of making a formal accusation.   All of those killed or wounded were said to be South Koreans. The original police report said 19 people were injured, and there was no explanation for the sharp revision in the official casualty figures.
lead_paragraph: An explosion apparently caused by a powerful bomb killed 5 people and wounded 36 others, 21 seriously, Sunday as they stood outside a terminal building at Kimpo International Airport here.

abstract: LEAD: The head of the International Olympic Committee said yesterday that he was certain Communist-bloc countries would ignore any call by North Korea to boycott the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul. Speaking at a news conference in Lausanne, Switzerland, Juan Antonio Samaranch, the I.O.C. president, said his organization was unwilling to add any sports to the four from the Seoul Games it has proposed placing in North Korea.
lead_paragraph: The head of the International Olympic Committee said yesterday that he was certain Communist-bloc countries would ignore any call by North Korea to boycott the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul. Speaking at a news conference in Lausanne, Switzerland, Juan Antonio Samaranch, the I.O.C. president, said his organization was unwilling to add any sports to the four from the Seoul Games it has proposed placing in North Korea. He called the I.O.C. offer ''a very generous proposal, a historic one.'' North Korean officials said Thursday night that they had accepted the four-sport plan ''in principle'' but that they wanted an additional five or six sports. They have threatened to lead a boycott of Seoul if their demands are not met.

abstract: About 60 South Korean students peacefully occupied a United States Government office here today. They vowed to stay until the American Government apologized for what they said was its complicity in the suppression of a 1980 political uprising.   They also demanded that the South Korean Government investigate the episode, which occurred in the provincial capital of Kwangju five years ago this week. About 200 people are believed to have been slain in the uprising, although the students say more were killed than that, and the Government says less than 200 died.
lead_paragraph: About 60 South Korean students peacefully occupied a United States Government office here today. They vowed to stay until the American Government apologized for what they said was its complicity in the suppression of a 1980 political uprising.

abstract: South Korea is making slow progress in opening its markets to trade with the United States and other countries, the assistant United States trade representative, Peter Allgeier, said today.   ''It is important to recognize that the Korean Government, unlike most other developing countries, unilaterally has adopted a timetable for further liberalizing its economy,'' Mr. Allgeier said in testimony to a House special subcommittee on United States-Pacific Rim trade.

abstract: The United States has threatened to expel a high-ranking North Korean diplomat because his mission has been protecting a junior official from arrest for sexual abuse, aides in the United States delegation said today.   Officials from the United Nations, the United States and the North Korean Mission today discussed a North Korean request to delay the expulsion for one week. The talks ended tonight with no agreement, but United Nations officials said they would be continued.

abstract: Faced with increasing resentment of this country's economic success, South Korea's Government economists have mapped a plan to stress cooperation rather than confrontation with the United States.    This year, the nation will once again record steady economic expansion, but to insure that such growth continues, the Government is working to promote Korean investments overseas, entice foreign investments to Korea and reduce the nation's current-account deficit.    A key part of the strategy involves forging closer ties with United States companies to gain allies against American protectionism. Such ties would also improve the competitiveness of American products by making use of lower-cost Korean labor or components.

abstract: The Origins of the Korean War Liberation and the Emergence of Separate Regimes, 1945-1947.  By Bruce Cumings.  606 pp. Princeton: Princeton University Press Cloth, $40. Paper, $14.95 Korea The Untold Story of the War.  By Joseph C. Goulden.  Illustrated. 690 pp. New York: Times Books. $22.50 By John Curtis Perry   Before June 25, 1950, and the outbreak of "our war" in Korea, most Americans had scarcely heard of that nation. Yet the "Hermit Kingdom," as Westerners called it in the 19th century, had already emerged as the cockpit of modern East Asia, a focus for Great Power rivalries. Foreign nations had fought twice on Korean soil within the preceding 60 years: Japan first defeated China (1894-95), then Russia, 10 years later, with the Koreans as hapless bystanders. The fate of their nation seemed to rest in the hands of outsiders.   After the Russo-Japanese War, Korea slipped into the orbit of Japan, that nearby, newly imperialist power. When the Japanese formally annexed Korea in 1910, not one foreign nation protested.
lead_paragraph: The Origins of the Korean War Liberation and the Emergence of Separate Regimes, 1945-1947. By Bruce Cumings. 606 pp. Princeton: Princeton University Press Cloth, $40. Paper, $14.95 Korea The Untold Story of the War. By Joseph C. Goulden. Illustrated. 690 pp. New York: Times Books. $22.50 By John Curtis Perry

abstract: Excerpts from speech, page 6.         SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, Nov. 12 - President Reagan arrived in this tense nation today with a message denouncing North Korea and encouraging South Korea to pursue democratic change as the ''foundation of true security.''   ''Let every aggressor hear our words because Americans and Koreans speak with one voice,'' Mr. Reagan said in a speech to Parliament. ''People who are free will not be slaves, and freedom will not be lost in the Republic of Korea.''

abstract: The Soviet Union, which has nurtured closer ties with North Korea in recent years, withheld comment today on conflicting reports of political turmoil in that country.   If Soviet officials knew whether Kim Il Sung, the North Korean leader, had been killed or ousted, as unconfirmed reports from South Korea asserted, they were not talking publicly about it.   Moscow's stake in any leadership change would be considerable because of North Korea's efforts over the years not to side with either China or the Soviet Union in disputes between these two countries.

abstract:
South Korean President Chun Doo Hwan's visit to the White House last week has been described as a particularly cordial meeting that fully reaffirmed the security ties between the two countries. In fact, it is unlikely that these talks penetrated much below the surface or recognized the need for serious readjustments in United States policy toward South Korea.

The legislative elections held in South Korea in February clearly highlighted this need. The campaign period, abbreviated as it was, allowed a more open political discussion than any in memory. In stumping sessions in which all parties shared the same rostrum, daring opposition speakers reached out to an enthusiastic electorate, drawing quite unexpected support for the newly formed opposition group, the New Korea Democratic Party. When the vote came, the ruling Democratic Justice Party was challenged by a popular outpouring of dissatisfaction.

abstract: The South Korean Government is making preparations to free Kim Dae Jung, Seoul's most prominent political prisoner, on Saturday, dissidents and Korean diplomats here said today.   Mr. Kim, who was arrested on April 17, 1980, is serving a life sentence on charges of sedition.  His expected release is seen here as a sign of liberalization by the army-backed Government of President Chun Doo Hwan.

abstract: LEAD: The problems the Navy is encountering with mines in the Persian Gulf have old Navy hands in the Pentagon recalling a similarly frustrating episode during the Korean War. In October 1950, the Navy was assigned to put marines ashore to capture the port of Wonsan in North Korea, which first required clearing mines from the approach areas.

abstract: The General Motors Corporation said that it had signed a memorandum of agreement with the Daewoo Corporation, a South Korean conglomerate, to produce a small Opel automobile beginning in the 1987 model year. The company said a new plant in Bupyeong, South Korea, near Seoul, would be able to produce 167,000 cars annually.

abstract: LEAD: South Korea will keep the won's exchange rate at its present level despite United States pressure to revalue the currency and threats of trade sanctions, Government officials said on Sunday. They said economic planners, in weekend meetings called to prepare for South Korea's trade talks in Washington beginning Tuesday, also decided to resist a drive to open Seoul's markets further to United States farm products.
lead_paragraph: South Korea will keep the won's exchange rate at its present level despite United States pressure to revalue the currency and threats of trade sanctions, Government officials said on Sunday. They said economic planners, in weekend meetings called to prepare for South Korea's trade talks in Washington beginning Tuesday, also decided to resist a drive to open Seoul's markets further to United States farm products.

abstract: OF ALL THE SORRY STORIES OF the Korean War, one of the saddest is its legacy -- that of a war whose cease-fire is remembered in America perhaps less for the end of the carnage than as the inspiration for the final episode of "M*A*S*H."    Korea was a war without a winner, a three-year conflict that ended with millions of Koreans and tens of thousands of United Nations and American troops dead. It was a war that introduced to the vocabulary of the cold war era such terms as "police action," "limited war" and "brainwashing," a war of carpet bombing and napalm whose victims were mostly civilians.
lead_paragraph: OF ALL THE SORRY STORIES OF the Korean War, one of the saddest is its legacy -- that of a war whose cease-fire is remembered in America perhaps less for the end of the carnage than as the inspiration for the final episode of "M*A*S*H."

abstract: South Korea's national police booked six more opposition lawmakers today for investigation in connection with a brawl at a meeting called by the governing party to approve the national budget. abstract: LEAD: South Korea's trade surplus was basically steady in May, at $348 million, compared with $349 million a year earlier, but the results so far ths year remain well ahead of 1986 levels, the Government said today. abstract: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone will visit South Korea next week for talks with President Chun Doo Hwan on a multibillion dollar aid agreement for Seoul, the Japanese Foreign Ministry announced today.   The visit is considered significant because it will come shortly before Mr. Nakasone travels to Washington for his first meeting with President Reagan as the head of Japan's Government. Mr. Nakasone will fly to Seoul next Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone will visit South Korea next week for talks with President Chun Doo Hwan on a multibillion dollar aid agreement for Seoul, the Japanese Foreign Ministry announced today.

abstract: The Reagan Administration pressed Congress today for more arms aid to South Korea and Thailand, citing what it called a growing Soviet-supported military threat to those countries.   One official told a Senate subcommittee under questioning that the United States would have to decide whether to send more troops to South Korea if the Soviet Union significantly increased its aid to North Korea.   ''In the event of precipitous action, we would have to consider what action we would take,'' Charles Jameson, deputy chief of the Defense Department's East Asian Division, told the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee.
lead_paragraph: The Reagan Administration pressed Congress today for more arms aid to South Korea and Thailand, citing what it called a growing Soviet-supported military threat to those countries.

abstract: Security agents checked hotel rooms, stopped cars and searched for weapons today in what the Burmese Government called an intensive hunt for assassins who bombed a memorial site Sunday, killing 16 South Korean visitors.   The explosion at the Martyrs' Mausoleum north of Rangoon also killed three Burmese and wounded 48 people. President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea, whose motorcade was delayed by traffic on the way to a ceremony at the shrine, had a narrow escape. Mr. Chun, who was visiting Burma on the first day of a scheduled 18-day Asian tour, immediately flew back to Seoul.
lead_paragraph: Security agents checked hotel rooms, stopped cars and searched for weapons today in what the Burmese Government called an intensive hunt for assassins who bombed a memorial site Sunday, killing 16 South Korean visitors.

abstract: Canada will not extend a 60-day ban on the Soviet airline Aeroflot, External Affairs Minister Allan MacEachen said today. Canada was the first to act after the Russians downed a South Korean airliner on Sept. 1, killing 269 people. Aeroflot previously flew twice-weekly flights to Montreal, its only direct air link with North America.

abstract: A police case involving a North Korean diplomat who has been secluded in his country's mission in Manhattan for almost three months rather than face charges of sexual abuse has grown into a diplomatic issue with international repercussions.   North Korean and American diplomats remain intransigent over their conflicting definitions of diplomatic immunity, as the police wait to serve an arrest warrant.   And now at stake are issues of international law being brought before a United Nations committee, the status of a group of North Korean diplomats stationed in Moscow waiting for visas to enter this country, and a letter accompanying the Moscow group, according to a North Korean diplomat, that was written by a United States Army private who entered North Korea last summer under mysterious circumstances.   The incident began on Sept. 5, a Sunday afternoon. A 43-year-old woman said she had been attacked by an assailant she described as ''an Oriental-looking man'' while she was walking along a bridle path at Twin Lakes Reservoir in the Town of Eastchester in Westchester County.
lead_paragraph: A police case involving a North Korean diplomat who has been secluded in his country's mission in Manhattan for almost three months rather than face charges of sexual abuse has grown into a diplomatic issue with international repercussions.

abstract: Juan Antonio Samaranch , the president of the International Olympic Committee, said the 1988 Summer Games would be in Seoul, South Korea, despite fears of another Soviet-led boycott. abstract: It has been 50 years since a Korean marathoner named Sohn Kee Chung captured the gold medal at the Berlin Olympics. Even now, Sohn says, he can feel the ''jubilation and agony'' of that moment. His agony was that he had to climb onto the victory stand with the flag of Japan emblazoned on his jersey. His country was then under Japanese colonial rule. The anthem played in the Berlin stadium was Japan's. The name that went into the record books was the Japanese version that had been forced on him, Kitei Son.
lead_paragraph: It has been 50 years since a Korean marathoner named Sohn Kee Chung captured the gold medal at the Berlin Olympics. Even now, Sohn says, he can feel the ''jubilation and agony'' of that moment. His agony was that he had to climb onto the victory stand with the flag of Japan emblazoned on his jersey. His country was then under Japanese colonial rule. The anthem played in the Berlin stadium was Japan's. The name that went into the record books was the Japanese version that had been forced on him, Kitei Son.

abstract: In a move hailed as significant by book industry officials, a leading South Korean book publisher recently negotiated contracts with an American literary agency for 10 books by Alvin Toffler. Moreover, several other South Korean publishers have signed contracts in recent weeks to pay royalties for books by Norman Mailer, Leo Buscaglia, Carl Sagan, Daniel Boorstin, Ken Follett and Senators William S. Cohen and Gary Hart.   The contracts are unusual because South Korea is one of the world's leading havens for ''book pirates'' -printers who publish unauthorized editions of novels, nonfiction and textbooks, for which they pay neither the author nor the legal publisher.   ''South Korean officials have admitted to me that this practice is wrong, so I'm happy to see steps being taken to end it,'' said Dan Lacy, formerly a senior vice president of McGraw-Hill, who has had a longtime interest in the multibillion-dollar book-piracy industry.
lead_paragraph: In a move hailed as significant by book industry officials, a leading South Korean book publisher recently negotiated contracts with an American literary agency for 10 books by Alvin Toffler. abstract: SWORN TO OFFICE IN SEOUL: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea being congratulated by Charles H. Percy of Illinois, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. abstract: In the first canonization outside Rome since the Middle Ages, Pope John Paul II conferred sainthood Sunday on 93 Koreans and 10 French missionaries who gave their lives for their faith between 1839 and 1867.    Vatican officials said the 103 martyrs canonized were the largest number number of saints created on one occasion. The large number of Koreans also made South Korea the country with the fourth-largest number of saints of the Roman Catholic Church, after Italy, Spain and France.    The Pope performed the canonization at a mass attended by 600,000 people in a square in central Seoul. The crowd, admitted hours before the mass, was unaware that shortly before his arrival John Paul had encountered a man brandishing a toy pistol who pushed toward him on a street near the Seoul cathedral.
lead_paragraph: In the first canonization outside Rome since the Middle Ages, Pope John Paul II conferred sainthood Sunday on 93 Koreans and 10 French missionaries who gave their lives for their faith between 1839 and 1867.

abstract: Does South Korea's President, Chun Doo Hwan, want to take his country back to the primitive politics now roiling the Philippines or forward to the economic miracles of Japan?   South Korea has a more advanced industrial economy than the Philippines and faces neither insurgency nor insolvency. But there are some uncomfortable parallels of political development. South Korea, too, must learn to assure a democratic choice of its next president.

abstract: Despite its progress in developing heavy industry, South Korea is still straining to become an industrial nation.    While its path to prosperity appears the same as Japan's two decades earlier - sending a flood of manufactured goods into foreign markets - the business practices of its East Asian neighbor may hinder its development.    In any case, in today's world of slower economic growth, increased trade barriers and accelerated technological change, the ascent is expected to be far more difficult for South Korea than it was for Japan.    ''It's been said that the world was fooled once - by Japan,'' said Chung Mong-Joon, president of Hyundai Heavy Industries, a major shipbuilder that is part of Korea's largest industrial group. ''It isn't going to happen again. Climbing up the ladder to become an industrialized nation by exporting manufactured goods will be far more difficult for South Korea.''
lead_paragraph: Despite its progress in developing heavy industry, South Korea is still straining to become an industrial nation.

abstract: South Korean student demonstrators were taken into police custody today after leaving the United States Government building they had occupied for four days.   A South Korean Government spokesman said late tonight that the students would be turned over to the police at their respective universities and would be interrogated to determine whether they should be indicted. He said he did not know exactly where the students were or how many would be indicted.   The end of the student occupation came at 12:04 P.M. when the steel door grate of the United States Information Service building rolled open. The students emerged with arms linked, carrying a handmade South Korean flag and chanting, ''Down with the military dictatorship of Chun Doo Hwan'' - the South Korea President.
lead_paragraph: South Korean student demonstrators were taken into police custody today after leaving the United States Government building they had occupied for four days.

abstract: Pope John Paul II began a four-day visit here today by expressing the hope that South Korea's economic progress would lead to ''a more human society of true justice and peace.''    He said he prayed that the Korean peninsula, divided for four decades, would be reunited ''through dialogue, mutual trust and brotherly love.''   The Pope spoke on arriving at the airport to a stiffly ceremonial reception amid heavy security. He was greeted by President Chun Doo Hwan and a crowd of 1,600 people who were reportedly carefully selected. Crowds lined the streets to watch the Pope pass in his special automobile.
lead_paragraph: Pope John Paul II began a four-day visit here today by expressing the hope that South Korea's economic progress would lead to ''a more human society of true justice and peace.''

abstract: Charges of a multimillion-dollar bribery scheme in which American and European rice traders were said to be paying off South Korean officials have sounded alarm bells in Congress.   The case, simmering since October, took on new intensity last week when a civil suit filed in California accused the rice traders of using at least $6 million in overcharges to bribe representatives of the South Korean Government for arranging favorable deals.   The rice trade has long been marked by controversy, including a Washington scandal in the late 1970's. Now the Justice Department, whose antitrust division already had a grand jury in San Francisco examining the industry, has received a request from three members of Congress to investigate allegations similar to those contained in the California suit.
lead_paragraph: Charges of a multimillion-dollar bribery scheme in which American and European rice traders were said to be paying off South Korean officials have sounded alarm bells in Congress.

abstract: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that the shooting down of a Korean passenger jet by the Soviet Union ''while reprehensible, is something one can understand as a mixup.'' He said at a news conference that the shooting could have occurred ''through a collection of misunderstandings, accidents, bureaucratic mixups in which the various commanders decided they would never be able to explain to Moscow why they let a plane that had wandered over their territory go.''

abstract: Several contradictions have emerged in the accounts of the downing of the Korean Air Lines passenger plane as given by United States and Soviet officials and in the transcript of conversations of the Soviet fighter pilots. These are the main points of contradiction:   NAVIGATIONAL LIGHTS - The Soviet Union has repeatedly said that the Korean airliner was flying in Soviet airspace without navigational lights. In the transcript of the Soviet pilots' conversation with Soviet ground control, the pilots refer three times to the airliner's blinking strobe lights. The United States has insisted the airliner was flying with its lights on.

abstract: LEAD: EVEN as South Korea modernizes and the people adopt Western dining habits - even with Wendy's and Burger Kings dotting Seoul - the native cuisine remains intact. Visitors to the Olympic Games, which open in Seoul Friday, will find that the dishes served in restaurants and homes are based on recipes hundreds of years old, the cuisine of a culture that dates back some 5,000 years.
lead_paragraph: EVEN as South Korea modernizes and the people adopt Western dining habits - even with Wendy's and Burger Kings dotting Seoul - the native cuisine remains intact. Visitors to the Olympic Games, which open in Seoul Friday, will find that the dishes served in restaurants and homes are based on recipes hundreds of years old, the cuisine of a culture that dates back some 5,000 years.

abstract: Since the end of the Korean War, American strategy for keeping peace in the Pacific ultimately hinged on the looming presence of a huge arsenal of American tactical nuclear weapons, stored at its bases in South Korea and aboard the ships of its Pacific fleet.   So when Asia's leadership awoke this morning to hear President Bush sweep that deterrent away, their public declarations of support also came amid an undercurrent of misgivings -- chiefly about whether Mr. Bush may be one step too far ahead of the pace of change in Asia.
lead_paragraph: Since the end of the Korean War, American strategy for keeping peace in the Pacific ultimately hinged on the looming presence of a huge arsenal of American tactical nuclear weapons, stored at its bases in South Korea and aboard the ships of its Pacific fleet.

abstract: The Korean Central Intelligence Agency, which was founded in 1961 and used by President Park Chung Hee for political repression until his murder by the agency's head, has been renamed the Agency for National Security Planning by President Chun Doo Hwan.    ''Despite the change in name, the N.S.P. will continue to carry out such jobs undertaken hitherto by the K.C.I.A.,'' The Korea Herald, an English-language daily in Seoul, said. The Korean authorities were quoted by newspapers as admitting that the old agency was guilty of ''absurdities and irrational practices.''
lead_paragraph: The Korean Central Intelligence Agency, which was founded in 1961 and used by President Park Chung Hee for political repression until his murder by the agency's head, has been renamed the Agency for National Security Planning by President Chun Doo Hwan.

abstract: AT about this time last year, North and South Korea were swept up in a rare outbreak of civility. For months they had been meeting more or less regularly, discussing visits between members of war-torn families, possible economic cooperation and joint sports ventures. While no significant progress could be claimed, even mere talk was noteworthy, given four decades of hatred between them. If nothing else, the discussions offered a sliver of hope that both sides were ready to ease tensions on their heavily armed peninsula and that the North was finally trying to emerge from its thick shell of diplomatic isolation.   But last year's optimism has been overtaken by grim reality. Not a single meeting has been held in 1986, and the likelihood of one in the near future seemed close to zero last week after a terrorist bomb exploded at the Seoul airport, killing 5 people and wounding about 30 others.

abstract: President Roh Tae Woo today replaced the prime minister and the foreign minister and shuffled eight other Cabinet posts in a bid to spruce up his party's image before next year's elections.   Ro Jai Bong, 54, a chief aide who holds a doctorate from New York University, was named to succeed Prime Minister Kang Young Hoon. Mr. Kang had reportedly asked to retire from public life.   Mr. Ro would be expected to lead South Korea's delegation in a fourth round of high-level talks on easing tensions with longtime rival North Korea, scheduled for February.   Named as foreign minister was Lee Sang Ok, the ambassador to Switzerland.
lead_paragraph: President Roh Tae Woo today replaced the prime minister and the foreign minister and shuffled eight other Cabinet posts in a bid to spruce up his party's image before next year's elections.

abstract: The State Department issued a historical volume today on relations with Korea in 1952-54, which included discussions on the possible use of American atomic weapons against North Korea and China. Here are excerpts from discussions on their use that involved Gen. J. S. Bradley, staff officer, Joint Chiefs of Staff; John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State; Gen. John E. Hull, deputy chief of staff for operations administration, U.S. Army; Deane W. Malott, president of Cornell University, member of special advisory committee for the President, and Adm. Arthur W. Radford, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.       Special National Security Council Meeting    March 31, 1953     The President then raised the question of the use of atomic weapons in the Korean War. Admittedly, he said, there were not many good tactical targets, but he felt it would be worth the cost if, through use of atomic weapons, we could (1) achieve a substantial victory over the Communist forces and (2) get to a line at the waist of Korea.

abstract: Vice President Bush, the highest official of the Reagan Administration to visit South Korea, arrived here this morning amid increasing expressions of concern in Korea about growing anti-American sentiment.   Mr. Bush, who came from Japan after a two-day visit, is on a tour of Asia that is scheduled to last two weeks.  Mr. Bush's three-day tour is part of celebrations marking a hundred years of American contacts with Korea. It is also designed to reaffirm traditional American military and diplomatic support for the Seoul Government. Mr. Bush is to visit a United States Army unit close to the demilitarized zone between North and South Korea - there are about 40,000 American soldiers in the south - and to confer with President Chun Doo Hwan on military and political issues.   Preparations for the visit were low key, with few of the giant welcome signs that are the usual greeting for Americans of high rank.  There are signs of concern among Korean officials about how the United States will respond to signs of anti-Americanism here. One of these signs was arson at the American Cultural Center in Pusan last month that was led by theology students. The incident was widely interpreted by churchmen, including conservatives, as an emotional outburst against American support for Mr. Chun.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Bush, the highest official of the Reagan Administration to visit South Korea, arrived here this morning amid increasing expressions of concern in Korea about growing anti-American sentiment.
